Very high quality breads! Good sandwiches. Huge selection of fresh baked breads. Not much else.  Cinnamon currant bread was delicious! Prices are fair.  Cheese and jam and arugula on the cheese sandwich was super good!

I'd definitely go back. Highly recommended if you like fresh crusty artisan breads.
author: Steve A.

description:
As I said in one of my earlier reviews I wanted to get some sourdough to bring back home with me.  Had already gone to one place on my list and now was the time to get another loaf.  Stopped in at Acme and picked up a smaller loaf for the plane trip back home.  Unfortunately they didn't have a plastic bag for this one so I knew I was going to have to consume it sooner than later.

This bread was crispy on the outside.  A different version from the other loaf I brought home.  I actually ate this one in about 2 days as towards the end it was starting to get a bit stale.  Very good bread though and for just under $3 a very good deal as well.

Keep in mind they are cash only.
author: Dan H.

description:
So so delicious.  So so many choices.  I controlled myself today and only bought two hot dog buns, which will hold my Prather all beef natural hotdogs.  Their buns are .75 each and are heads and shoulders above the usual cottony stale buns available in your local supermarket.

If you're going to eat carbs, make sure they are delicious, right?
author: .Hon H.

description: If there is a heaven, it includes Acme Bread Company. This is carbohydrate heaven. Don't kid yourself, you're not going to buy one baguette for now and save one for later, you're going to demolish both of those bad boys before you get to Coit Tower.
author: Dylan K.

description:
Ordered the green onion loaf. 

Great textural exterior with an amazing crunch while maintaining a fluffy, light interior. They really know how to make bread but man $3:30 a loaf is a tad high for me.

Overall Thoughts

Another amazing Ferry Place shop despite the slightly elevated cost
author: Eddie W.

description:
It's rare a baguette makes it out of the Ferry Building with both ends in tact. You can always track me down; just follow the trail of crumbs. But, please, don't eat them so I can find my way back! http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hansel_and_Gretel#Plot_of_the_story

If not the baguette, a smaller treat: a rosemary roll, a cross bun, a currant roll.
Larger 'treats' for special occasions: green olive loaf, challah, an herb slab.
Maybe one of everything. Each one, another excuse to go next door to Cowgirl and stock up on accompanying cheese. What started off as a snack, turned into a picnic in no time. Or perhaps a sandwich. Skimpy on the fillings (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/I19ntZQrZxMn9gYOOK1rhg?userid=Suw8tiW7EHWpt7HhuB7SDw#f2uO4BCWknUUTVJT94-T7w), but super flavorful. 

Always wonderful. Always a trail of crumbs.
author: Alissa A.

description: Really disappointing. I live in Berkeley and I usually get my bread and pastries from Acme. I assumed the Ferry Building Acme Bread would have the same quality. I bought an almond croissant (nearly $3) for my parents since they were visiting and it was cold and dry!! Tasted like it was from yesterday's batch. Too many tourists... they probably don't care about quality. Never getting pastry there again.
author: Sandy C.

description:
Amazing bread. It is always fresh and the fresh bread aroma is enough to make the day seem somewhat brighter and lovelier.

The line can get long at times but they are fast. I think they have the best sourdough bread in town. Everything else I got from this place had never disappointed ever. I usually get one of their sour dough loaves, get cheese from Cow Girl Creamery next door, then bring my loot either to the benches in the back of the Ferry Building or to Justin Hermann Plaza. 

Cash only.
author: Clarice O.

description: I love their bread. The sourdough batards. The olive roll. The cheese roll. Amazing.  You just have to try it yourself. The loaf was a little dry so I really suggest getting the rolls instead. You wouldn't be disappointed at all with anything you get here.
author: Han Teng W.

description: When it comes to sourdough bread, I immediately think of Boudin. However, I've been hearing great things about Acme and was excited to find it conveniently in the Ferry Building Marketplace. I chose a large Sour Round to bring back to my brother since he loves sourdough bread and an individual-size Sourdough Cheese Roll. Their counter is filled with their many bread options with descriptions and prices. It is cash only, so be prepared (there are BOA ATMs in the Marketplace). We enjoyed the Sour Round a couple days later as toasted garlic bread and it was very good! I look forward to trying more of their breads in the future.
author: Amelinda L.

description: One of the top sourdough rounds for me so far. You could rip off one of the shiny scored chips on top as a weapon if you should happen to get into an impromptu street rumble while carrying it home. Bread crust should be chewy and tough-ish in my view and this was perfect, with the usual softer inner bit. I also like that they have a smaller country loaf and many different sourdoughs. Just delicious!
author: Michele D.

description:
This bread and bakery is so good they can be CASH ONLY and still have a line! 
Who has cash??? The wallnut rasin bread is incrediable.
author: Katie F.

description: i'm going to start off by stating that i'm not a big bread person, but anything from Acme Bread Co. is life changing.  if you like sweet or savory you would be hard pressed to find something that wouldn't satisfy you.  the morning staff are all cool peeps and very friendly.  i always leave happier than when i came in.  be prepared to wait in line, there is alway one, but always worth the wait.  the bacon puffs are money.
author: Hiki L.

description: Love the breads here... especially the pan epi.  Every time I come into town, I always try to make it to the Ferry Building to get fresh bread.
author: Kayla N.

description:
Don't ever, not for one moment, think that just because The Ferry Building is a major tourist attraction, that there is nothing good inside of it.

There are a lot of really fabulous and wonderful things. Acme Bread Company is one of those things.

Some places in the Ferry building are just little hubs/kiosk-type-things of a much larger location somewhere else in the city. Acme Bread Company actually makes their bread onsite.

It's perfect for taking home or a little snacky. I've been there about three times in the last week. First to get a cheesy bread roll for breakfast.

That is a beautiful mystery of a bread. It's bread, but somehow still holds its cheesy consistency. Is it because it's sourdough? Is it because it's probably baked with real love?

The second bread items I bought were large baguettes. You grab a hold of the bread, and you might even think, "this is a really hard piece of bread." 
Do not bite right into this bread. Go home, cut it up, and use it to wipe up gravy, chili, pasta sauce, dip it in spinach dip, place cheese atop of it, or slather it with butter. The outside will be crunchy, but the inside will be the correct kind of chewy. The sourdough flavor will be mild but definitely there, and authentic.

The most recent item I purchased was a chocolate croissant. It smells like butter. It's flaky but not like bad dandruff. The consistency of the dark/semisweet chocolate is firm. These are made with real, true ingredients. What would send this treat over the edge would be these two things: a nice cup of coffee from probably Blue Bottle, and if it were a tiny bit warm.

As far as the lines go for this place, they may look long, but they move pretty fast. I will be trying to go to this little gem more frequently in the future.
author: Natalie C.

description:
I have always loved baguettes, but then my cousin introduced me to the epi at Acme and now.. nothing can match it. The only other place I've seen an epi is at Bouchon. Also have tried the cranberry walnut, YUM!

I took my friend here to get an epi, then some cheese from Cowgirl Creamery, and some Blue Bottle cappuccinos, and it made for an absolutely perfect picnic. My friend was like WOW this bread is soooo good. Yes, it is. Welcome to SF.
author: Vivian H.

description:
..I really wish I weren't, but I'm such a fan. I can't control myself when we get a loaf of Acme bread. Which is like twice a week. As a result, I have huge carb-licious days twice a week because it only lasts a day when I'm home LOL.

It all started when my father bought a loaf of the whole wheat walnut bread when we happened to be in the Ferry building. At first, I was straight-up disapproving of it because although it does say "whole wheat," it's actually 73% whole wheat. However, we were waiting at the Oyster restaurant and I was really hungry, so I stole a little bit and OHMYGOD.  I should have known not to take a bite when it said "walnut" because I'm a huge sucker for bread with nuts!

The bread is soft on the inside with TONS of walnut, which gives it a nice chew/bite. The outside is crisp, but not firm enough where you have to really work to tear off a piece. The best part? It's just as amazing the next day! I've also had their cranberry walnut bread and I didn't like it as much; I think it's because the cranberry just made it too sweet. In the end, I was purposely looking for parts that didn't have cranberries in it.

Now we get it from our local Whole Foods because San Francisco is way too far away. I honestly have no idea how much it is; I'm too blinded by that walnut-studded beauty to even glance at the price. I know they sell it in the Sunnyvale farmers' market as well, so if you're around Sunnyvale Saturdays 8am-1pm, grab a fresh loaf before they run out! 
*TIP: Whole Foods will slice the loaf if you go up to their bakery department and ask. 

SAVE YOURSELF WHILE YOU CAN. Don't buy a loaf or you'll be hooked on it like me! Unless you don't mind hehe.
author: Jackie S.

description: Authentic European style bakery with quite reasonable price tag. Good taste, lots of choices, ideal location, and LONG line.
author: Eric H.

description:
to be honest, i used to be super dubious about acme bread.  walking around the ferry building, the line wraps around the register about three times on a good saturday, and theyre cash only. and i mean, how good can the bread be?!

a few weeks ago, my parents were in town and we were getting dinner around the area, so we were just strolling, and there was no line! while my dad picked up a block of cheese at cowgirl creamery, i picked up a green onion slab to make sandwiches with the next day.. it was $3.80 for a HUGE bready slab. amazing..!

we taped the packaging shut to preserve the flavors, and man oh man, was the bread good the next day!  the was a good amount of sliced scallions throughout, and it was just so soft and savory and delicious. perfect for making an easy sandwich because there was already good flavor from the bread. it kinda reminds me of a shanghainese scallion pancake! mmmmyummms!

more recently i got an herb slab, and that was equally amazing. woot! THUMBS UP acme bread! :) im a believer now.
author: Christina L.

description: These folks definitely know how to make bread!  The sandwiches were fantastic. Highly recommend cheese and fig!  Personally I think anything would be great with there bread!
author: Tri H.

description:
I grew up in the peninsula, so I'd never really come up to the Ferry Building.  However, I can remember countless Saturdays as a child, going to local farmer's markets and ALWAYS buying bread from Acme Bread Company.  And loving it.

Seriously reminds me of my childhood.  I think I also liked it because it reminded me of the Acme Song from Animaniacs on WB 20...
author: Jennifer L.

description: This place should have been 5 stars. It's simply the best bread ever, the bread I missed so much while living across the globe, the souvenir I bring all my friends and family when traveling. 0 stars is the TERRIBLE customer service I received today at the ferry building. Went up to a employee who (seemed like the manager) was standing on the side of the counter today and asked about the breads. She rudely said "I'm busy doing something! Look yourself!" WTF??? She was a short white girl with medium length hair, didn't bother to get her name. Anyway, I just won't come back again. Yes, they have the best bread, but that's not the way you treat customers. if you think you're so great and don't need any customers fine then you won't be getting my business again.
author: Leo D.

description: Best.  Bread.  Ever.  We were going to get ice cream as dessert since we saw so many people with ice cream, but while waiting in line to get a loaf of sourdough bread, I saw that Acme made cinnamon currants!  I usually get cinnamon rolls as my pastry of choice but the currant looked so glossy and way better than the roll.  My significant other was initially going to get ice cream and not share the currant with me, but after taking a bite, he loved the currant immediately so we shared it :)  It was the right amount of sweetness and the glaze was mostly at the bottom.  The bread was soft yet firm and that also goes for the sourdough loaf we bought.  Wish Acme had a store closer to us since we don't go to SF that often!
author: Sam T.

description:
When I worked a few blocks away, I'd head over for lunch as often as I could. Every sandwich I tried was as delicious and fresh as it was simple.  I'd get a sourdough baguette too. The sandwich is lunch and the baguette is because, well, it's just too good not to get and sneak bites of throughout the day.

If you love bread, love sourdough, and love San Francisco, then...

...I forget where I was going with this. But this place is a great bet if you're looking for San Francisco sourdough, a sammich, or both.
author: Jeff S.

description:
I was volunteering at Laguna Honda Hospice one Friday, helping out at their bimonthly Happy Hour.

After all the food was cooked and drinks were served, it was my turn to dig in.  Of course I couldn't resist the bread and butter, even though I know better than to load myself up with unnecessary carbs.

I slathered the slice of bread with butter and took a bite.

Oh.  My.  God.  Bread.. with OLIVES?  Normally I'd think it's a bit odd, but I *love* olives.  I had to get a second slice and this time I devoured it without butter.  Even BETTER.  It felt like a life-changing moment, as if somebody from the heavens had called out to me.

I had to ask - where did this bread COME from??  Not getting any helpful answers, I decided to look on the bag.  "Acme Bread" it said.  That was the start of our relationship.

I love Acme, but I hate that it's located in the ferry building where parking is scarce and 5 cents a minute.  It's okay - the trek is worth it.  I've tried Acme from Andronico's, and it's not the same.

Acme, I'm so in love with you.
author: Vivian H.

description: Great bread for cheap at a convenient location, and no need to wait in a line! I came here today for the cheese wheel and while it was good, it would've been significantly better if they could warm it up for you. I'm definitely coming back to try some of their other breads and pastries :)
author: Austin W.

description:
I'm a carbo-vore!  My love of breads started at a young age; I remember seeing a picture of me as a toddler with a third of a baguette in one hand.  For the past year I've been discovering how yummy Acme Bread is every time I get Roli Roti's orgasmic Porchetta sandwich.  While the bread is delicious, the Porchetta outshines everything!  

The true test though was this weekend when my cousin brought over Acme's Pain Epi.  Oh my!  It was so delish, I didn't even need butter!  Chewy and hard enough & not too much flour dusting.  Their bread is super fresh too!  Watch out for me on BART I may accidentally whack you with a baguette or two, but at least you'll be hit by good bread!
author: Cat C.

description:
Acme is one of my favorite bakeries. I love their sourdough anything and usually tear off a piece to eat on my way home because it smells so good I just can't wait the 20 minutes. 

The line can get a little long on the weekends in particular, but it normally moves quickly. Yesterday I stopped in after work and there were only a handful of people there. Unfortunately, they always run out of baguettes and yesterday was no exception. But the woman helped me pick out something similar and it was perfect for my cheese plate needs.

Cash only.
author: Rachel E.

description:
Herb slab bread! Its all about the herb slab bread..

I now understand why there is always a long line for this place. So good. I picked up the herb slab bread and ate it with the Porchetta that I got from Roli Roti. So good!!!!
author: Phuong K.

description:
I ate another sandwich here today.  The cheese sandwich, with Mt. Tam cream cheese, arugula, figs/sweet fruit jam, and black pepper.  For $5.15, it was a delicious and light lunch!  

+ The bread, as always, was much the crunchies yet didn't hurt the roof of my mouth.
+ The cheese was creamy and light, just how I like it!
+ The fig jam was a great complement!  Balances out the cheese!  This was also my first time having figs in a sandwich, and I approve now!  I will no longer make fun of people who pay homage to trendy figs because there is some truth to it - it IS good!  
+ The arugula didn't do much for me, I couldn't really taste it, but at least the color was nice? 

It was also such a chilly day, but it was still sunny, and the sky was so blue.  Plus, it's almost December, my favorite time of the year.  Ah, yes.

So, imagine this: you have a nice, simple sandwich, and you have the Ferry Building, and the sun and the blue, and the water, and the Bay, and the ice skating rink, and the farmers market with free samples.

Don't see anything wrong with the picture?

Well, you're right.  There's nothing wrong with that picture.  It was just right.
author: Vivian C.

description:
ACME BREAD IS LOVE. ACME BREAD IS LIFE.

The best, most affordable bread I've ever encountered. Puts all supermarket brands to shame. You can choose from a big variety of bread. So many options... some of these are small sandwich rolls, salty olive loafs, levains, batards, sweet rustic baguettes, and pain de mies. Specialty offerings, like challah, are killer.

Go here, fill yourself with their carbs, and feel invincible for the rest of the day.
author: Dominique F.

description:
There are very few things in life that are better than a fresh Acme epi paired with burrata from Cowgirl Creamery next door.

The line is always long but moves quickly!
author: Carrie C.

description:
On my great food tour of San Francisco, Acme provided me the most surprisingly delicious dish. It was some sort of bread item with asparagus baked into the top, and just thinking about it is making me hungry 2,800 miles away.

It was only a few dollars, and the first surprise was the size. I expected a little savory treat, but what I got was bigger than a VHS tape (I realize this may not mean anything to young yelpers. It was of substantial size). It wasn't as warm as I thought it would be (not "fresh out of the oven") which I thought was going to be a disappointment, but the trace heat left within was enough. I don't have the tasting vocabulary to appropriately describe the swirl of tender, melted texture along with the dazzling explosion of flavor, but on a trip that included some serious fine dining, it's no exaggeration to say that asparagus thing may be the best bite of food I had.
author: Jack R.

description: This bread is legit! I hate myself for loving a great baguette or any bread for that matter but Acme bread is just perfect. I had a few different kinds during my weekend visit to SF and paired them with little hunks of cheese from Cowgirl next door. My friend and I would munch down on our gluttonous snacks in the back of the ferry building by the water on a bench. We would eat them so fast that we were tempted on many occasions to go back in and get more but we always had a full day of eating during our trip so we resisted. I am kind of happy there is no Acme bread at home!
author: Vanessa M.

description:
There is a line here for a reason. It was so long that security came and told us to snake around so that we wouldn't block incoming traffic. They have a lot of different types of bread laid out on their table, so it becomes pretty hard to choose what you want. I picked the olive bread because the lady in front of me took the last rosemary bread. Boooo. :(

Unfortunately, I had to stick it in the oven to reheat after it was in the fridge overnight. I was surprised that it was STILL delicious. I can easily see why it's 5 stars and will be coming back for the rosemary bread!

P.S. I believe it's cash only.
author: Allison S.

description: Cute spot.  Ordered a loaf of sourdough and the Brie sandwich.  Both not to be missed.
author: Susan M.

description:
OMG

 so good,...and so cheap ( especially for what you get )

  The Pain e'pin is lovely, delicious and goes great with just about anything !!  You can get cheese next door from CowGirl Creamery ( good, but not cheap ) and meats down the hallway from the meat company.

  It's so awesome to be able to build a picnic basket here and bring it with you to enjoy on the pier.
author: Anthony N.

description: Amazing bread and super delicious sandwiches!  The potato sandwich with pesto and creme fraiche might sound like an overload of carbs-on-carbs but it is super good and just the right size for lunch, around $6 and not too pricey given the selection of food in the Ferry Building.
author: Anita T.

description:
This is some really great bread. You're at the Ferry Building and you can get a great cheap snack to take outside to eat while you're contemplating the beauty of the bay.

My wife and I were there on a gorgeous September Friday morning. We enjoyed the Twinkle and the olive loaf. The Twinkle is a small baguette. Good stuff. The olive loaf though, wow! They sell them in these small 80 cent balls. They are soft and have olives baked in. So delicious.

Acme Bread is a highlight of any trip to the Ferry Terminal.
author: Tom M.

description: Their breads are really good and relatively cheap considering how good they are... did I mention that their breads are really good??!  I also like their pre-made sandwich options, especially the beats sandwich.
author: Christophe F.

description: They make great bread and rolls. Period! My favorite is probably the Epi-small little twists of deliciousness. Warmed int he oven or torn apart and slathered with chesse or salami. are you kidding me? Their hot dog buns and torpedo rolls are also great. They usually don't carry them at grocery stores and can only be found at their bakery locations.
author: Butch P.

description:
Fresh baked bread! 

Beware, there are long lines on Saturday mornings. I got to the Ferry Building Marketplace only 15 minutes after they opened at 8AM and I was at least #15 in line. I couldn't believe it. 

Anyhow, I love bread and I couldn't resist getting a baguette here for my picnic lunch. Between the sourdough and the rustic sweet baguette, I decided to buy the rustic sweet baguette. There were several customers before me that bought the same thing so it must be the bread of choice.

Well, I sure had no complaints. The rustic sweet baguette was the perfect accompaniment to the (salty) salumi and cheese. With a beautiful golden crust and a soft, chewy interior, I couldn't stop nibbling on this bread! 

Price: $1.90 each.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
Fantastic.  Hands down the best bread I've even had the pleasure of eating. 

It's affordable and delicious. It keeps well and I love just grabbing a school yard roll or a whole wheat deli roll just to snack on.

Now that I've had Acme, nothing else compares.
author: Laura D.

description:
Got ca$h? Better go get it.

This place is ca$h only. Totally worth the hassle of going non-plastic for a moment.

I grabbed a sourdough batard. It's San Francisco after all, how can you say no to sourdough?

...and gourmet andwiches for $5.25!? On Acme bread!? In San Francisco?? Are you kidding me? Hello, lunch!

I opted for one of the coolest sandwich flavors I've seen...potato with pesto and creme fraiche on a sweet french roll. Yup, you read right. Weird combination, but ridiculously fantabulous!

P.S. These peeps are located in Mtn View!? Since when?? Closer to me...totally dig that.
author: Mansi A.

description: Loved all the breads we purchased: Pain au Levain, Olive Bread and of course, sourdough! It definitely lived up to the reputation.
author: Tina S.

description:
Acme Bread Company is located inside the Ferry Building. I absolutely love bread so I was excited to try. I have no complaints about this place. They have a good selection of bread. Even at 4 o'clock in the afternoon on a farmer's market day, they had plenty left. There were a few photos of loaves on yelp that were sold out but we were pretty late getting there. 

My bf and I split an herb slab. A.MAZING. It was very fresh and soft and had the perfect amount of herb-y flavor. YUM. It was $3.75 for a big loaf. They also had smaller rolls and buns for under $1. The baguette was like $2.15, I think. The line moved fast and the cashier was friendly. A+
author: Hilary C.

description:
Ok so i was looking for some good bread for sometime in this city.  I found out about Acme through a Italian Deli in the Marina.  AS I was looking round the deli I saw from afar a great looking crusty baguette.  I b-Lined across the deli and of course bought the baguette.   I went home and I looked up the company and discovered they had one =of their locations in the Ferry Building.  I was excited.  

i decided to go to the Ferry Building location.
Dam.... What a line.  As I got closer to the register I started to see all those great concoctions of breads and pastry they had displayed.  The line was going fast.  I was so overwhelmed with the variety that they had.  I was going to walk out with a mini bakery.  

I got so wrapped up in all bread when I eventually reached the register to order.  I realized it was cash only.  So I ended up buying a small croissant.  

That would be the only downside; cash only.  Since my stay here in SF.  I had many kinds of there products and so far no disappointment. Great Spot.
author: A K.

description: During the Farmer's market on Saturdays, I prefer to order sandwiches from Acme (rather than order oily food from the crowded restaurant stalls behind the building). They usually offer 3 sandwich options. The pesto potato is quite good, but my favorite sandwich is the one with chevre cheese.  But, the sourdough cheese roll was a miss for me.
author: TZ J.

description:
My heart is broken.

Getting off work early is a rare treat. I can't think of a better way to spend it than with fabulous people and a stroll around the Ferry Building. Upon arriving, I realized that I may still have a chance to pick up a ham and cheese turnover before it sells out! While one of us was off to Blue Bottle, I had to make a quick beeline for Acme Bread. Once I got to the front of the line, I was told the apple turnover was sold out. I asked about the ham and cheese turnover and the man behind the counter had to break the news to me.

The ham and cheese turnover has been discontinued.

How do you mend a broken heart? I imagine the cure is something with a flaky layered crust, teeny cubes of ham peppered in gooey cheese. 

Please come back. I will splurge on my gluten intake just for you. I miss you.
author: Stella C.

description:
CASH ONLY!  After stopping at Boccalone at the Ferry Building I needed bread so went here.

I noticed w/ my trained eyes that they had Day Old Bread.  Well, if u also have trained eyes you know what to look for.  It's Half Price so u should look out for them (tip: read my older reviews)

I got: 
1 Walnut bread for $2.85
1 NY Rye for $1.65

Total $4.50 CASH ONLY!

Yeah!

Hrs:
M-F 6:20am-7:30pm
Sat & Sun 8am-7pm
author: Ann L.

description:
Fast line, cash only.

Hot cheese sandwich and salame one. Both almost $6 each and about 6 inches long.

Very good. Finished half of them the next day and still good... Bread and all!
author: Cara H.

description:
Whenever I pick up one of the tasty baguettes from Acme Bread Company, I feel a strong urge to beat someone over the head with it. But then I would be depriving myself of its crusty sweet goodness. A tough decision, for sure, but ultimately my stomach wins out. 

I don't make it out to the Ferry building as often as I'd like, but when I do, I grab some breads from Acme without fail. I usually opt for the baguettes (sweet, italian, or sourdough), but I've ventured out from time to time. Their bread is so good lightly baked with some butter, or olive oil, or nice cheese from next door. And for the most part, their bread is really cheap! That's not something you'd expect from a top-tier bakery. I love Acme bread. 

If one day I decide that I can't resist anymore, you better watch out, cuz I'm coming for you with that sourdough.
author: Saunders C.

description:
Lines were long, incredibly long. 

Service was fast unless idiot/slow customers ordering.

Cash only establishment- why? 

Croissants, buns, baguettes, rolls, ciabbiata.. endless selections but I wish the selections were easily readily for the customers in line to see because you see everything when you are up there but w/ the pressure of ordering quickly can have you leaving feeling unsatisfied because you may miss something that you originally did not see till after! 

I got the sourdough baguette and an onion loaf.. the onion loaf was good but not onion-y enough for me... I actually dived into it on my way to Chinatown.. I was surprised I wasn't thirsty because I ate 1/4 of it while I was hiking up and down the SF hills.. 

Service was fast/friendly. 

My cons- selections (cannot see all that was available till you are up) and it's a cash only joint. 

I will see if the sourdough baguette is any different than Anderson, Panera, and Boudin before I dismiss this entirely.
author: Tram N.

description: The best bread in the Bay Area, hands down! I have tried almost all their bread, and they're all full of flavors. You have to like the crust though. It reminds me of Parisian bread...
author: Kinder H.

description: Do yourself a favor and head straight to the Ferry Building, get a pain epi from Acme and a hunk of cheese from Cowgirl, and find a bench outside.  The bread here is to die for and the pain epi is the cream of the crop.  The sourdough and pumpkin loaf were also awesome.  Five stars all the way!
author: Laura L.

description:
Yummy rustic bread! Thin crunchy outside with a chew. 
They have different kinds of rolls like challah rolls, olive rolls, raisin rolls, etc.
author: Linda T.

description:
Ok bread if you can get it. And forget about having decent service from these people. Trying to help is the least thing on their mind. Location is great though.

Don't try their sandwiches, they are very dry. And most of their bread has thick crust, it may not be everyone's cup of tea.
author: Jess T.

description:
Perfect time to come here is before Thanksgiving because they have the best pumpkin/nuts rolls!! yummm! For less than $2 each, these rolls have a nice touch of pumpkin and tons of nuts. It's located in the Ferry Building which you can pick up everything under one roof. They offer many different types of breads but once I saw "pumpkin" I was hypnotized. 

So bring c@$h and an empty stomach here and grab some carb luvin' bread!
author: Santi T.

description:
Bread = my friend. my enemy.  my love.  total bane of my existence.  It's a real love-hate relationship--I love bread, and my body hates me for all the carbs. :)

I love the green onion slab here (and when they say slab, they mean a SLAB), and their baguettes (crunchy outsides, soft insides).  And everything else that they make of the baked variety.   I love the bread that's all stuck together in a leaf-like formation, but you can warm it up a bit, and pull it apart. 

They don't just have savory breads...they have some sweet pastries too.  

Service = friendly.

This place is cash only, so be prepared.  In other words, don't bother asking re cards.  There is an ATM in the building, or walk your butt down the street, as it IS near the Financial District and get some cash from any of the bank ATMs.
author: Fannie S.

description:
After all the walking we did in SF, my body was craving carbs.  Acme Bread Company not only satisfied my craving but made me a fan of their olive loaves, green onion slab, and sourdough baguettes. Oh, and did I mention they make delicious sandwiches (served from 11-2:30 for $5.15/ea)?  The green garlic sandwich is amazingly delicious (I am kicking myself for not buying more than one for the road).  

Bring lots of cash (no credit cards accepted here) you'll WANT to get a couple of loaves to take home.  For a real treat, pick up some bread from Acme Bread Company, go next door to Cow Girl Creamery (buy a Red Hawk or Mt. Tam), stop by Boccalone for a few slices of procuitto and make yourself an amazing snack!
author: Kelly K.

description: Here at the ferry building or at SFO airport are my favorite locations to grab a loaf of wonderful, fresh sourdough bread whenever I visit San Francisco. I enjoy those crusty  loaves made without whey (milk products). Can't leave the city without a loaf for the long flight home. Love, love, love the quality.
author: Lynn S.

description: I bought a little pumpkin roll during my walk-through of the Ferry Building and it was so good that I bought one for my friend who I was going to meet up with later in the day.  I was amazed at how soft the bread was.  Wish I could have eaten more but I had to save room since this was our first stop of the day.  The guy behind the counter who helped me was really nice too!
author: Nat N.

description:
What can I say about Acme bread here that everyone else hasn't already raved about?? The bread is undeniably good here! 

My favorites??
-Pain Epi: Basically a baguette but they shape it like little flames coming off each other. It's really easy to rip off chunks of the flames and make little sandwiches out of them. I love to spread some cheese and stuff it with some good deli meat and VOLIA! You've got some LOVE IN YOUR TUMMY!!! 

-Cinnamon Currant Bread: Basically tastes like a loaf of really good cinnamon bread. Comes with and without walnuts. I don't think the ferry building Acme bread location has the walnut option like Berkeley does. I seriously LOVE this loaf of bread and the ONLY reason I'm giving this location a 4/5 star is because the cinnamon currant loaf here is HALF the size of the loaf you get at the Berkeley location and it's the SAME PRICE!!!! What is up with that?!?!?! So if you are looking for some good currant bread...GO TO BERKELEY
author: Amiee H.

description: 4 Stars are for the location and the crusty walnut bread. The 5th star is missing, because the sales person could be friendlier.
author: M R.

description: Whenever I need to bring something to a dinner party getting bread here is a really cheap and tasty option. I think my favorite bread is the onion slab which is tasty on its own but great with some cured meats and cheeses.  (Conveniently you can also get these in the Ferry Building.) The last time I came here I bought two loaves of the onion slab for an office potluck and I felt it was a great compliment to the foods other people brought to the party. Both loaves disappeared in short order. It was fast and easy and really cheap. Definitely recommend buying bread here if you have an occasion to share it with some folks.
author: Huy V.

description: Fresh bread with some fresh fig and cheese. I got the sandwich of the day which had their baguette type of bread. It came with the Mt Tam cheese from Cowgirl Creamery and this delicious fig. All together it was bites of cheese/bread heaven with a kick of sweetness. I think the baguette type of bread was a sourdough and I'm not usually a sourdough fan but this was good stuff. I can't forget the argula and pepper that was inside this sandwich. I'm so eating this again when I come back to SF!
author: Andy N.

description:
I came here for lunch on Friday afternoon with a friend who was on break from work.  I got the pre-made sandwich that has goat cheese/jam/etc and it was just eh.  There was hardly any cheese on the bread, hardly any jam, or really any flavor.  You essentially just ate BREAD.  

The bread was good but there is no seating so you have to stand awkwardly (who wants to stand while eating?) and I felt like the only good thing about it was that it cost me 5.15 verses the outrageous 9 dollar sandwiches that their competitors sell.

Don't think I'll be coming back here again.

OH AND THEY ONLY TAKE CASH.  What is this, 1960???
author: Tamara W.

description: Very disappointed! I LOVE ACME BREAD but I HATE the service. What is wrong with the young asian cashier? I have NEVER met anyone more rude in my life. I've seen how rude she is with other customers too. If you don't like/enjoy your job QUIT IT! She needs a customer service class and a shower ASAP! (Smelly) Hey ACME BREAD MANAGEMENT you guys need more employees like the Hispanic lady who is always up front. She always greets me and everyone else with a big smile and always has a positive attitude. Two thumbs up for you señorita!
author: Jasmine R.

description:
4.5/5. Acme doesn't make the best bread I've had -- I've been to some pretty darn good bakeries in and around Paris -- but they do sell one of the best baguettes in the Bay. It's fitting that they would have a location at the Ferry Building, since practically ever store sells something on Acme Bread.

I always wondered why Acme Bread tasted better at nice restaurants than at, say, Whole Foods, until I realized that some of their breads (the sweet rustic dough breads in particular) are only sold directly to restaurants or at their retail locations. 

Baguettes here have a light, but crisp crust. They're authentic, unlike many of those tough baguettes they now sell at Whole Foods that are coated on the bottom with small sesame seeds. It's a great store, although the selection is a bit limited compared to the flagship Berkeley store.
author: Pierre B.

description:
Acme bread has a food stand at the farmer's market and also a store inside the ferry building. i'm glad i waited to to see the display of breads inside. every bread available (most under $3) was on display with a price in plain view. very easy to choose. sammies available also. short lines, fast service.

tried sour batard(2.45) ciabatta (2.45). not disappointed. found i no longer like sour bread. maybe only in french bread. bread went well with the steak and duck confit.

crumbs:
-many food stands and delis specially mention they use acme bread.
-short line inside ferry which moves fast.
-cashiers courteious, efficient, and patient..
-definite return..
author: Victor G.

description:
Before a cruise on the Hornblower, my husband and I stopped in the Ferry Building to get linner. After finishing up, I ingenuously thought it would be a good idea to get some bread from Acme to bring on the ship to soak up all of the alcohol that I would be pouring down my throat later that evening. I headed over to their shop and saw the long queue that had been set up for customers but luckily, I was one of two oddballs getting bread at the hour. 

I had heard that Acme can sell out before closing so I wasn't sure how much selection there would be left around 1pm but much to my surprise, there was an ample amount of loafs and rounds. I picked out what I thought was a small round for $2.80 but when he turned around to put the bread in the bag, I realized how absolutely massive it was. We headed out to the cruise where instead of getting dizzy from excessive alcohol intake, I got dizzy from an extreme and unfortunate bout of nausea and vertigo. I ended up spending the evening on the floor with a glass of ginger ale and the bread loaf and was constantly thanking my lucky stars for grabbing that bread as it was a total lifesaver that evening. I ate little bits of the round and it so incredibly good but I was afraid to eat too much. Soon after I got off the boat I was feeling better and later that night in the hotel room, I went to town on the bread. It was sooooo good. What little remained was then taken back home with us and we enjoyed the rest of it with cheese and salame. 

I would highly recommend stopping by Acme and getting some of their bread- it's absolutely amazing!!!
author: Nicole I.

description: I got a cinnamon swirl at the Ferry Bldg yesterday and with their brisk business I was surprised that it tasted like day old. Dry. Flavor was good though, and i assume their other breads are pretty good.
author: Sue W.

description:
Bread is such an evil thing for my tummy. I eat it and the belly blows up like a balloon on a helium tank. Add a beer to the mix (because I tend to crave beer and bread together, along with candy) and I feel like I might just start to float in the air. 

I think this some of the best bread around. I love it. The crispy, (today warm) Epi, was just perfect today and the cranberry walnut bread was to die for. (Yes, when I decide to fall off the bread wagon, I fall hard). I ate, and ate, and ate it as I drove through rush-hour SF traffic, knowing the tummy ache about to happen was so worth it. 

Now to figure out what to do with the rest. I think croutons with the cranberry walnut and making a spinach salad to put them on.
author: Theresa S.

description: Acme Bread you are amazing. I would definitely recommend getting an Olive Bread Loaf or Roll and an Herb Slab. I got two Olive Bread Rolls and an Herb Slab for $6 and then went next door and bought some Cowgirl Creamery Cheese. These are a few of my favorite things
author: Erica C.

description: Love the pain epi and the herb slab. I've never tried or bothered with anything else. The herb slab makes for a killer BLTA, you should definitely try it. The pain epi is best eaten immediately with some good, salty French butter. That is all.
author: Annie C.

description: Still good but afternoon staff can be apathetically slow to serve customers who are running to catch a ferry home ...
author: Teri B.

description:
Acme bread is simply the best. Whatever you try here can't go wrong, you'll walk out with a satisfied and content feeling from consuming some of the best bread in the world. Or maybe that's just the feeling of digesting carbs. 

For today I went and grabbed a rosemary roll, and it was just heaven. "What? BREAD=HEAVEN? Aren't you being a little dramatic" ... Bread is serious stuff and trust me, this was pretty damn good bread for 60cents! The perfect little bite to accompany lunch. 

Acme at this location also serves 3 sandwiches, from 11-2:30 or until sold out. Try their potato sandwich! It's delish. As with everything else

Only cash!
author: Sandra L.

description:
Delectable artisanal breads that don't cost an arm and a leg! 

* Pumpkin roll ($1.10): Crisp crust, mellow squash flavor, deliciously nutty. The cranberries and raisins provided a nice moist, tangy accent. 

* Sourdough cheese wheel ($2.15): A meal in itself, and so satisfying if you're a fan of sharp, salty cheeses (parm used here!). Chewy edges with a soft, fluffy, CHEESY center with a very slight bite.

Next up: croissants and sammiches! Acme has me thinkin' an all-carb diet wouldn't be so bad after all...
author: Pauline D.

description:
It's like fireflies to a light...I can't not stop here without a bundle of baked goodness.  You have not lived until you've had some creamy Mt. Tam with some fig jam between slices of their bread, or a 4505 dog in their buns.  

Low carb diets are Soooo overrated.
author: Maria S.

description:
I am seriously craving one of their salami sandwiches.  Such a simple sandwich - salami, cornichons, and butter -- but so ridiculously delicious.  This is carb heaven.  Next time if I don't have a flight to catch home, I'm going to bring back some loaves of bread; that is, assuming that I don't eat all of it on my way to the airport.

Cash only.
author: Marcin M.

description:
Absolutely awesome freshly baked bread.  The Pain Epi is the best...wonderful artisan bread flavor, not too chewy, with a moderately crunchy crust.  No joke, I could eat this stuff every day.  It comes in a long loaf, like a baguette, except each section is bent like a zig-zag shape.  You can pull the sections apart to make little sandwiches.  I believe this was $2.00/loaf.  Get there early so they are not sold out.  Oh so delicious freshly toasted with some good butter and a pinch of salt.  I'm drooling just writing this review!

The green onion slab is also quite tasty, but the onion flavor is very subtle.  This flat, denser bread reminds me of cibatta.  I slice it through the middle, then toast it until just a bit brown on both sides.  The green onion smells becomes more strong.  But still delicately flavored enough not to overpower your sandwich ingredients.

The BF tried a chocolate croissant (technically, it was called the Pain Au Chocolat).  It was a little dry, but the flavors were good.  We did get it later in the afternoon and we didn't reheat it.

Toasting the bread makes a huge difference in the taste and texture.  Have some patience and wait until you get home to eat your goodies!

CASH ONLY!
author: Kari C.

description:
The other night, I was watching "2 Days and 1 Night". It's this crazy reality-variety Korean show broadcasted on KBS2. They had a term they kept using on Sunday...wow-mazing. I kept thinking of this term while trying to describe the breads from Acme.

All of their breads are wow-mazing. However, I favor two whenever I can get my hands on them:

- Walnut Levain:  this bread eats better after a 30-second trip in your toaster.  Nutella, PBJ or salted-butter works best (at least for me)

- Whole Wheat Loaf: I like the appeal of slicing my own bread without the hassles of baking (D-Man don't bake) It's perfect for my sammies. But, I actually wait-in-anticipation for the bread to get stale so I can make french toasts with them.

You can purchase their breads in many retail outlets.
Their store in the FB is pretty cool and is like a temple for bread.
Pricey, but worth it.
author: Derek N.

description: I bought 2 mini rolls from Acme, one rosemary olive and one wheat. I was shocked to learn they were 60 cents each because everything in the one ferry building is overpriced. The bread was only ok. It wasn't particularly soft but better on the inside. They have a variety of breads to choose from and numerous sizes. From a mini roll to a large loaf. There's usually a line but it moves very fast. Parking was such a pain here. After circling around for 30 minutes, I just got dropped off.
author: Regina W.

description: ...of course the bread and rolls are excellent...I have not had great luck with their other offerings...an excellent baker of bread is not necessarily excellent with pastrys...
author: jim b.

description: Their sourdough, rolls, everything, is consistently good, and delicious. They pay attention to detail, even though they mass produce their product. Well done, ACME.
author: LeeAnn C.

description:
Meandering around the Ferry Building, owner of Boccalone, suggested I try Acme Bread Company to put together the sandwiches I was attempting to assemble.  I was very glad that he did suggest Acme.  They had a selection right on the counter for you to see, smell, and compare to other baguettes and loaves.

I settled on the sourdough baguette that went perfectly with the fromage blanc from the creamery next door and sliced pork from Boccalone.  It was wonderfully crispy on the outside giving it that nice sensation and sound of the crunch, while soft on the inside.  A perfect baguette.  I almost didn't even need to put anything on it, I just wanted the bread it was so delicious.

Enjoy!
author: Randy G.

description: Great fresh breads. My personal favorite is the epi bread that is crispy and crunchy upon proper execution.
author: Jay C.

description:
Of course I came here.  I had tro try out almost everything in the Ferry Building!  

No bread though, just an apple turnover.

An impeccable apple turnover it was.  Deliciously flaky and not sweet like those commercial pieces of atrocities parading around as a baked good.  This was one apple turnover above and beyond reproach!
author: Herman E.

description: One of the largest selections of different wheat breads that I've seen in a while - I got a sampler of the small rolls (8 kinds) and it's a steal for the price.  High end stuff - toast these up so you get a crispy outside with a soft inside.  The spread melts down into the air pockets and you will definitely be able distinguish the different ingredients they are using.  Highly recommend and I will try the big loafs next time.  You can't get this quality at a supermarket.
author: Ben K.

description:
"Three..?? Loaves...?" said the cashier guy.

Yes, absolutely, definitely. Three loaves of the most delicious cranberry walnut bread ever. I can't get enough of it and YES, I did eat two loaves all by myself. 

A couple months ago when the bf and I last visited SF, we bought a loaf and spent our time at SFO passing the loaf between each other and munching away. Chain-loafing.

Pretty sure people thought we were a little strange, but that was one of the best meals ever... No cheese, butter, or any kind of spread needed. The cranberry walnut bread is so delicious on its own.

Each loaf is about $4.95 which makes it crazy affordable to buy multiple loaves. :D
author: Steph S.

description: This is an awesome bakery!! We come back here every time we visit the area to grab some of their delicious and fresh pastries and bread.
author: Isabella D.

description:
Decided to go here after I visited cowgirl creamery.... I'm building my bruschetta recipe haha! 
They have their branch in mountain view.
Their bread are so good and so fresh!
Today I bought a couple of baguette and good white bread. Ahhhh! I'm thinking of a jam with it...
author: Cryszilla G.

description:
My dad loves this bread and it is hard to come by in Carmel.Being the oldest child (and the kiss arse) in seeing this stand at the ferry building I had to buy some... I bought a baguette of sourdough and a round.. the baguette never made it back.... the brother and his girlfriend got hungry on the long way home to Santa Cruz/Carmel and about an hour into our trip home I got handed an empty bread sleeve. 

CASH ONLY!
author: Vicky T.

description: All the trips to the Ferry Building involve a stop at Acme Bread Company and then at Cow Girl creamery which is located right next door conveniently. Plenty of options, good bread and friendly service. Only nit is that it is cash only.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Fresh, yes.
Delicious, yes
Variety, yes.

All in all, best bread I have had besides baking it myself  fresh from the oven {I have a 60% success rate}.

The only negative is that it is cash only, but for $2-$5 who can complain.
Best bread in town, give it a try.
author: Saar H.

description: If you go there on Thursday or Sunday, make sure you try their pumpernickel! It's the best one I ever tried! Also their rosemary rolls and herb slabs are so good!
author: Yifan W.

description:
4.5 stars.

I love bread. I love Acme. What's not to like? 

Though I would have liked my potato pesto sandwich to be warm. Still good regardless!
author: Michelle L.

description: I had Acme Bread at the Ferry Building and thought it was delish; but I think the best testament to how amazing their bread is came from a home made dinner I attended in which a nice loaf of french bread was served and I couldn't get enough of it. When I found out it was Acme it just cemented their high quality awesomeness.
author: Oulie T.

description:
Three letters. EPI. You get what you want in a baguette and you get more of the surface area of the crust (which is, btw, a beautiful crisp, wholesome crunch)
If you've been to bottega louie in la, you probably have had their complimentary epi bread. There is nothing I love more in this world than good bread (and sparkling water). And Acme has just made it harder to appreciate this complimentary bread
author: Cynthia T.

description:
I love this place; they make the best breads, all types
Fun to graze around the Ferry Building and buy something here
Efficient counter service
author: Rosquete B.

description: We have tried Herb Slab many times and it's phenomenal. The aroma of this bread is awesome. This slab can be used to make interesting sandwiches.
author: Piyush K.

description:
ACME - the time honored symbol of quality.  At ACME Bread, it's TWOOOOO!

If you eat and like bread and haven't had Acme I feel very sorry for you.  Their sourdough and rustic loaves, the olive loaf, the herb or onion slabs, the great rolls, baguettes of many persuasions... you just need to go line up, gawk and try.

Don't forget cash.   Acme's prices are a bargain for the quality.   I bet you will have a hard time getting home or to your next stop without ripping into some of your purchases.  What a good problem to have.
author: Bob K.

description:
I think their bread is reasonably priced and I love the idea of fresh bread but I've yet to had a piece of bread i enjoyed.

The pumpkin bread was eh - didn't taste any flavor of pumpkin and the outside was burnt / dry.
author: Margaret R.

description:
I'm usually the one who buys her bread and holds it up to her nose to smell for the rest of the day because freshly baked bread is just EUPHORIC. And Acme Bread Company knows bread.

For a bakery that has so much variety, it's amazing that I haven't had much of any disappointment. I've tried several from their Pain de Mie (White bread with honey and milk), Upstairs bread (loaf with several grains and flours), hot cross bun, brioche, cranberry walnut, levain, focaccia and the list goes on. 

Minimal, quality ingredients make up these delicious breads.  They have a bread for pretty much all occasions, moods and cravings. They all smell amazing too. I can vouche for that.
author: Amber M.

description: Very good bread, and a great location within the Ferry Building.  Acme does a fine job in their bread-making- one of the better baguette's in the Bay Area.  They are very well distributed, and deservingly so.  This is a great stop within the ferry building for a quick fix for your bread needs for the nights dinner, etc.  Cash only.
author: Andy S.

description:
I was at the Farmers' Market on Saturday and saw that they had a Pesto Potato Sandwich for $5.15.  I know....you're probably thinking bread and potatoes, carbs on top of carbs, what's so special about it?  Well, having had potato pizza before, I know how good it can be so I decided to order it.  To my disappointment, the sandwich was pre-made and not freshly toasted like I'd prefer it.  However, all of the flavors were there...the potatoes were thinly sliced and cooked to a soft, pillow-y texture and the pesto was delicious.  It would have been so much better if the bread was toasted...the hot bread with the cool potatoes and pesto would have been a perfect match.  For that reason, I only give them 3.5 stars.

It was pretty good overall and it is very likely that I'd order it again.  The two other sammies on their menu (cheese and salami) also sounded pretty yummy so maybe I'll try those next time as well.
author: Katelynn L.

description: we wanted good crusty bread as a nosh for our trip up north. it would've been better the day of but like great quality bread it didn't last the day but still tasted great.
author: NYSD G.

description:
Auspicious cicumstances in San Francisco afforded me opportunities to indulge in the same sandwich on consecutive days...

Acme Bread Company prepares three daily sandwiches for purchase until sold out or 2 pm, whichever comes first.

My sammy - sweet rustic bread enclosing fig jam (fruit spread changes at their discretion), Cowgirl Creamery Mt Tam cheese, arugula and cracked black pepper!  Sweet Mother Nature!  I cried when I penetrated the sandwich!  How can this be?  It's creamy, sweet, chewy and majestic!  Magical combination, a symphony of UHMAZING!

Namaste!
author: MiYun C.

description: I absolutely love this place.  The epi rolls are a fantastic mainstay, crusty and delicious, not too big either.  The herb slab is my other favorite.  Can't even bring myself to buy elsewhere.  Just beware they don't slice.
author: Darcy B.

description:
The World According to Noelle 
Allergic Girl's Guide to Life

On a crisp Saturday morning we made our way to the Ferry Building. After shopping at Sur La Table we were in search of something yummy for lunch. I asked my better half if we could take a look at the Acme Bread Company and he was more than willing to indulge my 'carb cravings.' We wanted to order two sandwiches- one salami and one cheese. I was really hoping to try the cheese sandwich because it had triple creme and fresh preserves. I was disappointed they ran out of the cheese sandwich. We ended up ordering a salami sandwich which was amazing- savory salami with crisp mini pickles on a sweet baguette. We also got a sourdough baguette to take home. There was a long line but it was well worth the wait :) The Acme Bread Company is amazing, they produce some of the best bread in the bay area. Everything is fresh, tasty and the customer service is friendly.

Noelle's Notes
Delicious Sandwiches!
author: Noelle J.

description:
I f.ing love bread! To the point where me saying "I f.ing love bread!" is an understatement. 

After a hellish month of finals, I took my exercise-starved body for a 5 mile jaunt around market street/ coit tower/ and the ferry building. 

I had heard that Acme bread was to die for. Needing carbs, I ordered a rosemary roll. 55 cents. Seriously?

Oh God. The crackle... the rasp of the bread and the hollow interior.. and the rosemary... perfection. I wish it had been piping hot and drizzled in olive oil and sea salt but wow. You can't ask for a better bread.
author: Emily D.

description:
BEST. CROISSANTS. EVER.

Their puff pastries are amazing! After trying the croissants at nearly every bakery I come across (including Bouchon, Tartine, and Jean Philippe) I've come to the conclusion that Acme makes the best ones (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/I19ntZQrZxMn9gYOOK1rhg?select=5Z3eBgawLuij1q-xUZN1VA). They're almost TOO flakey and buttery (who knew that was possible?) Acme also makes the yummiest (and prettiest) APPLE TURNOVERS I've ever had (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/I19ntZQrZxMn9gYOOK1rhg?select=2uuissaSkN9vhEIk-tPrBg, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/I19ntZQrZxMn9gYOOK1rhg?select=4S9ssGlfqkuoSv1k-o30ig). 

I'm a huge mess (face and clothes covered in flakes) after eating any of the aforementioned goodies. But they're so good I completely forget about how dishevelled I look. The flakiness is a blessing and a curse...

Other notable goodies are their flakey CINNAMON SWIRLS (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/I19ntZQrZxMn9gYOOK1rhg?select=TsQpdWCwSP6eCGXOC4vKsQ), gooey CINNAMON CURRANT LOAF (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/I19ntZQrZxMn9gYOOK1rhg?select=5Uc3MyIZ1L3v69utTgtW2Q), and SOURDOUGH CHEESE WHEEL (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/I19ntZQrZxMn9gYOOK1rhg?select=_9_aaKCL5mJiI99yP4Ho3w). So much cheesy goodness!

I also tried two of their SANDWICHES - green garlic with chevre and roasted red peppers (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/I19ntZQrZxMn9gYOOK1rhg?select=vuOE1Enfn8wO_eyBovnd3Q) and the brie with jam and arugula (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/I19ntZQrZxMn9gYOOK1rhg?select=py1Cp2HeNjv220g4_dpf5Q). I loved them both! So simple but oh so satisfying. They're even better if you take them home and toast them in the oven first. 

It's also not surprising why many restaurants serve bread from this bakery. You can always recognize them too. Their breads have the BEST crust! I love the crust so much that's usually the only part I eat. My friends used to give me weird looks for it but I think they've finally accepted me for it...
author: Steph L.

description: Awesome sour dough bread baked with a serious crispy crust. Made fresh daily, so good. I took one home and made garlic bread with it. It was amazing.
author: Tina C.

description: I LOVE ACME! The bread is delicious, cheap, and organic. I wish more bakeries would follow in the footsteps of acme and produce quality pastries at an affordable price!!
author: Happy C.

description: Acme Bread is great! I love the sourdough here. I wish I had tried more types of the bread here. This is definitely better than Boudin.
author: Nicholas S.

description:
GLUTEN.

This is the only bread you should ever eat.  Always baked fresh with amazing customer service.  My favorite, pain epi.  A close second, the cinnamon currant loaf.

Cash only, and sometimes a long line - but definitely worth every bite.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Are you shamefully a part of Carb-holics Anonymous, but still getting carbed up after promising yourself you wouldn't?  JUST EMBRACE YOURSELF and embrace Acme Bread Company!!

I am eager while waiting in line for a delicious herb slab if I'm ravenous, or an almond croissant / pain au chocolat if I'm in an appreciative Zen frame of mind.  I have been known to eat an entire Whole Wheat Loaf in one sitting because it was THAT good (not to mention with an upset stomach an hour afterward....).  Again, if I hadn't said it: it's THAT good!!  

Cast off the shackles of carb-restriction and treat yourself to the holy goodness of gourmet breads and pastries, done simply and done RIGHT!
author: Amy W.

description: A-OK Bread at ACME.  Cash only, baked throughout the day, and very tasty sourdough!  It's a bit pricey for your basic baguette (which is what I always get here), but it's a truly tasty sourdough in there so I put up with it.  Line can get long but usually moves quickly.  Boccalone salame + Cowgirl Creamery cheese + Acme sourdough baguette = tasty lunch picnic time
author: Shannon N.

description: I love stopping by Acme when i need a good bread fix. The sweet baguettes are perfectly crispy on the outside and nice and soft inside. I love that their breads aren't tough or hard to chew. The cranberry walnut bread is delicious too! Both went great with some Mt. Tam cheese from Cow Girl creamery right next door. And i love that it just tastes really fresh!
author: Evelyn S.

description:
I eat way too much bread. 

My arms are starting to look like Acme baguettes.  My right thigh- an Italian Batard, left thigh - a Rustic Batard, my fingers and toes look like twinkles (mini baguettes), and do we even need to address my stomach?  Yes my friends, Rounds and Rolls.

My favorite all time bread from Acme is their Pain au Levain.  Whenever I come across a restaurant that serves Acme's Pain au Levain I always request for more throughout the duration of my meal.  The crust is perfectly crisp, and the inside is pillowy but not too airy, chewy but not pizza dough-y. 

All of their items are bargain priced. I paid $3 for a loaf of Italian Batard and it looked bigger and felt heavier than my 2 month old nephew.  Friendly service every time I stop by.  Cash only.  High-fives welcome.  Jazz hands optional but not yet widely accepted.
author: Rho T.

description: Made my way over to Acme Bread since I was at the Ferry Building at lunch and oh so so good..you could smell the wonderful aromas and of course being my first time there I could not make up my mind! They even had already made sandwiches that look so yummy! I decided to try the cheese sourdough wheel! The man at the register was so sweet and said that was his favorite and he eats it with hot sauce! Wow I could not wait to stuff this baby down but I waited to warm up and it was heavenly,,even without hot sauce!! I have to try their sandwiches one day! Also the wheel was only $2.50 and good deal.. I"ll be back!
author: Dana D.

description:
Olive batard, what happened to you???  I brought you home and the next evening you had disappeared, never to be seen again.

The few slices we had together were amazing, heavenly, I really would've liked to continue this relationship further.  But I left you in the kitchen all alone by yourself too long, and other people wanted to get their hands on you too.

I understand though.  You're just so beautiful, and perfect in every way, why wouldn't you get snatched up the second I let my attention wander?  It's okay though, I know there are plenty of Olive Batards and breads in the bakery that are also interesting and comes in different shapes and sizes. You're my number one though.  *weeps*
author: Biqi C.

description:
I can get Acme breads at my local overpriced grocery store (Lunardi's) and I know all about the Acme bakery in Berkeley. There was something different and magical about coming here at the Ferry Building. The guy that serviced us was great-full of humor and pride for the bread he sells. The bread is delicious, yes, but it was seeing all of the wonderful incarnations that made us all salivate. 

My husband has decided we should go to the Ferry Building often just for Cowgirl and Acme. What a great duo!

*They do not slice their loaf bread*
author: Tam F.

description:
This place was amazing! Love it.  I just moved out of the city, and may even venture back in on a regular basis by BART just to get bread from here.  
My bf and I were walking around the Ferry Building on a sunny Saturday afternoon, and came across this little bakery store with a long line.  I wanted to buy some bread to go with the cheeses we had in our fridge.  After some debate............ I wanted a sourdough baguette, boyfriend wanted something called an Herb Slab....... I gave in and we gott he herb slab, which was a large square loaf of bread with rosemary and herbs baked in.  We got some herb and lemon oil to dip the bread in, and OMG, was the bread DELICIOUS!! The place is cash only, but sooo worth it!! The best bread I have had in a while!!
author: Celine S.

description: Omg, Acme bread is so good.  Today I bought Acme's sourdough loaf for the first time.  It was my first buy, though I've tried its bread at restaurants.  It was so crunchy outside, but once I cut the loaf into slices with my bread knife, the inside was so soft.  I couldn't help, but had four thick slices for brunch this morning.  The best part of all is that the big loaf only cost me $3.35.  Acme, I'll be back over and over!!!  From a satisfied customer.
author: Henna C.

description:
Have cheese in hand from Cowgirl Creamery which is conviently located right next door, hmm, I wonder if they meant to do that??

I grabbed a Twinkle (sourdough roll) and a Rustic Roll.
The Twinkle isn't as sour as Boudins but has a lot of flavor and that chewy crust with a soft billowing dough on the inside.  Goes perfect with my cheese!  

I went outside and sat on a bench looking out to Treasure Island and the Bay Bridge.  It was a great morning!
author: Erika G.

description:
Oh Acme, I love you so!

Your sweet batard goes phenomenally well with my favorite Cowgirl Creamery Mt. Tam and your herb slab slathered in sweet cream butter topped with a few slices of salame could be my very favorite thing in the world.

We often stop by the Ferry Building to pick up Acme sourdough to bring along with us to Tomales Bay, I love to dip the bread into broth we cook our mussels in. It is the perfect crisp, the perfect chew, the perfect bite. 

Gawd, I'm such a carbowhore.
author: Veronica C.

description: Whenever I'm in SF, I always buy this bread as a gift for those in LA who still eat carbs.  It's a crusty bread, not soft.  So you have to be into that texture...but it's really good.  This Ferry Building location is pretty but Acme in general is available all around the city.  I usually go to Whole Foods and buy some local cheese to cart down to the Southland.
author: Spunky M.

description: I absolutely love this place. This is where I get high quality, European style bread. I go here twice a week to get my beloved loaf of Pain au Levain. The staff is very friendly and I enjoy coming here every time. The bread is delicious! Haven't found a better bakery in the Bay Area.
author: D C.

description:
How do I love thee? Let me count the ways ...
I love thee sweet rustic bread for its light, chewy center and crisp crust.
I love thee salame sandwich for reminding me of my childhood in Germany.
I love thee with a passion even though I would rather have cucumber than cornichon in my salame sandwich.
I say to thee reading this to come here for your bread needs!
author: Joe G.

description:
Even if you've never been here, you've likely tasted the crisp crusts and yummy airy interiors of their bread before. There is a very, very long list of local well-known (and not well known) restaurants that don't employ their own baker, choosing instead to fill their free bread baskets from a choice selection of Acme breads.

Located in the middle of the Ferry Building, their bread is an absolute must for a special occasion or dinner party at home. Fresh baked baguettes, rolls, and loaves of all types, shapes and sizes. They even make fresh hot dog buns.

Now that I no longer live in SF, if I'm around during a weekend this is a must-stop for me along with some artisan cheese nearby in Cowgirl Creamery. 

Now if only they could slice the bread for me.

Tips: 
1) When sliced and put in ziploc bags, the challah freezes very well.
2) If you're thinking of making a long road trip just for bread, it doesn't beat Bouchon Bakery even though the selection is larger
3) They don't dump tons of preservatives in their mixes so if if you live at home alone, you might want to share that thick baguette with your neighbors before it goes stale. 
4) Stale bread makes for nice french toast and croutons
author: ChiYan T.

description:
good crunchy, chewey loaves of bread. my sister said we had to try it with some artisan cheese from the cowgirl creamery and cold cuts from boccalone. the wisdom of my big sis did not fail me once again.

protein dieters should stay away. this is carb heaven.
author: Cat B.

description:
How I was able to resist tearing my green onion slab - GOS - apart during the SIX hours it sat on my desk, its amazing aroma wafting over and teasing me, has to indicate some sort of willpower despite the fact that I will now probably go home and devour the whole damn thing.

I love Acme's GOS and have a very hard time not picking one up for $3.55 everytime I'm at the Ferry Building.  In fact, sometimes when I visit Acme too late in the day, and they're out of this heavenly bread, deep down - way, way deep down - I am kind of relieved because I know my body cannot handle eating nearly an entire slab of bread in one sitting.  Again. 

A creature of habit, I've only ever gotten the GOS (well, minus the one time, due to a brain fart, I accidentally ordered the herb slab instead), so I cannot attest to the Acme's other offerings, but the green onion slab is enough for me!
author: Mel T.

description: I'm new to SF and discovered this bakery on my tourist-style prowl through town. The bread is great -- they have a huge variety, and it's fresh each day. Highly recommend.
author: Rae B.

description: The bread here is awesome.  Everything is baked fresh daily.  The staff is nice too but you need to always check your order.  This place has one of the best breads in the City.
author: Samantha S.

description:
Whenever I go to the Ferry Building, for some magically reason I end up here to get bread and then some!  

I love the lightly sugary cinnamon rolls and the onion bread.  They are terrific!
author: Truong P.

description:
I'm waiting for Blue Bottle Coffee to open & standing outside the Ferry Building, enjoying my Acme Apple Turnover.......fresh & warm out of the oven, flakes getting all over my face.  I can't help but burst into poetry......

Ode to the Apple Turnover:

My dear Apple Turnover
        You are so very sweet
Your flaky crust & cinnamon 
        Paired with apples, a bit of heat
Hot out of the oven
        So buttery & freshly baked
Every morning, of your appley deliciousness
        I would absolutely love to partake
Acme Apple Turnover, cooked with love and affection
        Soft enough to melt but firm enough to crunch, you're true pastry perfection
I've enjoyed you many times & keep coming back to get
        Thank you dearly my dear Acme, this was the very best one yet!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Such great yummy bread!  We got:  the rustic roll, herb bread, croissant, and the cinnamon swirl.

This place is all about the bread.  I read some negative reviews about their premade sandwiches.  Ummm... did you take a look around yet?  the Ferry Building is a freaking market with artisanal specialties!  Next door is a cheese shop, and after that a specialty cured meats shop.  Make your own sammy!  

Anyways:  
rustic roll - crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.  very solid.  i'd probably like wrapping it in foil and throwing it in the oven to get it steaming hot and slathering a bunch of salty, full-fat French butter on it.  
herb bread - it was so aromatic, and full of rosemary and other herbs.  it was really soft and chewy.  it went great with the cheeses and meats we got at the specialty shops.
croissant - i was really disappointed with this.  it wasn't flaky, it wasn't buttery, it actually tasted like bread.  i don't think sweet pastries are their thing...
cinnamon swirl - not bad, but not the best.  it wasn't yeasty and chewy and elasticky like i'm used to.  lots of cinnamon flavor and sugary, but again sweet pastries are NOT the thing to get here.

i'm so sad i don't live in SF.  but probably a good thing because i'd be carbo-loading at this place all day everyday.
author: Crystal L.

description: I'm not a carb freak because I can no longer afford to be, but Acme bread is  so good and I can eat so much of it that I know I should google bread rehab facilities...but it is so good that I'll never quit.  I'll die with this addiction, and I'm okay with that.
author: Wayne S.

description: Great bread. Love the olive bread!!  Always fresh.  Many vegan options.
author: Kathleen F.

description:
Dear Acme Bread, 
Oh, how I've missed you. I moved to L.A. and I make it a point to have you every time I return to the Bay. I love your crunchy exterior and chewy insides. I love that you are so delicious that you don't need butter. Acme bread (any variety), some salted pig parts from Boccalone, cheese from Cowgirl Creamery, and a glass of wine make for a very happy camper.
With love,
c
author: CC R.

description:
The carbs here are worth eating. So delicious! I usually buy the rustic sweet baguette, go home and eat it with cheese (from Cowgirl's Creamery) and salami (preferably peppered). My favorite!

Their rye raisin roll is good as well as their cinnamon bun also.
author: Kelly T.

description: Cash only. Come early or your favorite bread is sold out. Lines are long. Lots of bread variety and some breads are better than I can make at home or cannot make. Bread is fresh daily.
author: Clifford W.

description: Meager sandwich with 1 piece of salami. I pretty much paid for a piece of bread. I can't comment on the other items but I would suggest giving a little more meat and adjusting your price point up a dollar or so. I'm currently looking for a second lunch as my piece of bread with a hint of salami didn't fill me up.
author: Julio S.

description:
This is carb heaven!!!

If you love bread, this is definitely the place to go.  They have bread for everything...breakfast, lunch and dinner( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/my2RrO0dSddhrn9XqzHgtQ/l ).  You can grab a ham and cheese turnover for breakfast, pick up some croutons for your salad, or grab some of their hamburger buns.  

My friend picked up an olive loaf and rosemary potato bread.  I didn't think I could finish a whole loaf by myself, so I just grabbed a sourdough cheese wheel.  I tasted a small piece of my cheese wheel, and it was sooooo good.  I can't wait to eat the rest of it!  

Now I know where to get lots of yummy bread!  I'll be back for more!
author: Patra I.

description:
Who said, "Man Can Not Live By Bread Alone"?

I got the Pan Epi bread....and that's all I got....and that's all I ate....I ate bread alone and it was good....it was yummy....it was tasty.....it was crunchy....it was chewy.....but not too chewy.....

Ok....I had my bread time alone....now back to my normal life....

When it comes to Acme Bread....man can live by bread alone....

I'll be back for more!!!
author: Alan L.

description:
The breads here are awesome. They really know how to bake some mean starchy objects, and they don't charge a boat load either.

The Berkeley location is certainly more unique, although this outpost really just fits right into Ferry Plaza. Providing bread to all of the artisan cafes and the like in this complex, Acme seems like the center to the spoke!

The rye raisin rabbit combines some of my most favorite items in assorted breads: raisins and rye. This little guy provides a hint of tartness and an abundance of raisin. He is slightly crusty and gives a little resistance on the inside.Good stuff for a midday snack!

The cheese round is oddly formed. It is boasts a whole mess of gluten, being almost TOO tense, but then you realize chewing it is half the fun, mainly because it is SO heavy on the cheddar (?) flavor. It is like sticking a piece of Cheddar gum in your mouth. Oh, back to the shape. It is rolled up, cinnamon roll style. I don't know why, but it sure makes it a heck of a lot easier to pull apart into large gumball shapes.

ABC doesn't need much advertising, but I just like to mark down where I have been. The system of Yelp is fun because you get to mark EVERY physical place you have been. I have had a boatload of Acme before, but after having it at Ferry, I was able to rightfully Yelp it once again. Nice.
author: Solomon W.

description:
I was on a shopping spree in the Ferry Building purchasing supplies for cooking dinner.

I was making pulled pork and wanted something beyond just a normal hamburger bun for the sandwiches.  

I shopped around picking up the other things I required and checking along the way to see if the line at Acme Bread Company had waned.  I finally completed the remainder of my shopping.  The line had slightly diminished.  

I have to admit though,  the line moved quickly.

When it reached my turn, I told the fine counter attendant that I was seeking a bread to use for pulled pork sandwiches.  She said that out of what was remaining her favorite for something like that was the green onion loaf.  I said that will do.  I paid.  We said our goodbyes and I was off.

I have to say the bread worked perfectly.  It was soft enough on the inside to soak up some of the sauciness of the pulled pork.  But it did not get soggy at all and held its shape very well.  Oh, and it was delicious.  The green onion added just a little special something..  My only regret is that I should have bought two loaves.  

Pulled Pork Sandwich on Green Onion Loaf

http://tinyurl.com/7wd5a8n

Overall, the attendant was very helpful and very friendly.  On the whole, even though it was very busy, the staff were nice to everyone and did not seem to be bothered by the hectic pace.
