I also saw that some of the attendants were patiently helping others determine which bread would best meet their need.  In the end, it is all about the product.  I really enjoyed the texture and subtle flavor of the green onion loaf.  I would not hesitate to try it again.  But, I also want to try some more of their breads.
author: Mark D.

description:
Okay, I bake bread I eat bread but I do not in no way consider myself a bread snob. Chocolate snob yes , bread snob no.

This review is based off of 2 visits.  Ciebatta bread, sourdough and  the third I forget.

 All three loaves were aparently stolen from a construction site that were going to be using them at a later time for building blocks.

The taste was medicore .

I was dissapointed. However I do love their packaging. Reminds me  of an older time , when bread tasted better then the packaging looked.

Sorry.
author: Lost B.

description:
THE BEST.

Enuf said.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
"if you gonna go for carbs - make it worth it"

Delicious gooey cinnamon rolls, well priced, in the ferry building - where its hard to find good value, (though most ferry building establishments provide excellent quality and high pretentiousness level). Anyway this place is solid.
author: Oleg H.

description:
I am all about bread. I love bread! The smell. The sound of the crust. The feel of the crumbs. The taste. Everything.

And I love Acme bread. Their sourdough has to be one of my favorites ever *second to Boudins*. 

I recently came here on a Friday afternoon, hungry for something. Thinking I'd order a croissant and leave, I decided to ponder the selection. I already knew that Acme bread was the shit....I've sampled it at Hog Island and at the Wine Merchant. So instead of buying a croissant, I decieded on a sourdough baguette. And a great choice! Coupled with a salami cone from Boccalone and their sparkling water, I had a nice picnic lunch to enjoy al fresco!

Mmmm....bread......


Of course, the only drawback to buying the baguette? I ended up assaulting many a people while wandering around the Ferry building the rest of the day. Notably at Sur la Table where, my baguette, decided it hated everyone around me and whacked everyone in sight. My bad.....
author: Jackie F.

description:
I know they sell Acme bread at lots of supermarkets and specialty food stores, but somehow the epi just doesn't taste as light and chewy anywhere else.  I'd argue that their epi is better than the one at Bouchon.  It's always fresh, crisped just right outside, so sweet inside.  This is the perfect accompaniment to anything from Boccalone or Cowgirl.

The line is always long, but it's definitely worth it.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
A total knockout. Amazing, fresh, excellent bread. A truly heroic staff than handles more people in line than almost any other place in the ferry building. Cheap, high quality, and excellent.

I usually go for the onion slab or herb slab, or the sour round. The cheese buns are awesome too. They make some excellent bread and it will go perfectly with some cowgirl creamery cheese from next door.

My favourite combo: sour round + mt. tam triple cream brie. You're welcome :) This place rocks, go here now!
author: Mike J.

description: I had heard many great things about the acme bread company while I was researching places to visit on a trip to the Bay Area and this place is the truth. How all breads should taste and at a very reasonable price. I would highly recommend the cheese sandwhich, with cowgirl creamery's triple créme and that delicious sweet fruit jam.
author: Miguel M.

description:
Anybody who has given Acme anything less than a 5 star review it was probably because they had to wait in that ridic line that they have when it gets busy.  

But that line is there for a reason!!

Acme has AMAZING fresh bread every single day.  And not only is it amazing and fresh, it's super cheap.  And not only is it super cheap it's right next door to Cowgirl.  (You guys aren't fooling anybody we know that was planned!!!)

Oh they do have a downside, cash only :(  But that's not going to take away their 5 stars :D
author: Jammir G.

description: This place is great to pick up a fresh loaf for the week.  The prices are also super reasonable, and it feels good to shop locally.  You'll be glad you did!
author: Mel G.

description:
Cash only? Really? Okay - I guess if a place being cash only is the biggest complaint I can muster it can't be that bad at all. 

Arriving in San Francisco quite delayed due to the heinous weather of 02/15/09-02/17/09 our arrival at the Ferry Market was unfortunately later than desired - many options were closed, many options sold out......but not at ACME. At 4:30pm ACME was still baking fresh and having just had a late lunch at Ferry Market Seafood I opted for a fresh-from-the-oven cinnamon-currant pull-apart loaf. In a word, splendid. In a long-run-on-word, eat-your-transfat-laden-heart-out-cinnabon. 

Having read myriad reviews before my trip to San Francisco I expected a lot from ACME, but others still stated that the best Cinnamon Bun was Tartine or Boulangerie.....having tried all three, I can absolutely say I preferred that of ACME - and it was cheaper than the others, in a larger portion. 

Top notch, but one star off for the lack of dessert-esque options (croissants, bread puddings, etc.) For bread and bread alone, I doubt there is any place finer.
author: Michael U.

description:
STAY AWAY FROM THE SANDWICHES! STICK WITH THE BREAD!

BREAD: 5 stars
SANDWICHES: 2 stars

I made the mistake of ordering the Salame Sandwich. Boy, was the bread excellent. But the sandwich is QUITE small. Included inside is a very, very thin slice of salame.

I may return, but will just order bread next time.

TIP: Buy bread here, and combine with the meat at one of the several meat specialty shops in the Ferry Building. YUM!
author: Michael W.

description:
The line up seems long and overwhelming but it goes by pretty fast. It was my first time here and I figured since there was a consistent line I couldn't go wrong and I was right. 

We bought bread to go with our cheese and meat and didn't realize how something as simple as bread could be so good. The baguette was crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside with a buttery taste and aroma. We bought some croissants as well and I can't wait to have them tomorrow for Easter breakfast.
author: Debbie P.

description:
Finally went to see the Post Impressionists at the De Young.   Marvelous,
Darling,Marvelous.  A feast for the eyes, yes, but it made me hungry for baguettes,  and croissants, as it was not quite noon.  Happily, my chauffeur dropped me off at the Ferry Building. Acme Bakery was nearest the main entrance.  
Ah,the smell of baking baguettes wafting through the market!!!!

But, alors,  the line had already formed.  Such good peasants one has in San Francisco!  How quietly they wait !!

As for me, I always have to find something to read. My educated eye alit upon the  sandwich menu  

BEET SANDWICH 5.50   Oh, mon Dieu.  Never had I ever imagined such a thing.  

"Gimme one of those beet sandwiches and a baguette, and make it snappy." said I.

On the way back to the East Bay via BART ( I often take BART to keep in touch with the working class), I imagines the train was rattling saying Beet Sandwich, Beet Sandwich.   Bien sur, I would not eat on the BART. , 

Wow!!! that was one GOOD sandwich!!!.  Thanks Acme!!!!!
author: Elle C.

description:
Sourdough batard, pain au levain, cranberry walnut, oh my! 

SO MANY CHOICES. I'm overwhelmed every time I come, but no matter what I randomly point to, I always walk away happy. Acme bread is unwaveringly amazing and not terribly pricy. You can get a fairly large hunk of bread for as little as $2.50. 

I often get the large sourdough batard for around $3 or $3.5. I swear I eat through that thing like candy. The only bread item from Acme that has ever underwhelmed me is the pumpkin roll. Everything else..DELICIOUS. I will never buy bread in a grocery store again.

Beware: Cash Only!
author: Talia G.

description:
2003 called, they want their Atkins Diet back!  I'm so glad that we're back to carbs else we'd never know the joy of Acme Bread Company.  They mainly do bread, but do have a limited selection of sandwiches and pastries.  Great for when you want your carbivore fix.

Cheese Wheel: What doesn't taste good when covered in cheese?  The parmesan crust on top adds a great tang to this doughy pastry.  The center is my favorite - huge chunk of cheese clump!!!

Salame Sandwich: Let this remind us that salame can be used sparingly successfully.  Doing so will help you stay looking like Brando pre-Godfather, not post!  The chewy baguette  paired with thin and fatty meat makes the experience hearty.  The cornichons add a good vinegary contrast and probably could have been more widely distributed.  Didn't noticed the European butter much, but suppose it helped carry the salame flavor more so.

Roasted Beet Sandwich: Beets are not that exciting to start with and I can't say I'm a convert.  However, the fresh horseradish is a great way to make do.  The chevre probably could have been substituted for a more potent cheese to help further add flavor.
author: Adam B.

description:
Class SF bread.  Crusty outside, soft inside.

Pair it with some Cowgirl Creamery cheese from the Ferry Building, and you've got yourself a sandwich.  

I like getting a roll as a snack.
author: Julia D.

description:
Acme's sweet baguette and pain epi are easily the best breads that I've ever had. They're perfectly crusty (but not hard) on the outside, and soft and moist on the inside. They've become the standard by which all other breads are measured and fall short. Fresh loaves from Tartine, Bouchon and La Farine are all far inferior. Bring on the challengers, but so far none has proven worthy.

Acme baguette + brie cheese + cherry tomatoes = Woohoo! As good as it gets!
author: Nathan C.

description: This is my idea of heaven, loaded with great breads.  The variety is mind-bogling.  However, they are so good.  I've not had one I don't like.  I purchased five different types of bread for Thanksgiving and the total was under $15.  The prices are amazing.  We enjoyed every single type.  Pairs well with Cowgirl Creamery cheeses in the next stall.
author: t d.

description:
Located within the Ferry Marketplace, there is nothing sexier to me than a place that just sells bread. That is rather unfair to my undoubtedly crazy carb fetish.

I ordered a sandwich from their extremely long list of 3 sandwiches, which makes picking quite easy. Before I decided on Acme, I was going to go to another place that was a dairy place. No worries, the sandwiches here use the cheese made from the dairy across the way. Double win!

While maybe not my most favorite bread in the world, it was tasty and just crunchy enough to stand.

Probably the one thing that didn't make this 5-stars was the fact that their food wasn't made fresh to order. My sandwich was just grabbed from a pile that were already made. How long had it been sitting there?
author: Richard F.

description:
Who doesn't love bread?  Especially ones that are freshly baked?  

Acme is Bread Heaven - so many delicious types and sizes and so little stomach space!

We got a sweet baquette - $1.85 at our most recent visit and it was just what we needed.  Perfect to munch on while walking and browsing in the Ferry Building.
author: Gloria H.

description: Acme breads are a step up from almost every other bakery in the Bay Area. It's just flour and water right? Yet somehow the end result transcends regular bread and sooo much better.
author: Michael S.

description:
#801

I'm a carb junkie.
This is where I go to get my fix.


AHHHHHHhhhh...

A couple bites of the perfectly crusty bread and that desperate look fades from my eyes and I fall into euphoria.
author: Vicky L.

description: BEST BREAD EVER!  I spent the Labor Day weekend in San Francisco and hiked back and forth to the Ferry building 4 times - for bread... the cheese roll, cinnamon pull apart and white loaf (not official names) were favorites.  I'm seriously going to plan another trip to San Francisco so I can try more types... Tourists can pick up butter right next door at the Cowboy Creamery cheese shop...
author: Andrene B.

description:
I've been to Acme Bread many a time just to get the Epi bread. It's nicely sectioned into small pieces that you can just pull off and eat. I love that. But I've never been motivated to write a review for Acme....until now. 

It wasn't until my last visit that I decided to try the sandwiches. They only have three options of sandwiches. I was craving salami so I ordered the salami one. They accidentally gave us the cheese one instead. When I went back to exchange it, they just told me to keep the cheese one too. I'm SO glad that this "mistake" occured. The salami sandwich was fine. Nothing super special about it. Just some salami on a baguette. 

But the cheese sandwich was exquisite! I am not kidding. You just don't expect it to taste so good!. For $5.15, you get Mt. Tam Triple Creme Cheese, Fruit Jam, Arugula, Black Pepper served on a rustic baguette. All those flavors together create a real nice party in your mouth. It was ridiculously good.
author: Esther J.

description:
Make sure you have strong denture dam or else your teeth will fall out!! I say at least 70% of the bread here has a hard shell to it, but soft soft soft insides. 

I've only tried a few pieces but I think their bread here is quite promising. Here are my ratings.
Tasty Level -- 1 through 10, 10 being DAMN that's tasty!!

SOURDOUGH CHEESE ROLL
Tasty Level -- 8

SOURDOUGH CHEESE WHEEL
Tasty Level - 6.5
There's something funky about this. All the cheese is in the center of the circular shaped bread and if you bite into it, it's wayyy too cheesey in a bad way. 

OLIVE ROLL 
Tasty Level - 8
I hate olives but for some reason olives + bread makes me salivate. I think it might be the salt coming from the olives. Either way, this was pretty tasty.

There were a lot of other rolls that I wanted to try, like the green onion slab but I said no to it because it's over a foot long and about 6 inches wide. Damn that's a lot of carbs for all you Atkin lovers.

I want to come back here to try their sandwiches and other types of bread. If my ass can't fit through my work doors, I'll know who to blame.

(Photo uploaded)
author: Heidi C.

description:
A trip to the ferry building would not be complete without  Acme Bread!! 

 "Of which there is no other" a quote from my 1932 Fannie Farmer cookbook ...applies here!!! 

We got the sour batard today...nothing like the traditional.
author: Katherine F.

description: Stopped in here before getting on the ferry to Vallejo.  It had to have been the best breakfast pastries we've ever had.  Also got some bread to snack on later in the day.  That was crazy good as well.  Keep on kicking ass Acme!
author: Nathan M.

description: It's like the soup kitchen here! Everyone lines up in an orderly file, clinging to their cash trying to look over the next person to see whats just come out of the oven, and let me tell you, whatever did is sure to be a car lovers delight! The bread is always really soft but with a crispy crust. One of my pet peeves is rock hard bread that you are left with should you decide you need a baguette a like 5PM. You don't ever have to worry about that because they keep their selection varied and they usually have what your looking for. The walnut loaf is great with a gooey cheese, so be sure to try that combo.
author: Hayley H.

description:
Acme Bakery chronicles Part 2 in the saga "Stephanie Takes Over the Ferry Building, One Bourgeois Boutique at a Time." Part 1 we had Lulu Petite. http://www.yelp.com/biz/lulu-petite-san-francisco#hrid:bAtwQWt0FegzwRYiTaQUpQ Now what did I say about acme?

Upon entering the Ferry Building, one is greeted by the sound of office workers on lunch break and the amazing smells of fresh meats, cheeses and bread.

Acme bakery produces some of my favorite bread I've ever had, in the bay area and otherwise. Their Pain au Levaine is amazing, and the twinkies (mini baguettes to much on during your trip) are great too. Everything is reasonably priced for the quality and freshness of ingredients, and there is a relatively large selection. But I've always purchased my acme bread in Berkeley or at Whole Foods. I've never been to the ferry building location.

The workers are patient and extremely helpful. There was no line when I went (amazing, I know) and I picked out the wheat walnut bread to bring home to my parents and the Potato Pesto Sandwich for myself (can you say carbalicious?) The bread is crunchy on the outside, chewy and soft on the inside just as Acme bread always is. The pesto has an amazing flavor, and the cheese from cowgirl creamery is, of course, excellent.

The sandwiches aren't huge, but they're only $5, have quality ingredients, and fill me up quite contentedly. I will, of course, come back to this spot in the Ferry Building, without a doubt.

Minus 1 star because they sell out very early of a variety of things. They were sold out of the cheese sandwich when I went at 12:30 this afternoon... Also, cash only. This is another drawback.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
UPDATE (Oct 2014): Yay!! Acme Bread has just joined us in the 21st century and started to accept CC ... 
-------------------------------
I love their New York Rye ... very decent bakery portfolio ...
Why one star only? Who the heck doesn't accept credit cards in this day-and-age? That is beyond stupid for company of this size ... Acme needs to wake up and realize it is 21st century ... Anybody with cellphone can accept CC payments these days ... Acme can't figure that out?
author: A B.

description:
Best baguette in SF. It's authentic and not too pricey. Croissant and Pain au chocolat aren't bad(or chocolate croissant, sorry..) although the frozen ones from Trader Joes are better..
Ok I'll stick to the baguette, best in the city!
author: Alice G.

description:
Acme Bread knows how to make bread! I go to ferry building practically daily to pick up a couple rolls, a baguette or a slab of bread. 

The bread is fresh and soft. Even if you cant eat the bread in one sitting, it is great reheated in the oven/toaster.
author: Tania D.

description:
Hungry CCG is hungry.

Shiny happy sun on Monday.

Hungry CCG likes sunshine and fresh air because CCG is trapped in tiny basement cave office 8 hours a day.  CCG decides to take a stroll down to Ferry Building for lunch with Sara P.  Friends are more important than massive amounts of work.

Anyway.

So, over the past few weeks I came to the conclusion that I'm slowly becoming lactose-intolerant.  It effing sucks, man.  But who cares when cheese is involved?

$5.15/sandwich, cash only (ultimate CCG meal).  There are only three types of sandwiches: Salami, Potato Pesto, and Cheese.  Ever since Yanny S. ordered the cheese sandwich, I've been craving one.

Crunchy fresh bread, mild and creamy cheese from Cowgirl Creamery, a bit of slightly sweet fruit jam, arugula and pepper.  Best sandwich I've had in a really long time, and I rarely like sandwiches (reasoning: I don't like hand-held foods).  This is offically my new favorite sandwich.

Service is awesome - the sandwiches are all room-temperature and pre-made, so you step up to the counter, order what you want, pay, and you're good to go.  Their bread is also reasonably-priced and IMO, much better than Boudin.  My favorite is their Pain Epi.  I literally finished a whole thing of it within 24 hours.

Coworker had the salami sandwich, and the salami was majorly delicious as well, even though I didn't have the whole package (I pulled off a bit of the salami to sample).  Next time I'll try that.  The potato pesto one also sounds delicious (talk about carb overload) but since I'm not a fan of pesto, I may skip that one for good.

Excuse me, CCG stomach is not happy with the cheese.
author: Tori S.

description:
Came back with 3 loaves of bread on my short trip to the Bay Area. Now I wish I had bought more and froze them to savor later. Seriously, this is THE best bread you'll ever find outside of Europe in California (can't speak for other states) and it's not even that expensive. 

This location has 3x the variety of breads on display. We used to purchase our's from the Mountain View Farmers Market -- there is a bakery in Mountain View and a third one in Berkeley -- and thus the selection was far limited.

When we finished the last bit of the 3 loaves, i sighed and longed for more. I thought the staff were very patient with me while I tried to decide what I wanted. We went early in the morning when they first open so maybe they were more pleasant -- haha -- I read what the other reviewers said about the disgruntled employees.
author: Anita L.

description:
My friend told me that all the bread in San Francisco is sour because their is heavy concentration of that type of bacteria in the air. Myth or not? Well, I was having breakfast at my hotel and the waffle mix was sour! Imagine, sour waffles! Maybe there is some truth to her theory. 

Anyways, the bread was not warm =(. I did get there around 4 pm. After looking at all their choices - they display all the different kinds of breads they have on the counter with a little tag to describe the bread and list the price. I bought a sourdough baguette for $1.85. The crust was a little harder than I would have liked, but the bread inside was soft, fresh, and sour! 

Nice bakery, but I would have preferred something warm.
author: Stacy T.

description:
Really good bread and pastries. 
Any bread and pastries here is good and I don't play favorites. I always try different ones when I come here. Prices are not too bad either. 

I never tried the sandwiches here though.
author: July N.

description:
Oh my, so simple and delicious.
Sure the lines are long, but it's worth it!
i'm still daydreaming about it.  *sigh*
author: Annette T.

description: I absolutely love their smaller rolls. I live alone, so most of their stuff is HUGE! I don't eat them, but they have a small assortment of sweeter bread, too.
author: Kevin F.

description: So far this is my favorite bakery in the city. The bread never disappoints, it's reasonably priced and always fresh. I got the sour and the sweet baguette, so fresh. Hint! Go to baccalone get some cold guts and cowgirl to get cheese. YAY!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
The sign of a great bakery is highly-rated restaurants across the city advertising that they use your bread.  Acme is well-known around the bay area and it's well-deserved.  Extremely affordable prices on all their rolls and breads.  Their pastries and sandwiches are a little bit pricier.

They don't slice their breads to maximize freshness (and only have paper bags for similar reasons).  One of their best items is the single-serving focaccia with seasonal toppings served from 11:30 AM until sold out.
author: Steve K.

description:
Sourdough Cheese Rolls!  They somehow manage to get the Gruyere cheese to bake evenly throughout the bread.  Amazing cheesy deliciousness!  I like to cut the roll up into little crouton-sized squares then toast it.  YUM!

Yukon Potato and Pesto Sandwich.  Yes, it was good, but for $5.15, it wasn't as big as other sandwiches in the area (outside the Ferry Building) for a similar price.  Maybe I should have ordered their Salami Sandwich instead since it was recently listed as one of the Top 40 Sandwiches by SanFrancisco magazine.  Oh well, maybe next time . . .
author: Christina L.

description:
Do not attempt to get the olive bun.  It's SUPER salty. :(  Why did the associate recommend that? haha

I love their Epi!  SO GOOOOOD
author: Moko R.

description:
it's pretty simple...best bread in the bay area.  hands down.  I worked in a bakery before and acme has it down to a science.  even their hot dog buns are delicious.  I'd eat those alone without the dog.  

Bread isn't overly dense and has a nice (not overly cooked or tough) crust.    I love the onion slab and it makes a great sandwich bread if you grill it up a bit.  There's lots of good bakeries in the area, but no one comes close to acme.  definitely check it out for a great treat in the ferry building.
author: Rob Y.

description:
They employ rude hipsters, but you really don't have to deal with them very much when you're buying bread.

The bread is perfect.
author: Lester B.

description:
I LOVE BREAD.  
 
It's been a life long love affair me and Bread.  (Well there was one indiscretion when I was briefly seduced by this Atkins guy.  I was young.  I was stupid.  I was bitchy from the lack of carbs.  Thankfully, Bread took me back.).  
 
Whenever I'm at a restaurant, the answer to my "Oh my god, where is this bread from?" is always the same:
 
ACME.
 
When I need an Acme fix I go to the Ferry Building.  Not only are their breads offered here but pastries as well.  The flaky Apple Turnover is a good way to get you through an afternoon slump.  
 
Also, around lunchtime they offer a couple sandwiches.  I've had the Cheese one ($5) which is a baguette with Mt. Tam triple creme cheese, fig jam, arugula, and black pepper.  Tasty but wish the sandwich was bigger and had more cheese.  Oooh cheese! 
 
I LOVE CHEESE.  It's been a life long love affair me and Cheese...
author: Amy C.

description:
SO FUCKING GOOD!

Minus one star for the disgruntled employees.
author: Suany W.

description:
Carbs, carbs, and more carbs! I can't stop eating Acme's bread when it's in front of me! I would never be able to go on the Atkins diet because of places like these! The smell of Acme's freshly baked bread puts a hunger in my belly! 

Boudin's used to be one of my favorite Bay Area bakeries when I was a kid for bread and breadsticks but Acme has now taken over its spot. The first time I tried their bread was at Waterbar and I've loved it ever since. 

Without a doubt, Acme is synonymous with artisan bread at its best.
author: Erich D.

description:
Prior to living in SF: "omg! This is expensive. What's the big deal?"

Now: *silence &  ::::nom, nom, nom:::::

I plan to try them all. Green onion slab sounds strange but is my current favorite, $3.60. It reminds me of a lighter and, of course, bread-ier version of Chinese green onion pancakes. All the baguettes are good; sweet, rustic, sourdough etc. I want to try the lunch sandwiches, $5.15. Sold until they run out. My co-worker got one today; not the heftiest portion, but decent sized and good quality.

The people are nice too. I bought cheese from Cowgirl Creamery once and I asked them what bread goes well with it. They knew, and I can't remember now. I asked them about storage of the bread--better to keep out and no plastic bag as it'll affect the crust, unless the crust is soft. So, any questions, just ask them =)

Cash only, which accounts for the cheap (for SF) prices.
author: Yan E.

description:
I have walked by Acme Bread many times but never stopped by to actually buy anything (the lines were so long every time I'm there!).  Recently I actually got a chance to buy something from the counter because the lines were not that bad. 

I bought the green onion slab and it was soooo good!  It also wasn't greasy or overly salty either.  The bread is definitely yummy and reasonably priced as well.  I paid $3.30 for a whole slab.  Will definitely come back to check out their other baked goods.
author: Wendy H.

description: by far some of the best bread that's landed on my tastebuds!  Nothing gets better then a fresh crusty olive bread.  The speckled black olives nestled in between the chewy dough gives it the perfect saltiness to eat on its own or with a spread of creamy cowgirl cheese and meats.  droool.  I seriously wished i lived in SF just so I could enjoy this and some vino everyday...xoxo.
author: Anita I.

description:
Almost every time I go to the Ferry Building, I purchase Serrano ham from the meat market.  I usually eat it by itself, but my cousin suggested to get some bread with it.  So we passed by the lovely storefront of ACME Bread Company.

The breads were displayed in a way that made me feel like I am Belle from Beauty and the Beast on her stroll in the little town...the quiet village... everyday, like the one before.  It is how I imagined the bakery storefront of the Baker with his Tray, like always, would look like. Though I wasn't looking for anything too specific and too cumbersome to eat (e.g. super hard crusted bread), I asked the sales rep some questions.  Real conversation that happened today at ACME BC:

Grace:  What would go well with some Serrano ham?

Sales Rep:  You cannot go wrong with any choice really, we have some nice sourdough breads over here---

Grace: (perusing around for something cheap... ahh the small rolls are cheap, less than a dollar each.... the baguettes would be too much, I thought.... the braided breads look delicious.... the olive bread looks enticing...continuing small talk about bread pairing)  Hmm... and what about the texture?  
("What about the texture?" I thought.  What the hell am I even thinking, asking about bread texture..)

Sales rep:  the texture is great.... I recommend this Long Italian.

Grace: (mumbles under breath while eyeing this largest and darkest Italian sourdough loaf they have).  Mmm, I wouldn't mind a Long Italian right now but it may be a bit much for my ham...

( | )
author: Grace M.

description:
This is the best french baguette outside of Paris I've ever had in the U.S. Unfortunately I moved to oregon and whenever friends visit i ask for a baguette or batard smashed into their luggage. I don't care what it looks like. 
When I was living in SF, sometimes the truck wouldn't come to the store until 11am; I didn't care. I'd go back until it got there.
author: S. P.

description: Wow, I did not expect to have an awesome apple turnover at this mostly bread shop. It was tall and flaky in sort of a slightly more bready way rather than the delicate crunchy 'fall apart' layers built by pure butter :)  I enjoy both types of turnovers, but this was a pleasant surprise.
author: John H.

description: Kind of a weird name for such great bread huh? I would have imagined them to have a French sounding name because this place reminds me of the great boulangeries in France. Its hard to find something not to like here.. my favorites include the pain epi, sweet baguettes, onion bread, walnut bread, and crap pretty much everything. Don't let the long lines deter you!! Just think about how you'd need to practically fly to France to get equivalent bread!! Oh and after you've got your bread, go next door to Cowgirl Creamery to pair it with some fantastic cheese.
author: Henry W.

description: LOVE their breads. I took my husband away from SF......he willingly came, but I still feel guilty for bring him out to the Central Valley. Anyways, we both crave sourdough bread. So, when I'm traveling for business.....I try to stop here to get a loaf or two. It's not only their sourdough that is good. I've tried a few and love them all.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Wow, updating one of my first Yelp reviews! Between then and now, I think I've tried nearly every item that Acme sells, and this place is still as darned good as ever. My favorite is the cranberry whole wheat walnut, which is a meal in itself and I can eat all day and night. 

I regret to say that I've had better almond croissants, but you come here for the BREAD. They also have some random seasonal breads sometimes, and it seems like they do sandwiches every day now! Cash only.
author: Ryan C.

description:
I always stop here before jumping on the ferry.. The items are always fresh out of the oven and always delicious...
They would get 5 stars if the accepted credit cards...
author: Robert O.

description: We need Acme Bread Co in Orange County!  Just the best!
author: Marie S.

description:
The bread here is pretty top notch, one of the best bread places I have been in the SF bay area.  The variety of bread that they have to serve your carb-guilty desires is bountiful.  This place and its neighbors makes the Ferry Building a place for me to swing by whenever I am in need of food and in the neighborhood.  Recently I gota  Rustica loaf here, some cheese at the cheese shop nearby, a great evening with some great wine tossed in.

My only suggestion would be if they had a board of what breads they have available because of the wide selection that Acme has, and on more than one occasion when I was pysched to get one kind chosen they were out.
author: Tom Y.

description:
Yummy fresh bread.  Great sourdough.  

Go to Cowgirl and grab cheese.  Go to Boccalone and get your favorite cured meat.  Go to Wine shop and grab wine.  Get bread from here.  That is the perfect afternoon picnic.
author: Carolyn W.

description:
If I had to choose only ONE THING to eat for the rest of my life, I would choose bread.  

Acme Bread Company should be a model bakery for all bakeries out there.  Their bread are ALWAYS baked consistently good.  

I had their bread at another place (Hog Island Oysters) and couldn't stop eating their bread...it has a spell on me!
author: Anne S.

description: If you love and adore bread, this is your place. Being a person that pretty much will eat a whole loaf of bread and call it dinner, this place is as good as it gets. I love their epi and cant get enough of it. Crispy outside and soft inside, it's ridiculous how good it is. Most everything I've tried here is wonderful so it comes as no surprise. Cant wait till my next visit. My stomach is rumbling already...
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Unbelievable challah and apple turnovers!

The apple turnovers are so buttery and so flaky; the filling is not too thin/thick or overly sweet.

If you dry out their challah, it makes amazing french toast.
author: Elaine Z.

description:
Jogging for 40 minutes (with my *mad face* on)
Eliptical machine for 20 minutes (on the highest incline.) 
Calories burned: 600 calories (says the machines.)

The reasons I do it:
Acme Bread's Olive Loaf (salty, savory) & Green Onion Slab (with a schmear of Marin Gourmet eggplant spread.) Chewy outside, soft inside. 

It's worth my sweat & tears.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Go here for bread.  Recommend getting:  epi roll. OMG, best bread eva.
author: Diane N.

description: The line was long, even though I was there during the early hours of the Farmer's Market, but it moved very quickly. Cash in hand, I limited myself to two selections and I can't decide which I enjoyed more. The rosemary roll that I paired with cheese from Cowgirl Creamery next door or the almond croissant. They were both winners.
author: Jen K.

description:
If I could just live in the Ferry Building and have a $200 per day stipend on food, I would be in heaven.  

Now, I'm not a bread man.  Much like I'm not a dessert man.  If it's not amazing, I'm not really into it.  

So, I was trying to copy the recipe for Hog Island's grilled cheese sandwich.  So, I ask the waiter where he gets the bread because it was just delicious.  And he goes, oh, right around the corner next to the cheese shop.  And you can get the cheese we use from the cheese shop.

So, off I go, Acme Bread Company.  Grab me a couple loaves of the onion loaf, pick up some cheese and head home.  Even picking up the bread at 5 PM, the bread was incredibly fresh, and light and delicious.  

My wife, who is the pastry person just went ape over it.  She kept on tearing off pieces, buttering it and eating while I was grating the cheese.  I was almost afraid we wouldn't have enough bread.  

She was wondering if they had other things like rolls and croissants.  So, I go back a week later, pick up a smattering of other stuff.  When she sees the bag as I walk in the front door, she nearly tackles me to get to it.  I must admit, everything was delish.  Especially the Almond croissant with powdered sugar on top.

Anyways, get your bread here.  It's great.  Cash only.
author: Samuel L.

description:
DEE-LICIOUS BREAD!

Best breads I've had...
1.  A bakery in Paris that has been around since the 1800s... how can that be beat?
2.  Bread made by my husband through the Tartine method.
3.  LaBrea Bakery (yes, you can get the bread at Costco)
4.  Acme Bread.

Acme bread is delicious.  Flavorful.  And just some damn good bread!  I highly recommend grabbing a baguette and then wandering over to the Cowgirl Creamery for some cheese to go with it.

You won't be disappointed!
author: Christine K.

description:
Excellent breads, fresh baked and ready to take home!  My favorite is the walnut levain, but I also like the olive bread and anything sourdough!

The line can look daunting at times, but it moves pretty fast!
author: Jenni S.

description: Our family ordered 3 loaves/baguettes, and they lasted less than 18 hours. One to eat as we walked around SF, one for french toast the next morning, and one for dinner later in the day (well that didn't happen, consumed at lunch!!) Do I need to say more? This bread is incredibly delicious. It is a craving that never ends. The negative is that it is cash only, but the prices are unbelievably inexpensive. We'll definitely have to get at least 4 loaves next time - one for each of us! :)
author: Pamela S.

description: This is a very good bakery.  I love their cinnamon swirl and their cheese sandwich is also very delicious.  I think next time I would like to try their Pain Epi.
author: Jim J.

description:
4.5

FOOD:
1.) Chocolate croissant = chocolate center, me likey 
2.) Almond croissant = mm, this was good ^__^ Kind of an almond gooey center... mm

Wow, the croissants had a lightly crisp flakey crust...I didn't think it would taste that great since it wasn't literally hot out the oven. but it was still good!  



SERVICE:
Order pickup at counter



ATMOSPHERE:
It's just one of the togo stores inside the Ferry Building ~_^ ... waited in line for a little on a Sunday morning.. So of course, the Ferry Building is super cute, and especially cute and bustly on a weekend.
author: Angela L.

description: wow went in early for work and went to buy chocolate croissants and cinnamon swirls for my coworkers beforehand and had the rudest cashier ever...not a smile or a hello just looked at me...I would understand him being annoyed if there had been a long line but me being the only person in line gave him no excuse...do I told him my order and went to pay in cash...got my change and left...still no smile not a word or muttering...even a hola would've been ok by this time but I had to get to work so I left and felt annoyed...wish I could get snacks and treats for my coworkers from somewhere else...guess time to scavenger hunt for somewhere more hospitable and clean(flies everywhere there too)!!
author: T. L.

description:
The place is packed on the weekends and there's usually some type of line so it's definitely popular. The setup is kind of odd, with no menu and all the pricing and descriptions on the bread display which you can't see till you're at the front of the line. It's a little awkward.

The cash only thing is a minus, just because it is the ferry building and not a small shop in an odd neighborhood but it's not that big a deal.

Their levains and baguettes are delicious and well done, crispy on the outside while soft and moist on the inside with a definite sourdoughness. However, my Acme bread is consistently extremely tough and hard to eat if I ever don't finish it the day of. Probably great for french toast, but a draw back in comparison to other bakeries.
author: Sam H.

description:
This place pretty much has all the different types of breads you could want. If you're not sure what you want, just tell them what you like in a bread (soft/hard, "herby", etc.), and they'll recommend the right one for you. Getting some bread from this place after getting cheese from Cowgirl Creamery next door makes for a great picnic.

I really enjoy the herb slab that they have, and it's very reasonable priced at $3.50.

I am deducting one star for their cash only policy. Get with the program and start accepting credit cards!
author: John C.

description: So I LOVE LOVE LOVE acme bread! it is so fresh and fairly cheap (for what your getting). Their breads are great and so are the pastries up front. I went there today and got their sandwiches (the cheese and salame sandwich). I was super excited because I know that the cowgirl creamery they team up with makes tasty and high quality cheeses. When I got to the register, the person there seemed friendly at first...until I asked her a question. I asked if they had the cheese sandwich and the salame sandwich and she replied like I was the stupidest person in the world because it was "so" obvious that they had both. I was like okay...weird attitude but I should ask what she likes because I was initially going to get one. She again was pretty condescending and said that if I'm a meat person, I should get salame and if I like cheese/jam, I should get cheese/jam. I really really disliked my experience with her, which is pretty sad because the sandwiches (I ended up getting both at the end of the day) were great (though I preferred the cheese). Great bread, but this person knocked off 2 stars for her awful and rude attitude. I will be going again, but I will not look forward to her.
author: Sophie D.

description: I always love this place.  They have the best bread and pastries ever.  Love their baquette, croissants, chocolate croissant, cinnamon rolls.
author: Fenny K.

description:
Giving this a poor rating only because I asked them to slice one of the small buns I purchased and the guy told me they do not provide that service.   Come on guys your a bread shop , pull a knife out and cut my bread so I can make a sandwich for my daughter.

That combined with a cash only policy tells me they don't really want my business which they will not get again.
author: Randall G.

description: yummy yummy yummy walking past makes my saliva jets fire. Sweet staff always helpful and friendly and kick ass bread.. Buy some bread, and a good tasty cheese and go eat it at the wine bar. yummyyyy
author: Madrone H.

description:
We tried the cinnamon swirl..."like oh my gosh becky...look at her buns" it was really good!=) It had the perfect amount of cinnamon (which I LOVE) and it was crispy but still soft as well.  We also tried the cheese roll...it's crazy how much flavor this little roll had. You can taste the cheese and garlic..BUT it wasn't this greasy cheesy mess.. again the roll was that perfect combo of soft and crispy. 

To top things off..the guy helping me was cute and really friendly=) woo hooooo...good food..good lookin guy..great location and atmosphere! I want to go back again..during the farmers market!
author: Christine A.

description: I don't believe in spending an arm and a leg for a loaf of bread but Acme's bread is reasonably priced and outstanding in taste. I LOVE their epi bread, which looks like a sheaf of wheat. Great crust and nice crumbs in the middle, it makes a killer lunch with just some good quality butter and a nice bowl of soup. I wish I live in San Francisco because I would buy their bread every week. Best bread in the country, bar none.
author: Kwoky L.

description:
Fresh baked carbs?  Only if it's from Acme.
I love their herb garlic slab.  Perfect for paninis. 

Ready made $5 sandwiches I tried was: Triple Cream (cheese from next door Cowgirl Creamery) with Fig jam, Arugula on sweet baguette... it was heaven on a roll.  Bread has the perfect crunchy crust.
author: Margaret W.

description:
Holy Crap! I never knew I could be so amazed by bread. 

Their bread is really something to venture over to this overly crowded tourist trap for. First time I came here, I got a loaf of the French Bread and decided last minute to get a loaf of the Pain Epi. Boy was I glad I did, because it had just come fresh out of the oven. 

While walking around the Ferry Building with a friend, trying to find a place to eat lunch, I was munching on the Pain Epi. When we sat down to start our lunch, I noticed I had eaten half of it in the span of less than 5 minutes. (I probably should have ran an extra 2 miles that day...)

That evening I shared my goodies with my boyfriend, his mother, and his little nephew from France to eat with cheese and pate. We scarfed it down like no other. 

Since then I have learned a little bit of self-discipline, as I have not gone back everyday to pick up a loaf of the Pain Epi. I work right across  from the Ferry Building and, trust me, it takes a lot of self-control to not go over there during my lunch. 

A word of advice to any Acme "newbs", such as I, make sure you get here early because these breads sell like hotcakes! I came after work one day to pick up a loaf of Pain Epi and they were all long gone. It was a very sad day for me...
author: Lisa T.

description:
We all know naked chicks exist in the Tenderloin, but the one I saw this morning was spectacular:  A tan twisted tangle of silicone boobs and naked well-oiled girlparts desperately stuck atop a bright green electrical box.   I'm not sure if she was protesting war or a lower PG&E bill, but this gal was definitely committed to what she believed in. 

And, since it makes me feel shallow to not be so passionate about a cause, I've found one of my own:  Holiday weight gain. 

Yep, it's said the average American gains TEN pounds from Thanksgiving to New Year's - and I'm allll about keeping up with the Kardashians so bring on the carbs.

Acme is open late during the week (8pm!), making it easy to drop by the Ferry Building to pick up a $2 baguette or rustic round to complement that heavy Italian comfort meal you've duped a special someone into cooking.  Come earlier if you want the Epi, 'cause it sells out quick.

Perk:  Fast enough service to ask your friend to double-park out front while you dash inside. 

They only accept cash, which makes me angry until I slather the freshly baked bread with butter whilst pretending not to picture my ass expanding.  Now, if I can just find a cave to hibernate in, i'll be golden.
author: Janney B.

description:
I don't know how this place can survive for charging so little for the awesome bread.  They might as well change its name from Acme Bread Company to Awesome Bread Company.  The Pain d'Epi is so yummy.  If I had time, I would check out more items but I was running out of time.  I can see why this place received so many great reviews from Yelpers.  When you are awesome, you are awesome.

Highly recommended for bread lovers.
author: Food S.

description:
When carb cravings hit and you happen to be in the Ferry Building - Acme Bread Company is the place to go! Let me put it out on the table. I'm a Boudin gal (sue me, I love the clam chowder sourdough bowls) and to be honest, I still have a preference for my sourdough to be from Boudin. I guess I grew up on it. It's in my blood, what can I say?

However, Acme is divine bread. It really is. I love the herb slab. The walnut bread is great too. Just a delightful assortment of fresh bread to enjoy - so I do.
author: Susan B.

description: I LOVE Acme Breads. The prices are so unbelievably low for such good bread. The little sammys they sell for $5.00 at the farmer's market  are simple yet delicious. My favorites are the beet one and the Cowboy Creamery brie with fruit preserves. YUM!!!
author: Betsy R.

description:
This place is Bread Nirvana.  I like it way better than the Berkeley location because they bake a lot more bread here and it comes out of the oven while I'm standing there.  I've never had hot bread at the Berkeley location -- though once I asked for "hot" and the cashier said "I'm hot but I'm not for sale" (too bad!).

Just about any time of the day, I can walk a couple blocks from the office, grab a hot epi and bring it back to share with folks around my desk - nothing perks up a day like a chunk of steaming hot French bread.  It makes the office smell good, makes your tummy feel good and... dang, Acme has the best bread around!

Try also the green onion slab - so good!  Anything with olives is also recommended.
author: Jenn C.

description:
My favorite (like the reviewer before me) is the pain epi... (which luckily for me they also serve at One Market - probably my staple SF go-to restaurant).   The pain epi also goes REALLY well with the balsamic vinaigrette dip you can buy just down the row @ Stonehouse (my favorite vendor for organic flavored olive oils).

But really, everything is great. I've purchased loaves and rounds to take to friends' dinner parties, and the olive rolls are always a surprising hit.

My best memory of Acme products is from the days when I used to work right across the street in the One Market plaza -- on heavy deal days (= early mornings, late nights) my assistant would surprise me by bringing me warm, fresh out of the oven, acme chocolate croissants....  luv in a fresh-baked mouthful.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I love Acme because when the breads are hot, they are awesome!  

I think they make the best French style
baguettes in Nor Cal.  If for some reason you are actually shopping for food in this area, pack a few baguettes for the family.
author: Mark M.

description:
Get the cheese sandwich.

The ultimate combination of the best the Ferry Building has to offer. Cowgirl Creamery's Mt Tam Cheese on a sweet baguette with arugula and sweet fruit jam. 

I am addicted. 

All for 5.15? It's the perfect quickie lunch (for a pint sized person like myself)

I also love their sweet baguette and my only complaint is that they sell out of it so quickly!! :(
author: Karen K.

description:
The tasty fresh bread baking aroma will lead you there.  
They make a limited number of cheese (goat cheese and garlic) or salami sandwiches too for about $5 for the lunch crowd.  
As a helpful hint, if you're a person who needs a substantial sandwich for lunch, (ie. a dude like me) this sandwich is good, but isn't so filling.  I'd suggest picking up a side salad few stores down too.  Sure, portion control, blah, blah, I know, but man, I need food, not just a little pretty sandwich to fill me up. 
Great bread.
author: Kev M.

description:
How can you not love this place?

The bread is fresh and AMAZING. I've never tried a type I didn't like. Favorites include the herb slab, cranberry and walnut, and the sourdough round (or loaf if you're going to use it for sandwiches).

My only complaint is that you can't see what's available until you get up to the counter and so then you feel in a rush to decide what you want so you aren't holding up the line (which can get a little long but moves quickly).

Oh and also, it's cash only. Inconvenient but not unusual for places in the Ferry Building. And it definitely won't stop me from frequenting this place!
author: Sydney L.

description:
Fantastic bread! My husband and I were here visiting for the weekend, when our friend brought us by and said we have to try the bread here.  To start with in the morning we bought a sourdough cheese roll, a rustic baguette, and a green garlic sandwich.  All were quite tasty as we munched our way through the day. If you want a sandwich, go early, as there is a limited supply and they sell out. Our friend said in the future, he would skip the salami for another type of sandwich, as there wasn't much salami on the sandwich. If you buy the salami sandwich, and enjoy a lot of meat on your sandwich, you'll probably want to get additional salami at the salami shop a few doors down.

As we went back through the ferry terminal to go home, we had to stop for more bread for breakfast on our drive home.  We got an onion slab, challah roll with poppy seeds, and another rustic roll.  The onion slab and rustic roll were great! Both were crusty on the outside, but soft and chewy inside.  The challah roll wasn't as great.  Our friend had another roll that was similar in texture to the challah roll, and it wasn't that great either.  Stick with the more rustic, crusty breads or sweet ones.
author: Deana S.

description: This bread totally wins over Tartine's bread.  I came here today with my brother and bought a huge loaf of sourdough bread, a slab of focaccia, a mini rosemary bread, and a mini rustic bread for about $6.50.  All of them are A++++++++!  They all taste exactly how a perfect piece of bread should taste like..crunchy on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside.   This place is a must if you're ever shopping at the Ferry Building!
author: Kristen T.

description: The bread is ridiculously good and darn affordable, the people at the counter are super nice, and the line moves quickly.  Next time I'm coming back with a bigger bag so I can fit more bread inside it!  This section of the Ferry Building is the most dangerous -- whoever decided to put Acme and Cowgirl Creamery next to each other was an evil genius.
author: Jen C.

description:
So every time I come here for bread it is usually to accompany the cheese that I get next door at Cowgirl Creamery. The smell of the fresh baking bread is always a comforting spot for me. I usually either get the soft or sour baguette when I go. Only one other time did I get a small rosemary roll that was also quite tasty. 

Staff is very friendly and can always answer any questions that you may have.

If you love bread you have to try this place out
author: Lisa W.

description: I had my first taste of Acme bread at my favorite restaurant in the city, COCO500, back in May 2010. There I had a salad of fresh arugula, buratta cheese, olive oil and grilled Acme Lavain bread. I was in heaven. This trip, when I came to the Ferry Building for some gourmet food hunting, Acme was the number one spot I wanted to hit. I took with me 2 small sourdough rounds and a round of the Lavain bread. I always though Boudin was the best bread in town, until I tried Acme. Nothing beats fresh sourdough in San Francisco and I can only dream that someday they will grow large enough to distribute to Southern California so I can get my hands on it on a regular basis!
author: Sheena M.

description:
ACME bread never goes stale because it has this secret ingredient that subconsciously leads you to keep eating their bread until it's finished. The ingredient? "Awesome".

For straight to your belly, won't last long, stomach stuffing goodness, get the green onion slab.

5 stars

Revisit? yes yes yes!!
author: Michael W.

description: I grew up eating Acme bread in Berkeley, and am sorry that their standards have fallen. The worst was when I found a dark hair baked into a batard. With all the competition that has grown since Acme was founded, there just isnt any reason to go back.
author: Ce Ce M.

description:
Imagine a bread so seasoned, so soft you wish you could sleep right between 2 sweet slices. Imagine a bread that makes all your tongue's dreams come true. Today I found my future partner, I am having an affair with Acme's Herb Slab. This is honestly one of the best breads I have ever tasted in my entire life. I bought it from a store in Redwood City and it still tasted freshly baked - out of the oven and cooled style. I bought my loaf to make a GIANT sub sandwich with and while it satisfied every spot as a sandwich I could gorge it all by itself and still be satisfied. It's that good.

The outside isn't hard. It's perfectly pick-up-able with a slight crunch and a soft center. It reminds me of a rosemary potato bread loaf. It's a complete package as it, no over crisping or reheating. It's good to go. 

My super sub sandwich of shame:
Acme herb slab, monster meats: turkey bacon, turkey ham, smoked turkey, roast beef, cotti salami... cheese: edam, dill harvarti, provolone... red onion, tomatoes, red leaf lettuce... mayo, olive oil, herb seasonings, garlic powder, garlic salt and black pepper... honey mustard on the roast beef... this beats any deli!!! This is downright insane!!! I can't imagine how yummy it would be if I bought it freshly made and still warm from the shop. I might not be able to contain myself. I may get so weak in the knees that I might just pass out.

This bread really is pass out worthy. Honest.

Herb slab is my new favorite. I can't wait to try the rest! I am now on a hunt to find out where they sell this bread on the Peninsula. I'm sure many gourmet stores will have it. My loaf was just under 5 bucks and worth every penny. I thought I was splurging with huge Dutch Crunch sub rolls at other stores but this one defeats them all.

I now bow to thou bread!
author: Food A.

description: Starvin, thot i would be eating a wise sons sandwich but they  r not here! Later in the day i git the newsletter sayin they r tied up with the new restaurant. Ok, i love u, acme bread feeds me the best damn cheese pinwheel in the world. Crusty, chewy, aromatic, takes me minutes to eat, love u. N i remember to engage brain and go to deli board! Thanks for the walk, i'm gonna need it. Happy allover.
author: Kelly K.

description:
I've been here several times and they always have great bread.  Whether it's a loaf, a lunchtime sandwich, or a breakfast pastry, they have a lot of variety for what you need.  The line goes pretty fast and they take cash only.  If you're not sure what to get, sneak around to the front since they have everything labeled then get in line for your order.

My favorite is the green onion slab.  Crisp crust yet fluffy on the inside and filled with slices of green onions.  Great for cold deli sandwiches, perfect for hot sandwiches such as a chicken teriyaki or bulgogi to soak up some of the sauce, as well as a side with some butter or garlic spread.  I can snack on their cheese roll or have their salami and cornichon sandwich for lunch.  A great bread bakery for home or a quick snack!
author: Jay N.

description: When Julia Child wrote "Mastering the Art of French Cooking," you could not buy a decent loaf of French bread in the United States. Hence her ellaborate recipe for making french bread at home in Vol. II.  I don't know how influnential she was in changing Americans taste for real French bread, but Bay Area residents, you are the luckiest people in the world to have Acme Bread Company at your doorstep. Not even in Paris are you likely to get French bread this good.
author: Gasper S.

description:
The Cheese Sandwich here is absolutely delicious.  I don't ever come to the Ferry Building without having a Cheese Sandwich from Acme.  The Sandwich consists of: rustic baguette, cowgirl creamery mt tam cheese, fruit jam (i think it's fig), arugula and black pepper.  It's such a unique blend of flavors and textures.  It'll be the best $5.15 you'll ever spend, says one of my converts =)  

**OK UPDATE: Today they used a cheese different from mt tam triple cream cheese and it was clearly not the same!  they used some st patty's cheese that wasn't as delicious and I'm very disappointed.  :( I hope it's temporary.

Line looks long but don't be intimidated - it moves fast.  The sandwiches are pre-prepared and they have a good system of simply grabbing the bread you want.  So you're in and you're out.
author: Alias A.

description:
I only buy 1 thing here.

Pain Epi.

That is as good as it gets.
author: Wakaknee J.

description:
I really like their green onion slab. It's absolutely delicious. If you bring your own bag you get a $.05 discount!

They also have good sandwiches made on their torpedo roll, if you need to grab something quick, I'd definitely recommend getting it from Acme Bread.
author: Analisa S.

description: Olive rolls and sourdough were good, but neither really stood out.
author: Sophia B.

description:
When I spent a summer in Berkeley back in 2007, I was spoiled by the Acme Bread on San Pablo.  I lived in a Berkeley Coop, and every day Acme would pass off its unsold loaves to a group of Coops.  Every Wednesday I'd return home from work to find some "end of the day" ciabatta, baguettes, and various other breads.  It was a delicious experience.

So what better way to bring a piece of San Fran back to LA than some Acme bread?  After scooping up some Mt Tam and Red Hawk at Cowgirl Creamery next door, I opted for a sourdough and a sweet baguette.  It was lunch time and I noticed that they sold sandwiches too - I got their Cheese sandwich, which was the sweet baguette with fig jam, Mt Tam cheese, arugula, and black pepper.  It was divine.  Salty, sweet, spicy - a perfect blend of textures and flavors and reasonably priced at $5.15.

As for the bread - yum!  I prefer the sweet baguette to the sourdough one - the only difference is that the latter has the sourdough starter added to the dough.  Crusty yet light inside.  The only better baguettes I've had were in France.
author: Tamar F.

description: How fitting to have a bread shop next to a cheese shop? If I spend the bulk of my lunch money on fancy cheese, luckily, I can still get good bread without further pinching the pockets...and what a great pair! The bread is made fresh daily and you can taste it (and smell it).
author: Helen L.

description: Ordered a small sourdough and rosemary rolls. Both were much more mild than expected, but the texture was delicious. Price was about average for the area, I think.
author: Amy H.

description: I am not much of a bread girl at all but when I see Pain au chocolat, I can seriously eat about 4. the herb slab goes awesome w the cowgirl cheese. oh God, I need to move to SF STAT. this is torture!
author: Monika K.

description:
Best widely available bread in the Bay area.

I love the baguettes. They are crunchy on the outside and chewy delicious on the inside. 

Grab yourself a baguette from Acme and go next door for a rind of Mt. Tam Cowgirl cheese and go at it. Yum!
author: Michael H.

description: The best bread of course but had a cheese roll (savory not sweet). Absolutely delicious and filling. For me a perfect breakfast. Of course great coffee down the aisle and cowgirl creamery is next door. Urban picnic. Later in the day get wine at ferry building place and go out to marina park for a picnic.
author: Becky M.

description: Get the cheese rolls, in fact take the number of cheese rolls you were planning to buy and triple it.  Trust me, they are that amazing.
author: Ann L.

description:
Great breads here, although I am now avoiding the sourdoughs. Not just Acme's but anybody's sourdough. 

Good pricing for the loaves, and the sandwiches here are yumsters.

Lines move fast. I remember some delis touting that they serve their sandwiches on Acme Bread. That's good enough for me.
author: Yoen K.

description: Hands-down, some of the best bread I've ever had. Of course, we've only tried the green onion slab and some of the olive bread... The green onion slab was delicious though. The texture was perfect - chewy with the right amount of 'crispy' to it. And the green onions/onions were a bonus. We picked up a slab on the way to Angel Island and snacked on it throughout the day. After coming back from Angel Island, we picked up the olive bread to bring home with us. I wish they had Acme Bread in SoCal! We also stopped by Cowgirl Creamery nextdoor and picked up half a round of St Pats cheese. Good stuff! I have a new found appreciation for the Ferry Building!
author: Jeremy L.

description:
I love acme bread. Anytime I go to a restaurant and eat all the bread on the table, I know exactly where they get their bread from.

I had no idea their location in the ferry building sold sandwiches til today and I just devoured the cheese sandwich for lunch: mt. tam triple créme cheese, fruit jam, arugula, and black pepper on a rustic baguette. Mmmmm...good.
author: Lisa C.

description:
"Cheese Sandwich: Rustic Baguette, Mt. Tam triple creme cheese, fruit jam, arugula, black pepper. $5.15."  That's verbatim from the wrapper of my sandwich.  Funny thing is, I was dead set on getting a hearty meat sammie that I saw people eating around the farmer's market.  But ah, then I saw "triple creme" and suddenly forgot everything else.  Who knew a non-meat sandwich could be so fabulous and also filling.  Must be the triple creme...how can one say no to that?!? Can't wait to return to try their other sammies.

Note: if you have a really sensitive roof of your mouth, the baguette is a bit hard on the top, so it might chaffe you.
author: Caroline I.

description: I like the onion slab and olive loaves.
author: Les L.

description:
I was born and raised in a country where there's an artisan bakery on every block.... Acme bread so much reminds me of European bakeries! The bread is delicious ( my favorite is the pain epi) and the croissants are so fresh!!! Pick some cheese next door and you have got a simple but delicious dinner!!! 
Acme is the best bakery in the bay area!
author: Anastasia M.

description: This review is specifically for their salami sandwich as I think their bread is great here and they have so many different varieties.  While the sandwich was good and the bread made it, I thought they could have added more Salami on there as I thought it was pretty slim.  The falvor was great but just asking to have more meat on there next time.
author: Blake B.

description:
This place is amazing.

Olive bread, sandwiches during lunch hour, and almond croissants.  Don't believe I've gone wrong by picking up a quick bite for lunch or dessert for later.  Prices are also pretty fair.  A large loaf of olive bread only sets you back about $5.
author: Jennifer Y.

description: I remember a time when you had to go to a fancy-pants restaurant like Zuni to even hope to sample some of this good stuff. Now I can get some by just standing with the unwashed masses for a while?!? Damn, this is a great country. Though I confess that I'm not going to open the bag until I'm back among the washed.
author: John I.

description: Brilliant,well spoken bread baker. Knowledgable, Courteous and a joy to visit.
author: John B.

description: The quality of this bread is amazing, especially for the price.  Yesterday, I bought a baguette and 4 dinner rolls for $4.50.  That's an amazing value.  This is my boulangerie of choice and I have a hard time buying bread from anyone else.  What really cracks me up is that for the price of all this bread, I could have only had a slice of toast at The Mill.
author: Otto D.

description:
acme,
you had me at epi.
author: Helen Y.

description: The line is always long unless you go close to closing time. It moves pretty quickly as long as people try to make their picks while they're waiting in line. The 10m wait is worth it though. They have a huge variety of breads, and they are crusty on the outside and just the right density and moistness on the inside. Love the currant roll, Demi baguette, and if you like olives, you'll enjoy the olive roll. Instead of having little tidbits of olives, they put olive halves inside, so there's no mistaken what you are eating. I recently asked for a cranberry walnut loaf, but they gave me a raisin one instead. I hate raisins, but I didn't check until I got home. Doh! Best thing to do is to pick up some crusty bread from Acme and then step next door and buy some cheeses from Cowgirl Creamery. Perfect lunch or afternoon snack.
author: Catherine N.

description: This bread worth the long line and cash only. Tried their sandwiches on Saturday and they're good, too!
author: Madeline R.

description:
I haven't tried anything except the ciabatta. I bought my first loaf at the Mountain View farmers market, and two more loaves at the Ferry Building. I know they have many other breads, and I'm sure they're great, but I'm so in love with the ciabatta that I don't really think about them. My husband might love it more than I do, hence the two loaves.

No, self, you WILL try the other breads! Okay, I will... eventually.
author: Julia G.

description: Got the salami sandwich this time. Still love the hearty, crusty bread. I think a bit of cheese would make this sandwich even better. Tried the apple turnover too. It reminded me more of a croissant, but was still good.
author: Wing Y.

description:
I love Acme bread!  It is delicious and made with organic, simple ingredients.  Their sourdough baguette is the best and is far better than any grocery store made bread.  The baguette is good eaten by itself, used for sandwiches or sliced up for dips & appetizers!   

The cranberry walnut bread is yummy as well, it's loaded with plump cranberries along with the crunch of walnuts!  Makes a nice breakfast bread, is good with brie & cream cheese and isn't sickeningly sweet.  Also love their herb and grain breads as well.  

There was a tempting array of pastries too!  

They have 4 locations around the bay and I've also bought their breads at Whole Foods and Sunnymount Produce in Sunnyvale.  Definately a fan!
author: Kris M.

description: The front counter at Acme is like bread porn. Every size, shape and type you would want - they have! I love perusing and smelling the freshness of all the bread. Great to pop by, stuff one in your bag and enjoy with dinner and some vino that night.
author: Daniela F.

description:
Oh Acme bakery. When I was younger I scoffed at your bread, I mean, there are only so many old school cartoons you can watch without feeling some sort of resentment to the name acme. But regardless, once I tasted their delicious breads I was hooked. While there are so many great breads out there in San Francisco, Acme has a consistency that is full of win, on top of which their bread doesn't go rock hard and become inedible after a day sitting on the kitchen counter (cough cough semifredi). I like to fantasize about working here one day, as a labor of love. But we'll see.

My favorites here are the pan epis, and their walnut and cranberry bread (sooo perfect with  mild creamy cheese). Not to mention all of their delicious rolls that are perfect to take home, freeze and use for lunch.
author: Allyson S.

description: Great range of bread to choose from and it was quite affordable. We got the baguette sourdough and it was very tasted and perfect for our indoor pinic at Ferry building.
author: John N.

description:
Wonderful bakery with many many bread options. 

On a sunny Saturday, after finding that this Acme location did not sell sandwiches until after 11am, I ordered a pumpkin roll to nibble on while I wandered the market. I was a little turned off by what appeared to be a hard exterior, but when I began to eat I discovered the outer crust had a developed chew- not a hardness. The roll was well baked and flavorful with the addition of various nuts and fruits- like raisin. 

FYI's~ 
* While you wait in line you can see your options on the counter 
* Acme sells many bread loaf varieties, rolls, baguettes, etc 
* Acme offers a few seasonal items in their choices 
* 3 three sandwiches were on the menu at the location I visited for lunch time 
* Use local merchants and ingredients
author: Natalie W.

description: Being married to a baker has made me pickier about bread, and this place is sooo good! I tried the little olive bun as a snack, which had the perfect "sour" taste, could have eaten more than one! Hubby bought a load of sourdough which we toasted for breakfast and was also very tasty with a nice crust and sour flavor.  Definitely stop by this place if you appreciate good bread!
author: Laura W.

description: To all Europeans craving for some delicious bread, go to Acme!!! It's the best and you have sooooooo much choice! Now I don't miss Europe anymore.
author: Claudia K.

description:
If you took bread away from me, well I just wouldn't be able to live.

I'd die.

If I had a last meal it would be full of  bread, cheese and sausages.  Oh and some sushi and pizza and cheeseburgers.  

For the bread portion of that meal please take me here.

Need I say more?

P.S. Sidenote- they only take cash - so hit the ATM on the way here.
author: Denise B.

description: What's the key to a perfect sandwich? Perfect bread! Acme has amazing bread, and because of that, I love coming to the Ferry Building specifically for an Acme sandwich. The best plan of attack? Come in groups of three. On my latest visit, I did exactly that so that each of us could order a different sandwich on the Acme baguettes. We each got to sample the salami, the cheese, and the green garlic sandwiches, and they are each Marvelous!! My favorite is the green garlic sandwich because it has the garlic for a little bite, goat cheese for some tartness, and red peppers for a little sweetness. The sandwiches are the perfect size and very portable. One of my new favorite things.
author: Ashley P.

description: Most awesome whole wheat and walnut... plus i love it that they distribute to smaller local corner grocers.
author: Doyle M.

description:
This morning, as usual, I went to the Ferry Building for my Saturday morning brunch and fruit shopping.  As I do every weekend, I ended my run at the Acme Bread Company to pick up my favorite Mt. Tam cheese, jam and arugula sandwich for a mid afternoon snack.

As I was standing in line waiting patiently, I noticed that some fresh baguettes were just coming out of the oven.  I could smell the deliciousness in the air and I could see the heat waves undulating over the freshly baked bread.  I was drooling all over myself.  When my turn came up in line, I ordered my cheese sandwich and then asked the order taker if they would sell any of the fresh baguettes out of the oven (w/ desperate drooly look).  He hesitated, then told me that the current batch may not be for sale in their store, I asked if he could check, and he said, yes, I think I can sell you one.  So he heads back, gets me a fresh, warm baguette.

As I walked away, I can feel the heat emanating through the bag and I can't resist taking my first bite.  As I peel the paper bag back, I can smell the doughy bready aroma, it smells so good.  I squeeze the baguette ever so slightly in the bag and enjoy the crispy crunchy sound of the bread.  Then I take my first bite...The outside of the baguette is delicately crisp and the inside is warm, doughy, pillowy and ever so slightly chewy.  The taste is totally on point and flavorful, sooo delicious.  THE best bread I've ever had in my whole life!  This is the first time I've ever had a baguette fresh out of the oven and it's sublime.  It doesn't get any better than this.

Note:  The poor order taker, he was a good guy, I think my weirdness threw him off so he gave me the wrong change.  I brought it up and he looked a little flustered.  He immediately remediated the situation and apologized.  I apologized back for causing so much trouble.  I was just grateful that he enabled me to have such a fabulous bread experience this morning.
author: Burrito M.

description:
The best bread and the best prices in the city.  Why go to whole foods and pay double when you can get the same excellent product straight from the source.  

Everything is excellent!  I am am a fan of the Green Onion Slab and the traditional baguettes.  The chocolate croissants are also great.  You really can't lose here.  

Make sure to have cash because they don't take plastic.
author: Moe J.

description:
I would give them 5 stars based on the sandwiches alone. I've tried all 3 (salami, cheese, and green garlic) and love 'em all.

The ingredients are top notch, the flavor combos (especially the cheese sandwich - Mt. Tam triple creme cheese with fig jam) are delicious, and the price is right at $5.15 for a small but not-too-small sandwich they could easily charge $9 for. Hey, a little portion control is not a bad thing. These are just the right size for lunch.

I realize most people who seek out Acme instead of the bread aisle at Safeway are the types who make their own sandwiches, but you really should try theirs.
author: S R.

description:
Some of the best bread I have ever tasted in my life! This is definitely going on my "must stop-by and get something" list whenever I come to the Ferry Building. One of every type of bread, slab, and roll they offer are arranged and labeled all around the cash registers so you can clearly see what you are getting.

The line seemed long when we got there but moved SO quickly that I almost didn't have enough time to decide what I wanted! There were so many options that I just opted for the whole wheat raisin rolls to eat as a mid-afternoon snack. O.M.G was what I thought when I had a bite of it. I am a fan of raisins and they were surprisingly plentiful in that little roll. The bread was crunchy on the outside, moist and full of flavor on the inside with nice hints of salty and sweet...*drool* Exactly how fresh baked bread should be!

I really want to try their cranberry walnut bread, baguettes, croissants, and olive rolls next time I am in the area. Oh, can't forget their sandwiches too...I'm looking forward to my next trip already!

Cash only but don't fret because their prices are very reasonable. Under $2.50 for 2 whole wheat raisin rolls...woo hoo!
author: Karen Y.

description:
PERFECTION ACHIEVED!!
Just GET OUT this bread is so good!
Pain.
Levain.
BUY IT.
MAKE A GRILLED CHEESE WITH IT.
THERE ARE NO WORDS.
author: Shira G.

description:
The fancy-schmancy cheese sandwich is not to be missed. Various kinds of smooth cheese, some sort of jam, arugula, cracked pepper, something else I can't remember, all ready to go on a baguette. Mmm...mmm...inspirational.

My only complaint is that I really wanted another 1/2 sandwich to enjoy but for a little more than $5, it's definitely a worth the slightly less than full feeling.
author: Angela N.

description: I have always held the opinion that Acme Bread Company was just alright and overrated. But whenever I eat their bread I devour it. If there's a slice available I eat it. I've come the realization that they're pretty good.
author: Michael H.

description:
Great lunchtime spot on weekdays (if you don't mind a bit of a line).

The Cheese Sandwich, which they always have is truly delicious. It varies seasonally, but combines a creamy Cowgirl Creamery cheese with some sort of delicious 'spicy/bitter' green (like arugula) and either a fresh or preserved fruit (figs, fig spread, it's all good)!

The other sando's a great too, and their Rustic Baguette is my go-to for bread. 

...their Walnut Levain loaf (so good on its own or toasted with a little tangy cheese) makes the BEST french toast!
author: T T.

description:
If carbs are crack, then Acme is my dealer of choice. In fact, you'll need to get better butter just to go along with it. 

My god, it's just so good.
author: Aaron L.

description:
I tried the South Beach Diet once, but quit after waking in the middle of the night, stomach rumbling like foot traffic escaping theaters screening "Drumline," to break into into my neighbor's apartment and eat an entire platter of cupcakes saved for someone name "Guillermo's" 11th birthday.

For me, avoiding carbs is like Project Runway gays avoiding attention whoring on national television; it's just absolutely impossible.

Acme bread company has become my saving grace in a land of restaurants and delicatessens that cater to the Pac Heights set...the Barney's of food courts, if you will. 

As suits line up at Out the Door spewing orders of faux Vietnamese favorites, like $10 Bánh mì, I tip toe over to Acme to whisper clandescent orders of $5 Cowgirl Creamery triple cream sandwiches slathered in fruity compote and crisp lettuce.

Although the sandwiches are small by American standards, they're delicious bits of jolliness much like the simple, crusty, cheesy baguette creations they sell at every train station in Europe.
