So even though after eating one of these bad boys I'm still starving enough to sneak next door for a side of macaroni salad, for a moment I can pretend I'm one of those French women who claims they never get fat while actually purging in the loo. 

I can't deny that I often purchase two meals a day from Acme. An olive or rustic roll to go with my cottage cheese for Breaky, and a sandwich or 10 loafs of herb slasb and a healthy side of shame, remorse and stretch marks to go with. Yummers!

If your recent hunger has driven you to ball gag Dr. Atkins and tie him to a guillotine, Acme and the carbettes will gladly shove doughy bits of badness down your throat and send you away with complimentary thigh rolls to boot!
author: Sammy S.

description:
you know what is evil? non-carb diets. EVIL. E-V-I-L. why? because carbs are just so damn GOOD. it's like eliminating GOODNESS from your life. and why on earth would one do that?

and on that note, you can get plenty of fresh baked GOODNESS at the acme bakery...a ton of variety, looks like it's fresh baked on the premises (from what I can tell anyway), and it's a great place to get the breads to go with the cheese you get next door and/or the meats&olives at boccalone! 

[it's cash only though so you're going to need some dough to get...well...more (cooked) dough.]

my personal favorite is the sourdough twinkle...it's petite, it's cheap, it's sourdough, and it's fun to say!
author: Grace O.

description:
if i were on death row, i think a slice of toasted acme bread with butter, and a NY strip with all the fixings would be my last meal.

hands down.

i almost didn't get the almond croissant, but i gave in. it was better than prolific oven AND la patisserie francaise. i think acme is neck and neck with patissereie philippe but i'll have to do a side by side comparison and get back to you on that.

real soon!
author: Christine P.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE everything here.
The epi baguette is to die for. I can eat the entire baguette in one sitting with a little cheese and olive oil.
SOOOO GOOD.
author: Kathleen E.

description: Love their fresh breads here and they got different kinds to choose from. Soft insides and nice brown crust on the outside. Was feeling for a herb slab today, so I bought 1 to take hope with me.
author: Frances V.

description:
Man oh man am I a sucker for carbs...especially freshly baked carbs!

The Acme Bread Company is in a great location in the Ferry Market- and the scent of fresh bread draws you to the register.

I got something called the "Twinkle" (mainly just a mini loaf of bread), I'll admit mainly for the name and it was just sooo good- my parents got other types of breakfast goodies (croissants, etc) everyone was satisfied and I will definitely be back.
author: Noelle M.

description:
My love for their olive loaf is ruthless.  My love demands I find new combinations of food that goes absolutely well with the olives in the bread and disregard all notions of common sense in terms of how much bread should be consumed in one sitting. 

There have been many times when I have gluttonously eaten a loaf within two days.  I am usually standing at the kitchen counter, tearing off slices with the serrated knife, just munching on one slice after another...sadly to realize only afterwards that I have consumed most of the loaf.

There are other times when I have come home with a loaf of olive bread and coppa (even better than prosciutto, believe it or not) and some insane half goat cheese/ creme fraiche cheese from the Ferry Building farmer's market and devoured half a loaf of bread with the coppa and the ridiculously rich cheese.  

Then, there was the time the duck pate man was at the Ferry Building.  I shudder to think about how much duck fat was consumed that day.

Most recently, I have realized that a light overall patting down of butter over some toasted olive bread followed by a thick smearing of tapenade is perfect in the morning with a fried egg. 

I soon plan on following this up with Exploteur brie cheese which I discovered is sold at Bristol Market.
author: Sooj O.

description:
Cinnamon  bread with raisins and topped with a sweet glaze, Cranberry Walnut boulet, cheese balls, citrus almond brioche...

Well, say goodbye to the Atkins diet.

If you can resist the smell of breads baking in their oven wafting through the crowds, you must have the will of a god.
author: Tangerine L.

description:
To hear the Food Lover's Guide tell it, Acme Bread is just that--the Alpha and Omega of bakeries, not just in the Bay Area but the whole world.  The Pain Epi, her "favorite bread in the universe", was an obvious place to start.  The verdict?  Brilliant!  Essentially a baguette of daisy-chained, majestically chewy little rolls that you can break off, split open, stuff with a Cowgirl soft cheese (if you can afford it) and a bit of high-class jam, and turn into one of the most sublime breakfasts ever.  I will definitely be back to try more of their surprisingly affordable (but cash-only) breads.

Plus they sell a baguette quiver!...perfect for bikers  When Americans finally learn to apply their ingenuity to the European lifestyle of simple pleasures, this is the kind of awesomeness we can expect.
author: Wes M.

description:
Acme Bread Company is a life-saver, why? Because my girlfriend loves bread, and there's really no easier way to say "hey honey, I know this is not going to be make you happy, but I you need give me some personal space while I play some games or hang out with the guys, but as an way to compensate for my rudeness, here's a loaf of Acme olive bread!"

So there you have it, Acme Bread Company is the life-saver for me when I need to get out of tough situations. Perhaps it might just work for you too!

Warning: life-saver effect only works on individuals who love bread, may cause angry man or woman to throw bread at your face if they are not fans of bread.
author: Ming S.

description:
Bread might just be my favorite food.  I've always thought that you could tell a lot about the quality of a restaurant and their food by the bread they serve prior to the meal.  My only problem is that if the bread is too good I rarely can finish my meal.  By too good I mean a crusty crust, chewy mantle, and soft but airy inner core.  

Acme is this happy place where I can fill up on as much bread that I want and not worry about a meal on its way.  All they sell is bread.  Bread bread bread!  Only caveat is if you're waiting for a table at The Slanted Door you might want to save room.

I've had them all.  Small breads to large ones. Fat breads to skinny breads.  Cheese to Cinnamon.  Walnut to Garlic.  They are all so good!  I usually go two different ways.  Before a workout I usually go with the Cranberry Walnut Rustic loaf.  It has the perfect amount of Cranberries, raisins, currants, and walnuts you could ask for.  Plus it is very hearty in a whole wheat flour.  Gives me sustained energy for hours.  I usually buy these by the loafs and store in my freezer (in freezer bags of course).  If I'm in the mood for lunch I buy the small crusty cheese loaf and buy salami and brie at the place next door to make an awesome sandwich.  There is also a fruit spread that pairs well with the brie between the bread.

Highly recommended!
author: Rhett S.

description:
the best bread in SF.

i don't know what makes it so tasty but their bread da best.  i thought boudin was the best, but was wrong.  sorry boudin.  i had tried almost every pastry they have. the favorites are, cinnamon swirl and pumpkin roll.    

i like to start a day with great acme pastry and blue bottle coffee!
author: Little D.

description:
Subway, you can take your "five dollar footlong" and shove it up Jared's @$$.

I dream of their cheese sandwiches.  Lusciously rich, smooth Cowgirl Triple Cream slathered onto a baguette.  Sweet, tart, fruity jam.  Peppery, crisp arugula.  (Insert Homer Simpson drooling noise here).  For a glorious $5.  

Oh yeah, and they have good bread too.

4 stars for no credit cards.  And for breaking my heart with their "Sold Out" sign on the one day a month when I had given myself permission to eat this decadent sandwich for lunch and you didn't save me one, thanks a lot, Acme.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
I wish Acme would just bake me a gigantic loaf or roll just so I could sleep on it, eat a little bit and then die on it. That would be sweet. This is my highlight of going to the Ferry Building. Doesn't matter which bread you pick, it's great. I love the Olive Roll and the worker recommended the Torpedo Roll. I wish I could come here everyday and just make a new sandwich with a different bread every day.

"How can bread be that good?" What a question when discussing Acme. There are really no words to explain the bread. It's just amazing, soft and flavorful. I've always loved bread and this place makes me go above and beyond the unthinkable.
author: Andy Y.

description:
As you watch people, bags in hand, walk away from businesses in the Ferry Building, you will see many of them ask the same question: "That was HOW much???  Really???"

Only at Acme Bread Co. are they walking away PLEASANTLY surprised.  I have no idea how the paragon of SF baking can still afford to let its bread go at such reasonable prices (often $2 a loaf), but I'm certainly not complaining.  I love the baguettes and the herb slab (it has some different name, but all you need to know is, it's an herby slab of bread).

BRING CASH.  Walk home happy.
author: Ben P.

description: AMAZINGLY DELICIOUS BREAD. I couldn't stop eating the epi.  If you're at the Ferry Building, it is totally worth it to stop by Acme Bread Co.  Just grab a roll/baguette and munch on it.  It doesn't need anything to go with it!
author: Jennie C.

description:
I love their bread! It's just so tasty and has the perfect texture.  I always look forward to their bread and warming it up slightly so that the butter will glide on smoothly and... **drool drool** I don't know if I can go on without running out to buy some more delectable bread!

They have a wide array of choices that will simply blow your taste-buds away.  I know that Hog Island and most of the places in the Ferry Building use their bread.  I am always asking for more fresh bread since I get it free with my meals! ^_- 

This may come as a shock to some but I am not big on Carbs.  I am a meat-eater but the bread here is just so good that I have to have it! The flavor is always so wonderful with every bite and it has just the right moistness inside that is only enhanced by the crisp crust on the outside.  **drool drool**
author: Kat L.

description: Get the slabs of bread, theyre fantastic-like a crisper foccacia. Awesome bread all around.
author: Alex L.

description: Love the epi baguettes and the challah!  I heart carbs!
author: Anna V.

description:
Blessed to live in a great bread REGION, you can go to a supermarket or specialty bread store and get great tasting bread. Hard to SCREW up and purchase a bad baguette of sourdough out here. 

If you want the GOOD stuff. Venture down to the Ferry Building a buy yourself some outstanding ACME bread. Many other places carry their bread, but this location has a great variety to choose from. Seasonal bread, small rolls, different assortment of loaves and the best of all, the sweet baguette. Make sure to go down here early on a weekday and get it hot off the presses. On weekends ACME has a truck outside for the Farmer's Market. Easier to SCORE some bread there, then going inside.

Many times people wait in line, get ready to order and FREEZE. Overcome by the number of choices, they stumble upon their order. Be ready to order! Not really a bad choice. And they even have a decent assortment of pastries for your morning kick or afternoon snack!
author: Ryan G.

description: Acme makes like...the best bread...and it's not expensive!
author: Luke M.

description:
Whoaaah.  Acme is mothership of bread factories by the Bay, and the Ferry Building is an outpost of the pod people.  Maybe not the very very best -- that's a religious question in this town -- but if not, darn close.

If you dine out in SF you've had Acme bread.  Many if not most of the best restaurants serve it when they don't make their own.  They bake it fresh here in the back, five or six kinds of dough shaped into a few dozen types of loaves.  While waiting in the often long line to get to the counter you catch glimpses of vast trays of loaves sliding in and out of massive ovens.

One trick is to buy a loaf and either eat it straight on the pier, or find some nice ingredients elsewhere in the Ferry Building to slather on.  They're too righteous here to cut bread for you, even cut a roll in half.  Here's a tip: sneak your bread into Sur le Table and use the knives there to slice your bread.  Uh, a little demonstration test.  Load up on free samples, buy a half bottle of wine, and voila!  Impromptu picnic.
author: Gil S.

description:
It is hard to make a choice in deciding on what bread to get when approaching this place.

Some of the things that I like about Acme:

1. Olive Bread=delicious
2. I love bread with cheese
3. Ciabatta
4. I love friendly service with a smile

With a decent selection of different breads,well I find Acme quite wonderful.
author: Dani D.

description:
All I can say is that I ate THE ENTIRE loaf of onion bread (16 inches long!) within 6 hours. 

ALL. BY. MYSELF.

*hiccup*

AND the olive bread is my favorite!
author: NirvAnna M.

description: I ate an entire Rustic Sweet Baguette (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/I19ntZQrZxMn9gYOOK1rhg?select=bv-G2kltBBR5PTsuEhYLMg) by myself while walking around the Ferry Building.  The bread is so good here.  I think the baguette was at least 3 feet long and I still wanted a second whole baguette.
author: Austin D.

description:
4.5 stars

I FLOVE Acme Bread Company!

I've been searching for an equivalent bread bakery in my new home of NYC and I think I've finally found a place that's come close.  But nothing will ever replace my beloved Acme Bread Company.  This is the best bread I've ever tasted (after the heavenly bread in Paris, of course).

I used to pass through the Ferry Building every single workday, and there wasn't a week when I wouldn't buy loaves of the Olive Loaf, Ciabatta bread and those asiago chese thing-ies they served in the morning.  The freshly baked loaves had the prefect crusts -- not to hard, not too chewy -- perfect for dipping into fruity olive oil.  I could always count on Acme to hook me up on the bread tip.

If you happen to be at the Ferry Building and you find yourself hungry, may I suggest buying a loaf here, cheese from Cowgirl, salami from Mastrelli's and then buying a bottle from the wine shop.  Then chow down at the tables at the wine shop while the hordes that pass by look on and drool in jealousy.

Acme also had a seasonal cranberry (or was it pumpkin???) bread that rocked my world.

Cash only, from what I remember -- I recall having to dig into my bag for all that change for my almost daily cheese thingy fix.  They open super early during the work week, 6:30am.

Acme, if you ever come to NY, I will seriously be your bitch.
author: Caroline B.

description:
I love Acme Bread, the baked goods they supply are just incredible.
The most perfect artisan breads you can buy.
I want to reccomend the Rye Raisin Rabbit Rolls, chewy wonderfull dreamy. The Sunflower Seed Bread is also incredible. The Wheat Bread is to die for , so perfect yet not too dry.
I bake bread myself, so I know it's not an easy task to produce consistantly perfect loaves, yet they do, time and again.
author: Dean J.

description: I love the bread here and it always smells so good I used to come to BOUDIN but now I come here the Sour Loaf is great for French Toast, the Pain Epi is great for a snack, the Sour Batard is great for regular toast I would come back here at least once a week maybe 2.
author: Aurelio L.

description:
Great bread, crappy attitude.

I love their stuff. I buy at least one loaf a week here, some weeks two. I'm addicted to their Pain de Mie, and their baguettes are the best. One day I came bought a savory cheese pastry and a chocolate croissant, added an overpriced apple from the produce shop down the row, and had one of the best lunches ever.

But damn, the people who work there are a bunch of cheerless new-age freaks. You'd think that being surrounded by such glorious food would make you downright happy to be alive, but you can't get them to smile, no matter how pleasant you are. Recently I asked them if they could slice a loaf (of sandwich bread, mind you, not some artistic peasant boule) and the dude actually sneered at me: "We don't *believe* in slicing. It destroys the longevity of the bread."

You don't *believe* in it, like you don't believe in Santa Claus or the Boogey Man? Man... chill. It's a LOAF OF FREAKING BREAD. I'm using it to make about 2 dozen mini-BLTs for a party tonight, so it doesn't need to be fresh into the next decade, Rain.

I mean, would it kill you to say "Oh, sorry, we don't have a slicer. Our breads last a lot longer if you cut them one slice at a time." There, point made, customer educated and not insulted.

So yeah... cranky employees, but damn fine bread.
author: anita c.

description:
Acme has been one of my favorite bakeries ever since I first encountered their Sourdough Batards at Park's Farmers Market in the Inner Sunset back in the early '90s.

Being able to walk into the Ferry Building and get their amazing breads right from the oven is truly wonderful (and a serious carbohazard ;).

It's bakeries like this one that remind us why humans have had a love affair with bread for over 10,000 years (http://www.bakersfederation.org.uk/antiquity.aspx).
author: Nivek M.

description:
Writing this makes me droooool.  Only downside to this place is its cash only.. but damn I'll be lookin at the bottom of my purse to look for any cash I may have.. because this bread is to die for!

Seriously, who carries cash.  Lol... but my itty bitty coin purse has at least 2 bucks in it for some wonderful breaddddd.
author: Alice E.

description:
I could eat a sour batard everyday if I could. Goes perfectly with a big bowl of steaming hot soup (cioppino!) or just toasted and eaten plain. I'm actually considering shipping a few loaves to my brother's girlfriend who couldn't get enough sourdough while she was here. Oh, the herb slab, walnut levain (lovely with a bit of goat cheese and a drizzle of honey) and olive bread are consistently tasty but still second to my sourdough!

Update: For a cheap but oh so satisfying lunch, pick up a cheese or salami sandwich for $5! Sold from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. I've been having one of each weekly for the past month or so...yeah, nowadays I pretty much only wear stretchy pants. :(

Update 2: Mr. Sour Batard has been replaced by the sweet rustic baguette and pain epis. I lounge around in my underpants and gnaw on baguettes every Friday night. Better than booze!
author: Nathalie L.

description: Yummmmm! Almond croissant with toasted almonds the way every almond croissant you eat should taste. Menus one star for being cash only. I can buy you for a dollar more at the airport and use you when I'm in sf on business but getting your bread on a regular basis at the ferry building? Nope.
author: Crystal K.

description:
Abso-frickin-lutely good. 

They sell the best and freshest bread in all of San Francisco. I love their rustic baguettes, cranberry walnut bread and chocolate croissants. 

There's no faking it at Acme, it's a total breadgasm!

And while you're at the Ferry Building, hop on over to Cowgirl Creamery next door. They have the most fantabulous cheese available. 

Bread from acme, cheese from cowgirl, a nice bottle of red wine, blanket and an old movie shown at the park = perfect.
author: Erika I.

description:
I'd never give up on bread, thanks to Acme. 

I'll never deprive myself of this carb filled delight. I am lucky enough to have a loaf at my house regularly and down the street from work at the deli. 

I only get Acme bread! Rosemary is my favorite, but I like them all!
author: Dee C.

description: WOW! is all I can say. Don't let the cash only sign scare you away.  4$ for a loaf and its fresh and wonderful !  Blow off the other bread shops in the area!
author: Shawn S.

description:
I love bread.  I love it a lot and, like some relationships, sometimes too much in a not-so-healthy-stalker-kind-of-way.

I've had two bread epiphanies in my life:

1.  When  my older brother told me that I could squeeze an entire loaf of Wonderbread into a ball the size of a regulation baseball.  He described it in such a beautiful way that I immediately went to the kitchen and squeezed two loaves from the pantry into balls EXACTLY THE SIZE OF REGULATION BASEBALLS!!  My little seven year old mind was blown.  Meanwhile, my brother had removed himself far from the scene of the crime and I was left, holding the bread -um- balls.  My mother was not pleased and in no way impressed with the balls o' bread..

The epiphany (and moral to the story) was that my brother was evil.  Unfortunately, I fell for this kind of thing over and over and over again.

2.  When I was in college, I lived in a dorm my freshman year.  Every Friday was 'steak' night where steak, baked potatoes, salad and sourdough rolls were served.  My friends and I would load up on dozens of these sourdough rolls and they served as Saturday morning breakfast for the regular event we named "Drugs & Bugs".  Cartoons were involved as well as other non-sanctioned substances.

Ahem.  

Huh?  Oh yeah,  what was the bread epiphany?

The sourdough rolls were FANTASTIC!!  Probably my first conscious (albeit cosmically and chemically altered) recognition of really good bread.

(Imagine many calendar pages flying and swirling about, the hands of a clock twirling about madly to denote the passage of time).

Acme Bread.

The only thing better than the olive loaf are the olive rolls.  The olives-to-bread ratio is higher and quite perfect.  

Have I mentioned the walnut bread? No?  Well, it's my 'little bit on the side' when I'm not mooning over the olive rolls.  This makes great toast, too.  

Rosemary rolls.... On my Saturday trips to the Ferry Plaza Farmer's Market, breakfast consists of a Blue Bottle quad latte and an Acme rosemary roll.
author: Nancy W.

description:
Forget about the low-carb nonsense... it should have always read "low-chem".  Acme takes only basic whole food ingredients and hand-crafts them into the finest breads the old-fashioned way.  They offer excellent prices, exceptional variety and quick service.  Great place to stock up for dinner parties or just the occasional side snack.  In particular the Currant mini-loaf is highly recommended as a fine dessert option... guaranteed to impress your friends.

For those of you in the Financial District, this is the lunch hour excuse you've been looking for to trek on over to the Ferry Building.  

Once I went Acme, I found it just too hard to consider any mainline brands from grocery marts to be real bread.
author: Jim W.

description:
Acme walnut-cranberry bread + butter = bliss.  Sometimes it takes very little to make me happy.

Update 3/28/08: I almost hate to add to this review because it's so perfectly succinct, but I have to give a shout-out to their sandwiches, because they are GOOD.  Seems they decided to make friends with their Ferry Building neighbor, Cowgirl Creamery, and they've paired Cowgirl's triple-cream cheese with their bread, added some fig jam and arugula, and created a damn fine sandwich for an even five bucks.  And they're pre-made, so no wait.  Although I think next time I'll ask if they can add more jam to mine.  I'll bet they will.
author: DD B.

description:
I love Acme Bread, especially their herb slab.  Redolent of rosemary, the herb slab is the perfect bread for munching on as you wander around the Ferry Building (its soft enough that you can just tear hunks of it off rather than use a bread knife) or to take home for sandwiches.  Its even better when its warmed up in your toaster oven, so that the crust crisps up again and the rosemary scent is stronger.  Perfect just plain or with a little butter.  Yum!

I definitely need to come earlier next time so that I can get a crack at their famous croissants- I'm always here in the afternoon, so they're all gone.
author: Angela H.

description:
It's the greatest thing since sliced bread! Unfortunately, they don't slice bread.

Everything is good here, and the prices are decent. I'm so impressed I've decided to open a bakery of my own, devoted entirely to easily-pronounceable American breads. All my items will be certified immortal, as they are infused with a cocktail of God-defying preservatives. Customers will complement my bread by saying, "Your sourdough has an excellent tangy zest," to which I shall reply, "Sir, that's not sourdough..."
author: Keane L.

description:
There is something about the minimalist Parisian sandwich -- saucisson sec, butter, maybe cornichons for contrast, on a chewy crusty baguette -- that is soul satisfying. There are no bells and whistles here. No avocado-mango salsa. No curried shrimp coleslaw. No piled-high mounds of roast beef. There are no powerhouse flavors to bowl you over or extraneous fillings (iceberg lettuce, I'm looking at you) to stretch out bland flavors to fill a stomach. A perfectly-executed Parisian sandiwch (Salame, here) is the elegant pinnacle of sandwichery.

And here, we have that near-perfect sandwich. Salami is as good as I've tasted, cut slightly thicker than I'm used to, but with an amazing melting mouth-feel that is never unctuous. Enough cornichon to brighten the flavor without overpowering the meat. Butter bringing the entire enterprise together, and, of course, supreme bread.

If I have any criticism, it's that the sandwich was maybe a little small for the price, but perhaps that is more to blame on my appetite having been artificially inflated by larger-than-my-head deli subs than any fault of the sandwich here itself. My co-luncher got the green garlic sandwich, which was great in its own way, but I'll stick with the simplicity and grace of this three-note harmony every time. Exit the Ferry Building, play the flâneur by the water, and pretend you can hear an accordianist in the distance, and you will have no regrets.
author: Ben K.

description:
BREAD...GOOD!

Being from the Mile High City, I can appreciate the value of a delicious loaf of bread baked at sea level. We just can't get it quite the same at high altitude. 

Thanks, Yelpers, for recommending Acme! I bought two big sourdough loaves for the road and a cheese roll for lunch. My boyfriend and I ended up tearing up the loaves like a pack of rabid starving wolves when I brought them back to Denver. Great bread!

I take away a star because even though I was super-hungry, my cheese roll was not very good. Kind of greasy and tough. Also, the gal who rang up my order was either dopey or on something, although she was pleasant enough and ended up getting my order right after all.

I love bread! Go Acme! Go Acme!
author: Nicole G.

description:
I tried their ham & cheese creation and while normally, I would ask that the place toast the thing (the texture adds a special element), this place does not do that.  SO, instead of waiting to get home to do it myself, I just ate it as is.  The ham was cut into chunks and the cheese was so-so.  The pastry was good, not great, but I think it's because it wasn't warmed through like I like it.

Next time!  Patience to get to a toaster oven!
author: Lynnie P.

description: Love love love Acme bread! Actually I am addicted. So happy they sell it at Sunnyvale's Farmer's market so I do not have to get to SF to buy some weekly :) Love their epi and olive batard and sweet baguette :) Yum yum!
author: May B.

description:
My name is Alex and I am addicted to ACME Bread.
(especially the epi and cheese rolls)
author: Alex L.

description:
I'm completely addicted to the Torpedo roll, which I top with softened Boursin cheese.  It's my favorite treat.  This roll that costs less than a buck (70 cents to be exact) has bewitching powers on me.  Prior to my discovery of Acme, I probably ventured to the Ferry Building once or twice a year, and in the last few months I think I've been there 10 times.  All for a 70 cent piece of bread.  

It's good stuff.  But you didn't need me to tell you that.  I'm sure the other stuff is good.  And it's a good thing that they don't take plastic.  The economy crashing makes it abundantly clear that the American population has been relying too much on plastic.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Very, very good bread, and pretty good sandwiches. Always good,  I go
here to buy my daily? weekly? 10-daily? bread. Highly recommended.

The one minus to this place, is that they do not accept credit cards. I can
deal. The bread is worth it.
author: Max R.

description: This is my go to place for bread.  I usually get the cranberry walnut bread for breakfast.  Toast up a slice of this and put some amazing french butter (like the one from the Cheeseboard, Buerre de Baratte), and you're good to go.  I've only tried a few things here, but liked everything so far.  Love that most of the ingredients is organic.  It's one of the main reasons I stumbled onto this place.  And prices are reasonable.  Remember to bring cash!
author: Meg D.

description:
I recently discovered their little pre-made sandwich's, TOTALLY worth the extra 15min on the treadmill for one of these bad boys!

Yum Yum and more Yum, so simple yet so good! I'm all about simple FRESH ingredients and ACME has really mastered that, they only offer 3 different types of sammies: A cheese sandwich with Mt. Tam cheese, fig jam, and Arugula.. A Salami with baby pickles and butter and a vegetarian option which I have yet to try...

Perfect quick options for lunch at a reasonable price, $5.15 per sammie, not bad at all in my book!
author: S A.

description: I usually go next door to Golden Gate Meat for the steak sandwich on Wednesdays.  They use the rustic rolls from Acme for their sandwiches.  Decided last night to make my own ribeye sandwiches.  Bought five rolls for $.65 each and grilled my own ribeye.  The bread is perfect and taste great slightly warmed or not.
author: Josh L.

description:
I wasn't sure if I should go 5 stars, because, that's just a lot of stars, but it is definitely the best bread company I've found so far in San Francisco. 

The rustic and sourdough baguettes are good, so are their smaller rolls, the ciabattas, everything.  

Oh wait, you know what, I wouldn't recommend their chocolate crossaint. In fact, I'm not sure about their pastry products, but their breads . . . . awesome.

Also, great prices.
author: n s.

description:
This place is great. The sweet baguette is awesome! 

The sweet batard is amazing - it makes fantastic french toast. The croissant and pastries are average but good. This is really THE place for bread.
author: Chili B.

description: Very good.  Had the salame sandwich which was very tasty.  A reasonable price as well.  Cash only so be prepared.
author: Anthony R.

description:
Got some rustic rolls and rosemary rolls Thanksgiving morning (thank you!) for Thx dinner. Good thing I got too many, because they smelled so good I couldn't help but pre-sample lol. The rustic was a total 5 star standout, very simple and satisfying all on its own. The rosemary was merely pretty darn good.

Great bread at reasonable prices.
author: Charles B.

description:
One word:  CIABATTA!  mmmmm....  with a little butter or olive oil...  

I also love love love their pain de mie.  Sooo... bready....  if you know what i mean....

Extremely cheap for the wonderfully tasty bread.  ACME breads are always fresh!
author: Gigi T.

description: Oh yum!  It's all good.  Go ahead & indulge!  Really, everything we've ever bought from here is just delicious & almost never makes it home without us ripping off some bites to eat on our walk home!  YUM!
author: Donna W.

description:
I have always been a lover of bread & I thought I knew how fine bread could be, until I met ACME!
Holy Lord, this bread is amazing! I DREAM about it. Is it just bread?? NO! It is my life's blood! 
I ate 2 sweet baguettes today & that means you're jealous!
author: Melisser E.

description:
FERRY PLAZA FRUGAL: If you're ever in the Ferry market and Acme is not positively mobbed with people, you'll be able to stand right in front of the counter and actually SMELL why everyone is beside themselves about Acme. And, you can sample their pastries. I had their BUTTER CROISSANT, and it was a frugally delicious surprise at $2.15 USD (less then Tartine). It's an American-made croissant- big-big and ugly-but it gets the butter and browned and delicate moist layers juuuuuust right. (Probably would be great with homemade jam, too.)

As for the rest of the bread, read the other 166 reviews. I personally think all their bread is smashing. And, I look forward to trying their pannettone next Christmas. I especially like the hot dog buns which I also use for my petite cheesesteaks (made with TJ's sliced carne)- Does that seem a little extravagant to get your hot dog buns from Acme??? Nah, I didn't think so either.
author: E L.

description:
They really only have bread and nothing but. I asked if they had a bit of butter and they were like "You can buy a whole stick at Cowgirl." Well, I didn't need a whole stick of butter with my little roll.

Great little torpedo rolls, olive rolls, ciabatta, pain epi, ahm and cheese turnovers, baguettes and so on. The torpedo rolls are the best for sandwiches. Light but not tasteless.
author: cyndi L.

description:
I would have to say this place is actually about a 3 1/2 stars out of 5 but i didn't want to give people the wrong impression and turn them off to it because i put a 3 instead of 4 haha...maybe its a 3 and 3/4 :-P

I absolutely love the herd foccacia slab at the acme bread co.

This is by far the best bread company in San Francisco in my opinion.   I think this place blows the Boudin bakery out of the water.  The people behind the counter here are all friendly in my experience and they really know their product. A few times ive wanted to try something different but i didn't know what, and if you ask their opinion they usually have some pretty good recommendations.  

The reason this place is only about 4 out of 5 stars is because not everything that i have tried there is over the top.  I have been here several times and i would say about 3/4 of various breads here are very good and at least above average.  As a local, the Arizmendi bakery is still by far my favorite bread in the city (especially since its closer to my house) but if it comes down to an actual bread company when im not in my neighborhood, this has to be my favorite.  

If your looking for a wide selection of breads that are all at least above average, that are all reasonably priced, then this is a definite place to try.
author: Mark R.

description:
You people in No Cal don't know how lucky you're, awesome awesome bread.  

San Diegans, if you think Bread & Cie has good bread this place will blow them away.
author: e l.

description: Oh my god did I miss this bakery when I lived in New Orleans.  All their perfect bread is crusty yet soft and completely delicious.  Best sourdough baguette in the city!  There.  I said it.
author: Cork C.

description:
Bread is the staff of life.  In San Francisco and the Bay Area, we are fortunate, I think we live in a bread mecca.  Many worship at the altar of Acme Bread.  I confess, I do too.  

Acme's baguette is famed for the crust, if you are not careful, a baguette can tear and cut the roof of your mouth and shred your tongue.  But think of the pleasure you enjoy while doing that?

I love the green onion slab, it's just heavenly, plain, with butter, toasted with an eggplant spread, melty with cheese, it's always a staple in my house.  It also freezes great!

One thing, and I do hesitate to mention this, the sandwiches.  In particular, the Fra Mani salame sandwich.  Tear your mouth up with the crusty baguette and tear your heart out with the wonderfully delicious salame.  Now, I've reviewed Bocalone down the hallway of the Ferry Building already (pretentious pig, put some lipstick on it), and I am an avowed fan of everything Molinaris (gimme gimme more), but I have to confess, I would walk a mile or two for some more of this Fra Mani salame.  Simple is the sandwich, but incredibly tasty.  For $5 you'd think you would not be satisfied, but believe me, you will be!  Just save one for me, okay, now that I've told you about it, it's our secret, okay?
author: Donna H.

description: When it comes to bread, you can't beat Acme! The herb slab is delicious and makes a mean sandwich. Last time I was in the city I didn't get to the Ferry Building until the end of the day and they were out of the slab, so I picked up focaccia instead, which was also delicious but monstrously huge (see pictures). It was a bit of a pain to carry around, but totally worth it!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Cheese rolls (the pinwheel kind, not the round ones), pan de mie.  Nothing more is needed. The cheese wheels beat Arizmendi's cheese rolls. And the pan de mie I have found nowhere else. As a kid my mom would buy that milk bread at the original Acme in Berkeley for holidays. I would try to eat the whole loaf. I say try because my mom wouldn't let me. It was supposed to be for everyone. But I think I did eat a whole loaf at least once. I totally would now, but I know better than to buy a whole one.
It's not quite as dense and amazing as my childhood memories would lead me to believe, but still very tasty. In fact, I think I shall buy some this week and try to make it home before eating. I suspect it would be even better warmed up.

Yeah, their other bread is good.  But it is much like other artisan breads available in the bay area.  I've had their croissants. Okay, nothing to write home about. This a  bread baker, not a French patisserie.  And that's the way I like it.
author: Allucaneat G.

description: Maybe I'm missing exactly why this shop is so highly rated. We picked up a baguette this weekend and it was good. Just good. Not great. Not even close to the best I've ever had. Just good. I'll buy another the next time I'm there, but I wouldn't visit the ferry building for Acme Bread alone.
author: Ivan L.

description: I love the bread at Acme, especially all the crusty and sour dough dough rolls they make. I just wouldn't recommend coming here on a weekend as the lines are very long and they tend to run out of popular items quickly, like their salami sandwich (though it's kind of a rip off since they only put a very thin layer of salami in it and you end up tasting mostly the bread. But definitely one of my favorite bread companies in the city.
author: Petra S.

description: Soooooo good.  Their olive rolls make me swoon.  I suspect the fact I want to stay away from starch adds to Acme's appeal.  You know you shouldn't.... but oh WOULDN'T it be nice!  Thank God they don't serve them hot, or else it'd be all over for me!
author: Kristen S.

description:
As good as bread gets in the bay area. Not too fixated on sourdough either which is a nice change (but plenty of sourdough anyway). The epi is to die for but sells out. When last night on the way to ferry and not much left, but that forced me to try something new - upstairs bread. Everything bar the kitchen sink in this one as good as the rest.
Grab some acme bread , some cow girl cheese and a bottle of plonk from the wine store and you're set.
Carbs rule!
author: Tony S.

description: We got two sandwiches and both were just OK - the bread was a little hard to chew on sandwiches.  We had the Cheese sandwich and the pesto.  They do not have knives so you can share a sandwich, which is a tad irksome and odd. Two and a half stars,
author: P S.

description: Great bread, maybe a half notch below Tartine, but quicker lines and easier to get to. I think it's reasonably priced - maybe the only thing in the Ferry Building about which I'd say that.
author: Lefty R.

description: We were at the Ferry Building early awaiting our ferry to Vallejo, not expecting anything to be open.  Thankfully Acme is open at 6:30 am weekdays which is great for commuters.  The setup of the bakery is great for tourists because you can watch the bakers in the kitchen while you are waiting to place your order.   We ordered a chocolate and an almond croissant, for $2.50 each.  Both were flaky, the dark chocolate was definitely high quality, and the almond filling was so delicious.  Acme is great for breakfast pastries or a loaf of bread.
author: Amy D.

description:
Yum yum yum. 

We do not like sour bread. We live in Livermore and go to Geary Street in San Francisco for the good bread of the russian bakery. 

YUM YUM YUM! Now this bread beats the russian bakery's bread by far when fresh. It is so fresh and soft and not sour and I LOVE IT! When a day or so older, the russian bakery bread actually holds a little more, because it is just plain bread. Nothing fancy, just plain good bread.

Whenever we can we head to acme and get us a good loaf of bread.
author: Mona O.

description: 4/5 get the bread, then go next door and get some mt tam or something. sit outside and eat it all.
author: Alvin D.

description: Acme Bread is an artisan bread bakery located in the Ferry Building Marketplace (merchant #15). Their breads (made with organic flour + hormone-free milk) are baked fresh during the daytime and smell heavenly as you pass by. I highly recommend their Herb Slab, Pain d'Epi, and Olive Bread. So fresh and tasty! The owners are intimately connected with the world famous Chez Panisse restaurant across the Bay since the husband was the restaurant's first in-house baker in the 1970s. I remember a funny scene around Christmas when a Russian tourist family of three visited. A very young boy was very impatient with the wait, to which the mother replied "honey, we're Russians in a bread line!" Both she and her husband exchanged knowing looks, but the boy was too young to appreciate her humor. I recommend buying some bread here and dipping it with the Persian Lime Olive Oil from Stonehouse California Olive Oil (merchant #28) located in the same marketplace! SO GOOD! Lastly, this place is CASH ONLY. All in all, this is a must-stop for me whenever I come to the Ferry Building, regardless of the lines!
author: Andy C.

description: Acme bread is good but the one you find here is even better. Try the epi and the cranberry walnut bread. They are excellent.
author: Luca R.

description:
I love Acme bread, especially the Walnut Levan and Herb Slab.    I love going to the Ferry building and smelling that wonderful fresh baked bread smell.  And I think their prices are reasonable for organic bread.

2 things I don't like. I trek there once a week from SOMA, during lunch time, and usually buy 2 loaves.  I would LOVE to get a brown paper bag with handles.  Instead I get a brown sack that I have to lug around. I know I should take my own bag, but although I own several hundred, sometimes i just forget.  The other thing is that its Cash Only.  Sux when the BoA ATM is busted.

But the bread, the bread is AMAZING!!
author: Jax L.

description:
The bread lover's heaven! HUGE selection of breads and with Cowgirl Creamery right next door and wine store a few steps away, it makes the ferry building the perfect one stop shop for a relaxing night with cheese, bread, and wine!

I LOVE carbs - noodles, rice, bread, pasta - you name it! It took me forever to decide which breads I wanted to try this time. I opted for the olive bread (delicious although a bit salty) and the green onion bread (good texture, light subtle taste). Service is friendly. Cash only!
author: Linda C.

description: Well, maybe my disappointment came from having too high of  expectations, after reading all the positive reviews on Yelp.  We tried a few sandwiches, including the potato with pesto on sweet baguette, and the salami w/cheese on baguette.  Both were fairly average in taste; just not my cup of tea.  Lines can get pretty long during the weekends, but they do move pretty fast.
author: Mike M.

description: This place is the closest thing to heaven for a bread lover. The only bread shop that transports me back to europe each time i bite into a perfectly crisp baguette. Cheese wheel similar to the cheese wheel that brought me to my knees in France. Pair it with cheese from the cheese shop next door. *Amazing* FYI: the only downside: cash only
author: Rebecca S.

description: I tried the Au Pain Chocolat and it was good. I would prefer it is a little more crispier. Perhaps it would be if they just came out from the oven. I would like to try other bread items next time when I visit here again.
author: Art T.

description: If I live within walking distance of the ferry building I will be a fat bastard thanks to acme's french loaves. Seriously, no one should ever touch this form of diet killer unless it comes from acme's baking grounds. Skip the sandwiches though, they are kind of a rip off.
author: Jerry H.

description:
With all the exquisite culinary creations i've tried in my life so far, I am almost ashamed to say that quality bread and (salted) butter is still my favorite part of any meal.  Ludicrous right?  I am known to consume the equivalent of a loaf before the appetizers even arrive.

If you have tried Acme's breads, you will not think this is ludicrous.  Their sourdough has just the right consistency, crustiness and amount of yeast to provide that true San Francisco sourdough taste.  You know a restaurant knows their shit when they offer Acme bread.

All of their breads are phenomenal.  Their ciabatta, sourdough, sweet batard...all mouthwatering.  The perfect addition to any sandwich, bread pudding or as a beginner to every meal.  Not going to win the carb war thanks to this...
author: Genevieve M.

description:
Love this place, stop there at least once a week on my way through the ferry building. They have excellent Sourdough, great Sour Baguettes and their Herb Loaf is my personal favorite. Add some Red Hawk Cheese from the Cowgirl Creamery, a bottle of vino and you're set for a Friday evening commute.

One thing that really kicks ass about this place is the fact that you can get fresh Challah...a fresh loaf of Challah makes one rocking french toast on Saturday morning.

Well I know where I'm stopping this afternoon!
author: Rob C.

description:
There are a lot of things I don't miss about France: the endless strikes, the bureaucracy of various government institutions, the abundant dog poop in the streets, the shops being closed on Sundays and late evenings.  But one thing I miss that I can't find in the US is their amazing fresh bread. 

Fresh bread is everywhere and cheap in France!  I can slowly stroll two doors down from where I live, and pick up a just-out-the-oven baguette for 4 francs (about 80cents at the time).  It's not uncommon for my roommate and I to finish one long baguette each as an afternoon snack.  It's like Pringles, once you start, you can't stop.  And often we don't even put anything on the baguette, not even butter.  That's how good they were. 

ACME definitely fills that void for me.  So it's not next door to where I live and it's not like 80 cents a baguette (there IS inflation and the weakening of the dollar).  But the bread is darn good. 

I have had the ciabatta many times.  They are great for panini sandwiches.  And they stay good for a few days.  If they do get slightly hard, just pop them in the microwave for 15 seconds and they will get softer and chewy again.   The herb slab is also really tasty and the dough is super chewy which is how I like my bread.  

I like it when I bring the bread back to work and every so often I can smell the lovely bread-y fragrance.  It's so salivating!
author: Candice B.

description:
OK.  We love love adore can't get enough of their bread.  So why the 3 stars?  Please bakers - go easy on the flour.  The Epi and various baguettes are often time caked, yes CAKED IN FLOuR!  

How can I enjoy the crusty/chewy wonderfulness when all I can feel is the floor in my mouth?  Plus I can't imagine that's good for you.  

So Please:  go easy on the flour.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Acme is simply the best bread around.  I love the pain epi!  Sort of trying to not buy it as often as I do since it makes me not venture out to the other ones.  If you work downtown or happen to be at the ferry building, you can ask them what will be coming out of the oven soon.  I can't even begin to describe how good the pain epi is hot from the oven.  

Aside from my obvious favorite epi, the herb slab is super good and so is the batard and the baguettes.  I also really like the deli rolls and the torpedos for sandwiches.  Another great treat is the sourdough wheel.  Probably not the best thing for you on the menu considering that is is covered in what I think is parmesan cheese, but it is super good and a nice chance of pace for breakfast.

Do yourself a favor, go to Acme, ask them what will be hot soon and hang out an wait for some of the best bread around straight from the oven.
author: Brian L.

description: Very good artisan breads.  Much, much better than you'd get at the supermarket.  They know their bread - we picked up some baguettes for a couple bucks apiece - hard and crusty on the outside, soft on the inside.  You can make a meal out of the bread you buy here and the cheese you buy next door at the Cowgirl creamery.
author: Rob K.

description:
You'd think that there'd be more competent bakeries in the city or at least places that knew how to make a proper baguette (And, no, not sourdough).

Yet, Acme, is the easy hands down winner in this apparently one horse race for baguettes/bread.

The pain epi is our favorite but rustic italian, sweet baguette and ciabatta all find a way to our home.

Best place to buy, in our opinion, is to go to the Ferry Building and purchase it hot/fresh.

Little know hint/tip is to cut up the bread and freeze them in sandwich bags (I know, it seems like a cardinal sin) and toast them when you're ready to eat them...Saves us frequent trips to Ferry Building as Whole Foods and others have a tendency to both sell out and get pretty dry quickly.
author: Barca F.

description:
I'd give it a 4.5 star for the following reasons:
(1)  Bread is reasonably priced, and oh so delicious.  I've tried just about everything, and honestly don't have any favorites (i love them all).  If i had to pick one to eat everyday, I'd probably pick their croissants (Almond or regular kind, but i'm pretty partial to croissants, especially if they're decent like Acme's, I'd eat it everyday)
(2)  Highly recommend their Salame sandwiches, which are sold during lunchtime, for ~$6, which is great considering lunches everywhere else in the Ferry building is around $10.  Their Salame sandwich is perfectly sized, with couple slices of Salame, butter, cheese & pickles.  My mouth drools as i type this...
CASH ONLY, be prepared.
author: Laura C.

description: Best bread ever.  Also great sandwiches.  Very simple and can't be custom ordered but who doesn't love bread, butter and meat/cheese?  Also one of the fastest places to get lunch in the Ferry Building.  The line is usually pretty short so there's basically no wait since the sandwiches are pre-made.  Cash only.
author: barbara b.

description: So good.  I like savory in the morning so I skip the sugary croissants and buy a cheese wheel from Acme-it's just a sourdough base with Asiago cheese melted into it.  On the way home I'll pick up a baguette or roll.  They have so many sizes that one person can eat.  And if you want a croissant they are actually excellent too.
author: Jean T.

description:
I usually frequent the one in Berkeley, however, when Acme is nearby, My eyes get bigger than my stomach and I buy more bread than I need.
Low carb?  That concept is foreign to me.  Since the young age when I was barely able to speak, my love of food consisted of 'B'.  I still love bread, but have expanded this to include most other forms of carbs as well.

At Acme, I only have eyes for PAIN EPIS
author: Amy T.

description:
Whether getting a simple baguette for your Cow Girl Creamery brie, picking up a couple of hamburger buns for a BBQ or looking for a fancy potato rosemary loaf Acme can NOT be beat. 

The smells alone will lure you up to the stall, the friendly and prompt service will entice you to stay and the price and quality will keep you coming back. Yeah Acme!!!
author: Jenni D.

description:
It's bread... only better than any other bread you've ever had before. My roomie works in the Ferry Building, I need to remind her to bring this stuff home more often. 

Meryl, if you're reading this, you know what to do.
author: Alex C.

description:
Walking to work from BART in the morning, I see the Acme-emblazoned truck drive by.  Mini heart attack.  I ponder just how crazy the driver would think I was if I were to ask him to a) sell me bread right there on the spot in the parking lot, no one ever needs to know a loaf went missing, here's an extra dollar for you sir or b) ask him WHERE WHERE WHERE that bread is heading!

I decide it's a bit too crazy.  So instead, the next morning, I wake up an hour early and walk ~2 miles out of my way to the Ferry Building to buy a rustic batard and a roll to nom while trying not to finish my batard on the long walk back to work.  Sleep deprivation swaddled in the tender, elastic, assymmetrical crumb of an Acme batard?  Biting through that crisp, crackly crust for breakfast, lunch, AND pre-dinner end-of-the-day snack?  BEST DAY OF WORK.  EVER.  My boss thought I was crazy.

Dammit.  I went three times in a week.  I mean, I only ate oh, a pound or so of bread each time.  Blisssss
author: Pam Z.

description: I'm a sucker for these guys, because they are (normally) quick, take cash, and make some delicious bread. I still think that Thorough and Firebrand make better bread overall, but Acme has some awesome rolls--- olive, rosemary, and currant being my favorites (currant only available on Friday!), and are awesome mid-run snacks. The staff behind the counter are always friendly, efficient, and helpful too! If only they made more whole wheat-y breads...
author: Amanda S.

description: This place is wonderful. Fresh bread...lovely. And their distribution is in this store, restaurants, and local gourmet stores.
author: Amy O.

description:
Things that I love about Acme:

1. Their sandwiches. For $5 you can get a delicious sandwich. It's not the biggest $5 sandwich out there, but the ingredients are top-quality and they are presented in such a nice way. I especially like the one with goat cheese, green garlic, and roasted red pepper that they make in the spring. They currently have a potato, pesto, and cheese one (which reminds me of a less greasy version of the You Say Potato pizza at Escape From New York) that is delicious too. Word to the wise, get there early before they sell out.

2. Their croutons. I'm sure they're good on salad, but they make excellent breadcrumbs with only a few spins in the Cuisinart. 

3. Their cheese wheels. So cheesy. So deliciously amazing.

4. Their whole wheat walnut bread. A little sour, a lot wheat-y, and lots of tasty walnuts. Yum!

5. Their immediate neighbor is Cowgirl Creamery. Pick up some bread, buy some cheese, and go sit out on the ferry viewing deck for a wonderful afternoon.
author: Katie I.

description:
Great bread.

I have to agree with the others that the olive bread is the best.  Also, the olive rolls and rosemary rolls.  I cannot buy this bread in the morning or else I will snack on it all day at work and only have half a loaf left by close of business.  Not to mention spoiling my dinner.

Hard to go wrong and the prices are fair.  I wish they sliced like Boudin - but still a great loaf at a good price.

MMMmmmmmm
author: Suze C.

description: The smell of bread impresses me!  When such a company can make bread that not only smells good but tastes better!  Anyways, the bread that is made here is incredible!  I love it!  Buy anything here, it's that good!
author: Limzer L.

description:
It's official- I polished off an entire loaf of cranberry-walnut bread in one day.  Ok, so my roommate had a little... but, uh, not enough to justify that the paper wrapper is now sitting forlornly in the middle of the kitchen table, all lonely-like. Breakfast tomorrow is gonna suck.

It cost $3.50 for a thick, crusty-outside-soft-inside-cantaloupe-sized loaf, which seems totally reasonable to me.

Plus, I've decided when I buy things at the Farmer's Market, I am helping the world in my own small way and therefore can purchase and eat whatever I please.
author: Tovah S.

description:
Visited the Ferry Building today, and after having a delicious sandwich made with Acme Bread, I was excited to see that they had a storefront right nearby.  I stood in line, and happily browsed the extensive varieties of bread and pastries that they had for sale; knowing that whatever I picked would probably be made with the same care and quality of the bread that I had tasted earlier that day.

So why only two stars?  Their customer service behind their counter just wasn't up to the same stellar caliber as their bread.  In fact, it was seriously lacking.  The guy who helped us didn't greet us, barely made eye contact, and had a "this-is-just-a-paycheck" attitude that was nearly robotic.  Granted, it's a bread shop, so I'm not expecting enthusiastic cartwheels for everyone who walks through their doors, but a little courtesy and warmth would have gone a very long way in earning them higher marks from me.
author: Jane Y.

description: I must say that I've had mixed experiences here. I've gotten good bread before and almost inedible sandwiches as well. I think their sandwiches can be great but we just got it too late in the day and the bread was already too hard to chew comfortably. I'm still giving it 4* because the fresh bread that I've tried was really good though.
author: Miko L.

description: I had a sandwich, which seems like it may have been the wrong thing to get. It was kinda small and not very exciting. The bread was good though.
author: Grant M.

description: Mmm, grabbed a roll or 2 to sample here, so yummy! The cheese bread had actual cheese in the dough!  Good for your thicker bready kind of bread.
author: Jackie P.

description: Their ham & cheese turnovers fully warrant my rating. Buy one in the morning--the only time they're available--and your teeth will sink into the layers of phillo that condense into flaky rich carb meat offset by sweet, pungent cheese and smoky ham. I honestly have to control my drooling because these simple parts come together so immersively and complex, they must be one of the best things on earth.
author: Nicole L.

description: Rustic Sweet Baguette: I was surprised that it wasn't that expensive. The baguette is absolutely delicious. The outside is crispy and not chewy at all. The inside is soft and moist, not dry like you'd find at grocery stores. I definitely want to try all their breads.
author: Vera W.

description: One of the best bread places in the country. Rivals what you can get in Paris - although not the same it's just as good. Lines can get long but there's a reason. Cash only so they can pass the saving on to customers - it's insanely cheap. Stop complaining about cash only, long lines and get your butt some good bread period.
author: Sam P.

description: I can't remember the names of what I have bought here, but everything really is good. Prices aren't that high either.
author: Jennifer P.

description: The best almond croissant I have had in a loooong time!
author: Cassie P.

description: Mmmm...fresh bread. Gimme Gimme.  I highly recommend the Cranberry Walnut, Olive Loaf and the Herb Slab!
author: Debbie C.

description: It is tradition to go to the Ferry Building and gather bread, meat, cheese and olive oil for hotel room picnics. We make the best sandwiches in San Francisco. Acme makes that possible.
author: Kellee K.

description:
My go to place for my morning baguette (I put nutella in it and grill it).  They make the best baguette (in my opinion) in San Francisco,  try their Rustic  Sweet Baguette, Epi, or Rustic roll.  

If you are lucky, you will get it fresh and still hot out of the oven...I eat it just plain with a cup of hot latte...nothing better in the world.
author: Amy F.

description:
Arguably the best of the bay area's bread places. Try their daily bread special, which always great and on a rotating weekly schedule, pretty much any of their rolls esp rosemary, olive and pumpkin, and any of their sandwiches. I'm not as fond of some of their raisin rolls but that's not their fault.

Don't be afraid of a long line. The line moves quickly and it's cash only. 

Bottom line: Really, if they make it you will probably like it. They are bread artists! Pair with some cheese from Cowgirl next door and you're ready for a classic Parisian sandwich that is simple, delicate, delicious and will totally knock your socks off!
author: Claire G.

description: This place smells delicious. Service was prompt and helpful. Enjoyed the bread here immensely.
author: David H.

description:
So so sad...those sourdough baguettes outta the oven? Cant get anything that comes CLOSE to sourdough on the East coast.

Pure Heaven = Acme sour baguettes.
author: christy c.

description:
I am such a big fan of ACME bread that I drive long distances in south bay to find it. 

I was so looking forward to visit Acme in Ferry Building, and I was sure I would be ready for a treat

Soo many bread choices, its unbelievable. Everything is fresh, and I was tempted to eat, or atleast try every one of their breads. 

Yes, I've seen the variety in a store, but nothing beats going to the source.

We got the Cheese Sandwich, and WOW! 

We never thought something as simple as Baguette, Cream Cheese, Arugula and Preserve would taste so heavenly!! 

The Cream cheese was just fantastic. 

We got some bread for home, and my love for Acme has grown, after a visit here!
author: Manish P.

description: good lord, do i love acme bread company. i ate here every morning during my recent san francisco adventure, and now that i'm home on the east coast, i wish i could have them teleport me bread every day. delicious x 100000000000000.
author: Sara H.

description:
From its great location at the cool Ferry building, to its perfectly baked wholesome breads, Acme delivers a perfect product.

Who knew bread could be this good.

Definitely start here if you plan on making a sandwich at home.
author: shaun l.

description:
Damn fine bread and pastries. Not a clunker in the bunch. So, why not 5 stars? I'll tell you why. If you're going to be grand, and have a big-ass space in the Ferry Building, then accept credit cards. If I have to pay extra for an ATM withdrawal from BofA, then guess who loses out? 

Acme.
author: Rene D.

description:
I heart Acme.

One of my favourite breads in the entire world.... 

Find it, buy it, enjoy it... I told you so.


Bread artisans.... masters.  Yay.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: Sitting here at SFO on a 3 hour fog delay ...I've just inhaled a large hunk of the green onion slab that I was going to have with soup once I got home to Denver ....delicious, mild tasting and perfectly chewy ... I am one happy man.  Tried to get a ham and cheese croissant based on their reviews, but I was too late.  Doing my best not to tear into the NYC rye that is tucked away in my bag.
author: Paul W.

description:
After hearing a few coworkers and friends rave about Acme Bread Co., I was really excited to try the different kinds of bread there - especially considering since I am a bread junkie and would honestly be content to skip dessert and eat warm, delicious bread instead.

Now that I have been to Acme Bread several times, I have to say that I am somewhat dismayed and disappointed.  Is the bread pretty decent and better than what you get from a Safeway bakery?  Sure but it is not worthy of the lofty ratings and praise it seems to consistently get.  

Acme makes a really good sourdough bread but in SF that is no big deal.  Like making a decent slice in NYC or a cheesesteak in Philly.  It takes a lot to really stand out since there is a lot of decent competition.  As for the other things I have tried at Acme, the quality has been mixed.  I have gotten a couple of different French loafs and they have varied widely in quality.  One had a nice consistency while another didn't have the nice, light interior a quality French loaf should have.  A few of the specialty loafs have been decent but there hasn't been one that really jumps out at me either.  Guess it depends upon individual preference more though.     

Not exactly sure what it is but the dough is just not quite right most times.  Maybe they aren't kneading the bread enough manually or it just might be the oven.  One thing that I heard from a friend who is a baker is that the quality of the water on the West Coast makes it difficult to make good dough in general.  

Acme still makes a quality loaf of bread most times but it is far from the best bread I have ever tasted.  Plus, it is a bit on the pricey side for a bakery in general.
author: Matthew G.

description:
Fantastic bread, and for those visitors like myself who did not bring a cooler along and was thus not able to take any Cowboy Creamery cheese home with me, Acme makes a daily cheese sandwich with ingredients from said cheese neighbor.  My triple creme quince paste arugula sandwich was an enormous consolation for my lack of foresight this trip, and the bread brought back memories of my days in France.  Lovely crusty yummy baguette.

Oh Acme, why can't you set up a shop in South Lake Tahoe? You'd make me and so many mountain foodies so happy.

They don't get a 5th star from me because they don't take credit cards.  Had they done so, I would have come away with a lot more than just un sandwich.
author: Jenn G.

description: Bread-gasm, Bread-gasm, Bread-gasm!  oooooooohhhhhhh...... yeahhhhh
author: Nikki B.

description: I love the cheese sandwich, made with fig jam and Cowgirl Creamery Mt. Tam cheese.  The breads here are all very fresh and tasty too.
author: B. Y.

description: the best bolillo outside mexico ,,,,  in sf ca
author: Salvador G.

description: My office used to be right upstairs from Acme. Over a nine-week period I gained nine pounds. You get fat just from smelling the stuff, I swear.
author: Liz T.

description: If I weren't bored I probably wouldn't have bothered writing a review for this place. I got some ciabatta bread for my mother and it was okay. Just average bread nothing to write home about but nothing wrong with it either. I guess I just expected something because it was inside the ferry building - oops.
author: becca w.

description:
Hands down best bread company in the Bay Area.
Great prices, long lines....which translates to ALWAYS superfresh bread.  I regret introducing this place to my mom cause now everytime I come home (which is every week) I have to stop off for a sourdough wheat loaf and an Epi.  A cant miss in the ferry building.

UPDATE: I have since moved out of the city and continue to buy Acme Bread at the Berkeley Bowl, but NOTHING beats the bread offerings at the Ferry Building...they are so fresh out of the oven there...I miss it so much!
author: Cathleya G.

description:
if you like Olive Bread - for sure get some here - it's jam packed with olives...
I've found though that the best for gifting is the Herb Slab. Everytime I head up to Marin I pick up a loaf of something for whomever is lucky enough to pick me up from the ferry building...
the most smiles come from the Herb Slab. My dad also swears up and down it makes the  BEST morning after toast.

I'm also a big fan of their croissants - butter up the wazzo which makes it even more tasty - Piperade also serves them in their cafe window...knowing where Acme bread is served all over the city makes life a little more awesome also.
author: Katy A.

description:
Favorites: 
Epi
Olive roll
Cinnamon currant bun
Sourdough cheese wheel

Tip: prices are a tiny-weeny lower if you go out back to their stand in the farmers market.
author: Mark C.

description: LOVE their olive bread...crusty and full of delicious plump olive pieces.  I haven't tried their other breads but it has to be good if all the surrounding restaurants use their breads.  Note: Cash Only!
author: Cathy L.

description: ok, I am a bread and baked goods fan.  This place is great.  I got the ciabatta and herb slab.  Both fresh, moist and delicious.  I ate both loaves without any condiments or additions.  Yum
author: Floyd F.

description:
Acme's bread is really fresh and they've got all these specialty breads. I've snuck out of the office a few times just to run over here to buy a loaf of bread and ate it at the office with some butter.

They've got those great day old loafs on the shelf for the half the price and are still really good. I know you don't save that much considering their breads aren't all that pricey, but if you feel like it. It's there and is a great deal.  

I get all Anti-Akins when I go to a place like this.  Buy their Challah bread and make french toast out of it.  

Jesus got a loaf of bread here and commenced the breaking of the bread.
author: Miss Pigg y.

description:
This place is solid. 

Bakes pretty good bread, including one of my favorite breads of all time: orange and almond brioche, which has a shape like panettone. So Delicious. Now I really need to have it. It's new year's eve and they are probably closed. Besides the parking is a pain there. Great, I wish I didn't review this place.
author: Erika K.

description: The best baguette and bread store in the SF Bay Area by far.
author: Miguel E.

description: Really such consistently good quality.  You can't go wrong showing up for a dinner party carrying an epi loaf.  The price is really fair, despite being located in the pricey Ferry Building.
author: june b.

description: If I can only eat one thing for the rest of my life, let it be Acme bread!
author: Chloe H.

description: I'm a big fan of the olive bread, full olives and perfectly baked bread. Their selection is pretty big and well worth trying a few. I suggest getting them as rolls so you can make small sandwiches.
author: Angela K.

description:
The best bread. Hands down. The breads are great, the rolls are fantastic and prices can't be beat. I drop in a couple evenings a week to bring home rolls or bread and have never been disappointed. 
If you need bread stop by and treat yourself to quality not usually found for prices like these.
author: Kfir L.

description:
This BEST place for bread.  I love taking my out of towner friends to show them what REAL bread taste like and believe me,  they are converts and wishes they have an Acme Bakery in their city. Being an avid runner, I will never have to worry about carb counting at this place! *evil laughs*

Their herb slab......probably the best bread in the world.  So savory and sweet and just the right amount of chewiness.  Their baguette is also one of the best I ever had.

Go get their bread!
author: Chris C.

description:
My coworkers always rant and rave about Acme Bread.  And I have yet to try it.  They told me about the sandwiches they also have.  So the other day, I decided to give it a try.  I got their cheese sandwich and can i tell you...it is so yummy!!  I even kept the little tag on the sandwich with the following description: 

Cheese Sandwich:   Rustic Baguette, Mr. Tam triple creme cheese, Fig Jam, Arugula, Black Pepper.  

I keep the label up at my desk thinking I can make this at home...but we know that I probably won't do that and will just to back to the ferry building for another sandwich!
author: Brenda H.

description:
For me, this is a great place to stop before I hop the ferry home and I would highly recommend it for anyone who can get by the Ferry Building in the City.  A wide selection and service is excellent.  

Only drawback - no credit cards.  I find a couple of times where I don't have any cash and have to take a pass.  Come on, this IS the 21st century.  Yes, they take a percentage, but really, bite the bullet and come into the digital world.  I bet if the did a cost-benefit analysis, they'd discover they likely would learn that the percentage points they saved were more than covered by the folks who'd be able to buy (or buy more) if they took credit cards....but I digress....it's why I didn't give them a full five starts.
author: Greg R.

description:
Best Bread Ever

Anywhere

I love hitting the Ferry Building outpost on my way into work.  Nothing like a sweet roll with my Peet's.

BEST SWEET BATARDS ANYWHERE!!
author: Christine K.

description: Fresh bread is yummy in the tummy.  Can find the perfect bread here to go with all the other yummy goodness you have picked up at the Ferry building.
author: Mabelle A.

description:
Bread was good but if it's not fresh bread, it's crap. I really, really want to like this place. 

The sourdough bread tasted great but in the end it wasn't fresh. I'll try to go back and get there earlier but as my yelp rating says. "Meh. I've experienced better."
author: Chris P.

description:
This is my favorite bread ever. I love coming by here and picking out a loaf from their big selection. They have all the varieties laid out on the counter so you can easily look around and pick what looks good.

The italian batard is really good, I love the crispy top part of the crust. The pan levian is cool, you can pull apart the individual pieces, nice if you have a group of friends together. I can't wait to try more, they have a few treats like croissants and cinnamon bread that I haven't tried.
author: Nathan M.

description:
i love their bread! everytime i visit the ferry buliding, i have to get bread.
you cant go wrong with organic bread (not 100% organic, only the flour).

did anyone notice the price of bread went up?
the rosemary bread went up 5 cents.
60 cents each now.
just putting it out there, not complaining, but they should make a value deal or discount/incentive for being a loyal customer.

my only problem is having the bread the days after the day you buy it fresh. it gets so hard, and dabbing it with water and reheating is a little bit of a pain so i jus eat all the carbs i can in one day.

Cash only.

Thank you for the longer hours.
author: Janet W.

description: I wish they cared about their customers and not just their product.  If it's so crowded in the market you miss seeing the "cash only" sign you are in for a rude surprise.  Even after a substantial purchase and offering all viable forms of identification they send you to stand in a long line to pay a fee over at the ATM, then you have to stand in their line yet again.  Mention your frustration to the manager afterwards and all you get is a snide, "Are sure you want your purchase today?"  The other merchants inside take plastic or checks but these folks simply couldn't care less.  Never again!
author: Patricia T.

description: We have a few good bakerys here in OC but whenever I'm in SF or if a friends there I asked them to bring me back a baguette.
author: Jenny Q.

description:
I've almost eaten entire wheat walnut loaves from this place.

Seriously bored counter help though.  If you don't like working around food, maybe you shouldn't be working in the Ferry Building people. It's a bakery. I don't need your attitude when all I'm buying is bread. K?
author: BroSauce J.

description:
Best bread in San Francisco, hands down.

The Pan Epi is amazing, and the cheese wheel and loaf are exceptional breads. 

No preservatives, so don't expect this bread to last longer than the day you bought it on!
author: G J J.

description: Where do I start....rye raisin rabbit, pumpkin roll, panettone -- I love it all! You can't get bread that is any fresher or more delicious -- it's really too bad that man can't live on bread alone. I would live on Acme!
author: Joanne B.

description:
Acme Bread is a big reason why I like going to the Ferry Building.

I love their sourdough cheese rolls! I first had it when they were passing them out to the runners after the SF marathon, and I've been addicted ever since. Unlike most places, the sourdough bread is chewy, not hard as a rock. There's no skimping on the cheese either...all delicious goodness.

Also superb is the potato pesto sandwich they serve for lunch from 11am-2pm. It's very filing and has a nice potato to cheese to pesto ratio - nothing overwhelms.
author: Christine T.

description: What can I say about Acme Bread Company that hasn't been said time and time again?  This is THE BEST bread in the Bay Area.  You have to start with the sourdough baquette but then pick a few other items at random - everything is great and you're likely to find a new favorite.  You'll wonder how you ever lived without Acme bread.
author: Laura L.

description: I love this place. One block away. Great Bread. I think I'll try each type of bread they make.
author: Johnson H.

description:
Fought through traffic and crowds to reach the counter, and was amazed by the selection. We picked out the following to try:
1) Olive roll
2) Walnut Levain  Bread
3) Raisin roll

Like the others say, this is expensive bread. Most of them are sourdough based.

Based on the 3 types of bread we tried, I honestly think that Acme is overrrated on Yelp. There was nothing spectacular about their Walnut Levian Bread - I've had better from Trader Joes and from Anderson Bakery in the South Bay. My bf said it's very plain tasting and wouldn't buy again. The olive roll was full of green olives, with a very strong taste, but we've had better olive bread from La Brea before. As for the raisin roll, it tasted ok, was good with cream cheese, but again - not memorable. 

I'm not sure if it's because we didn't try some of their more classic combinations like Sourdough Baguette, but at this moment, I am positive that this bakery did not make it into my list of favorites around the bay.
author: Lei P.

description: So many choices, but we ended up getting the sweet rustic baguette - delicious!  So fresh, perfectly crunchy on the outside (no toasting necessary for this bread) and soft on the inside.  Combined with a slice of Midnight Moon from Cowgirl Creamery and prosciutto from Molinari Delicatessen - a foodie's dream come true!  Take it outside and eat it on the benches along the pier for a quintessential Ferry Building picnic lunch.
author: Cassie H.

description: Olive loaf.  I'm wondering why I didn't bring back more than one loaf with me on the plane.  I am going to try to recreate this at home sometime, but I have very low expectations of success.
author: Megan C.

description: The selection of freshly baked bread is unlike any other. They have it all and more. Grab some cheese from Cowgirl Creamery or some olive oil and balsamic from Stonehouse and you are all set. Oh and don't forget your favorite bottle of vino!
author: Angelica C.

description: All the bread is consistently good, and a couple of the loaves are delightful. The Upstairs Bread, especially, makes me cry because I only allow myself to buy one at a time.
author: Lili R.

description:
I made my own artisan bread once...  wow, that was a lot of work.
