Now I know it's totally worth the money to buy a loaf at Acme whenever I want to. This is darn good bread. Try all of them.
author: Ethan B.

description: I'm definitely a fan of ACME Bread Company. I like to consider them the bay area equivalent of La Brea Bakery here in Los Angeles. Awesome bread selection, fresh, and it doesn't cost an arm and a leg for it. Wholesome and perfect for every occasion. While a lot of local restaurants in SF and Oakland carry or serve ACME, this location in the Ferry Building is my favorite. Located just a few feet away from Boccalone and Cowgirl Creamery, this is the perfect place to get some grocery errands and some picnic basket making done! I'm in love with their Pan de Mie (a loaf of amazing bread for less than $4) as well as their smaller breads like their hot dog buns, brioche buns, and their cranberry walnut or sourdough rounds. A solid and satisfying boulangerie! It should be of note that there are hardly any lines during week days, but there can be a little bit of a wait on the weekends. It really says a lot when you can find sheer bliss from a slice of bread with butter.
author: Frances L.

description:
I wish I could take one home every day!
The best baguettes in the city and the herb slabs are great for panninis.
author: jennifer l.

description:
Having lived in France for oh so many years, an Acme baguette is perhaps the closest you'll get to the every day staple.  Try and get it fresh from the Ferry Building instead of from Whole Foods, Harvest Market, Bi-Rite, or any number of organic stores.  When it's fresh and warm from the oven, it's easy to down the baguette in one, two, three bites.

Their other bread is solid but not as good.  The one exception is the olive bread which has plenty of olives, just the right saltiness, and the same deliciousness that the baguette has.  Now, let me just go find some cheese...
author: A K.

description:
Good bread.

Of the options here in the City, I will usually reach for an Acme loaf before any other. Nice stuff.

Everything I've had is good, but I have a soft spot for the two Slabs (Herb or Green Onion) with a slight pref towards the G.O.

Stop next door and get some good Cheese and ENJOY!
author: Ryan F.

description: Fantastic bread. We have used acme bread... forever.  Cash only kind of sucks.
author: Alex M.

description: This is a hardworking crew with a great product. The cheese pinwheels are great!
author: Peggy J.

description:
If you are not sure what to get, just close your eyes and point at something completely at random. You will not be disappointed. I always like their French loaves, but I usually just get the cinnamon currant loaf/bun/thingy.

No, they do not accept credit cards, and anyone who tell you that they do is high. They even have signs out that say cash only.
author: Gareth B.

description:
Screw what they say about breads being too carb heavy. How can you resist a Acme twinkle. Wow that sounded kinda disgusting. LOL!!! 

The service is always spot on and they helped me figure out which loaf I should get for croutons I'm going to make myself. They had some pre-made but I like making my own. 

Prices cannot be beat and definitely a wide selection to make any bread lover go crazy.
author: S L.

description: My hubby & I absolutely loved the cheese sandwiches made with fig jam and cheese from the next door shop. There was a farmers market taking place in front of the pier where we got us some freshly squeezed blood orange juice. the combination of all those flavors was havenly :))
author: Bella F.

description: I was not dying to get a loaf of bread or anything, however the shop smelled amazing and the $5 cheese sandwich is well worth it (triple-creme cheese, fig spread, arugula). The cinnamon croissant-y thing looked incredible as well.
author: Gina Q.

description:
As I search for a job and watch my finances, i sometimes need an excuse to get out of bed. 

My reward for rising and making the twenty minute walk to the ferry building? An Olive Roll. Small on size but packed with flavor; you are one of the best treats under a dollar.

Thanks Acme!
author: Cynthia J.

description:
I find that most of their breads are over-crusted and their selection is fairly plain. I've tried several loaves and they are all very mediocre. The herbed focaccia is good, but their olive loaf tastes like vinegar and is all air and crust.

It would be nice to see them adopt a more creative selection, but when you're an institution like Acme I doubt that kind of change is possible. Acme is carried at Whole Foods, Costco, and almost every Farmer's Market so at least it's really easy to find. There is also a "cult of Acme" that really turns me off (120 reviews and mine is the second lowest!), but that's a bit off-topic.

Check out Great Harvest in Rockridge. They're pretty good -- not as good as the bakery I used to visit in San Diego, but oh well.
author: Alex P.

description: Everytime I get to the counter I still cannot decide which bread to buy because I want to try all of them - from the baguettes to the olive rolls, there's dozens of different breads to choose from here. Gone with the scallion slab ($3.50 each) and olive rolls ($0.80 each) - and after biting into the olive rolls while en route back to Los Angeles I regretted not buying a lot more. The olive bits were flavorful but not overpowering and lends the bread a soft oily finish on the inside. Goes great with the rabbit pate from Cowgirl Creamery or any of their cheeses. The scallion slab reminds me of scallion pancakes in those greasy chinese joints but without all that grease - a great bread to go with balsamic vinegar - my fiancee was pouring balsamic vinegar on the bread while in the car during our drive home down to LA. I think next time I will just buy 5-6 different types. I love artisan breads.
author: Calvin Y.

description: If you are here early enough try the breakfast sandwiches they are killer.  The olive bread is also another tasty favorite of mine. Don't forget your cash as credit cards aren't accepted
author: Roger H.

description: This is a must stop for some farmers market carbo loading. All the bread here is great and I've noticed that many local restaurants use bread from ACME. So if your out at a fine dining eatery and can't get enough of the bread? chances are it's from ACME. I'm a huge fan of their sourdough sandwich loaf. A sourdough loaf, some gruyere from cowgirl, and a ripe and red organic tomato from the market and you've got your self the ingredients for a damn fine grilled cheese. They don't cut the bread loaves however so make sure you've got a nice sharp knife at home that wont squish your fresh bread! Excellent place, I'm a fan and will be back again and again!
author: Danny R.

description: The BEST baguette in SF comes from Acme!  I really like getting the bread and some cheese from cowgirl nearby.  That with a bottle of wine is sooo soothing. Acme also sells other types of breads like rolls with raisins or loaves but the baguette is what i come back for.  Yeah, it's a little pricey when you think about the fact that it's bread and how big it is but for the quality and the fact that they have to pay ferry building rent, it's totally understandable.  GO and get yourself some ACME bread stat!
author: Ka C.

description: I got a garlic cheese sandwich, and their bread was spectacular! It reminds me of this lox, creamcheese sandwich from NYC. It was really good, i'd recommend it highly. $5.15 for a sandwich, reasonable prices for other such breads. Share w/ a friend to keep you coming back for more. Yummo!
author: Camille T.

description: I came here after going to Cowgirl Creamery to get cheeses and got the olive loaf and the chocolate croissant.  The olive loaf had big green olives stuck in them, and it was delicious.  Although more flavorful than a plainer bread, I actually didn't find this bread too salty and it went really well with the cheeses we bought.  We liked this bread because it tasted good alone AND with the cheeses.  The chocolate croissant was definitely high quality with delicious dark chocolate in the center.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Best Baguette on the west coast.  Brings me back to the taste of Paris.  I wish they would open one up in LA.  La Brea Bakery is so meh compared to Acme.
author: Grace C.

description: good bread
author: Michael E.

description: I have yet to encounter anything form this bakery that isn't great, with most of their products verging on wonderful, like the cheese sandwich or the olive roll.
author: Andy G.

description:
i love it warm or room temp, topped, filled, sweet, savory or just buttered. this is the best bread anywhere ! 

only downside for me is so many choices.
author: roger b.

description: Delicious fresh breads at relatively cheap prices. Go get a nice cheese next door at cowgirl creamery for a nice simple Lunch.
author: Brian T.

description:
Acme works miracles with just 4 simple ingredients (flour, water, salt and yeast). Their baguettes are second to none locally, especially the pain epi, which strikes a sublime balance of crispy and chewy. It's the only baguette I can happily devour without anything added, including butter.

Make the effort to get the bread directly from their Ferry Plaza shop. It's much better than the Acme bread distributed throughout Bay Area supermarkets. Their freshness half-life is measured in short hours after baking.
author: jj w.

description: I've seen/passed this bakery a million times and never bothered to stop until I had their bread while having lunch at Hog Island Oyster Company. It was soooo good that I had to ask where it was from. The waiter informed me that it was from Acme and as soon as I was done with lunch I went right over and bought some to take home. Ever since then, I buy some whenever I'm done there. It's just sooo good!
author: Diane M.

description: Amazing bread.  Their olive bread is the best.  It's the only bread I buy when bringing stuff to a pot luck or if I'm serving a ton of people a big bowl of pasta.  Bake it drizzled in olive oil or butter and some basil or chives.  It's delicious.
author: Honey L.

description: Cheese wheel and validated parking.  Friggin' awesome!
author: Ed C.

description: BREAD....its an element on the periodic scale named Br. Not bromine. Its an element like carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, phosphorus and silicon that we breath everyday. My one complaint about SF bread is that it ALL tastes like sourdough cuz of that silly bacteria in the air. Its silly because one time it slipped on a banana peel just to make me chuckle. Of course it worked! Im a sucker for physical comedy. Anyway, of all the people that make bread, ACME stands out in my book, especially the rosemary bread with unsalted butter dipped in some kind of zauce italiano. If i remember, their black olive loaf was tasty too. I also wish it were as a available in this city as ironic tshirts, iPods, and apathy.
author: Mick F.

description: The Foccacia is sooooo good! I think its only like $6 for a huge loaf! I have driven from the Peninsula all the way to SF for Acme bread, its that good. TRY IT!
author: Norma B.

description:
fluffy loaves. (ciabatta, sweet loaf, sour loaf, pain de mie)  thats what this place can provide! other bakeries are more about the sweets, the muffins, the good coffee, this place has chosen one arena, milky fresh bread and hit a home run. but hot damn, the croissants are really good too. 

activity to go: buy a pain de mie and make french toast with cinnamon sugar.  buy a ciabatta and make olive oil and sea salt crispers.  buy a sour loaf and some good cheese and make a heavenly grilled cheese. hungry yet?
author: Liz S.

description: It the friggin' staff of life, people.  Walking up to the counter and taking in the aroma wafting from the fresh from the oven goods just beyond the racks makes me miss my college bakery job...this misty watercolored recollection doesn't happen at every bread store, but Acme really hits me where I live.
author: L W.

description: I consider myself to be a bread connoisseur (or snob) so I'm really picky and critical of the bread I eat. Life is too short to eat bad bread! I must say that I have not at all been impressed with Acme lately. Their bread is too light and airy. I prefer heavy, dense breads that put up a fight as I'm biting into them.
author: Anastasia B.

description: To put it bluntly, this is the best bread I've ever had.  I've been going here nearly weekly for the past few months, and each time I try to get a roll or piece I haven't tried before.  I've yet to be disappointed.  Great stuff.  And their cheese sandwich is amazing.
author: Kurt M.

description:
acme haiku

crusty bread sandwich 
heaven that costs five fifteen
no crumbs for pigeons
author: Barney B.

description: All the bread that I have had there is FANTASTIC!  I go there every Saturday and buy the same thing but I can't ell you what it is unfortunately.  :)
author: Mark M.

description: The smell of fresh baked bread fills me with happiness.  I love everything inside Acme, especially at 8am when nothing is sold out.  If you like raisins, the rye raisin roll is a must try.   (It doesn't taste like rye.)
author: Wakako U.

description: Other then my momma's bread, Acme was some of the only bread I was allowed to eat growing up (we were crazy macrobiotics ;) because it's fresh, natural and wholesome. I have such fond memories of all the wonderful flavors! My selection changes by meal, but staples are always the walnut and the rustic French loaf. This bread is especially tasty when you wet it down then wrap it in foil and heat in the oven at 350 for about 15 minutes, this will give it that toasty just baked deliciousness that we all love :)
author: Hazel Grace D.

description: Good bread, but not so easy to cut. And they don't have a slicing machine on premises either (it's the little things in life, ya know?). Nevertheless, Acme Bread Company clearly knows their was around a loaf. Grab a few items next time you're in the Ferry Building.
author: Julia D.

description: Yum...Carbs! I always swing by Acme after hitting the Cowgirl Creamery. Perfect bread to go with their amazing cheeses, all at really fantastic prices.
author: Brianne K.

description: Almond croissant comparable to ones from a Paris boulangerie.  Cheese sandwich is always sold out before I can buy it!  Good deli roll.  Okay cheese wheel and olive roll.  Patient counter clerks.
author: Ai M.

description:
epi. epi. epi.

Epi. Epi. Epi.

EPI! EPI! EPI!

Today, outside the Ferry Building, transferring trains on the Muni:
G., "Do we need bread?" (*hint *hint)
(seriously, when do we ever neeeeed bread?)
Me, "Wanna go to ACME?!"
author: Carnley P.

description: So good I pee myself just a little each time I visit.
author: Jordan M.

description: Acme Bread is the BEST bread.  anywhere.  we were on a long trip and it was just impossible to find good bread.  Acme breads are awesome and worth staying in SF for.  really.  Whole wheat walnut is so awesome.  whole grain plus nuts in a round shape could be completely scary, but it is so so so good!  The herb slab is pure fun.  Olive roll is great for snacking on while walking around the Ferry Building.  bring your cash and get some awesome bread!!
author: Lisa A.

description: I didn't know what I wanted to eat for lunch. Was just wandering the Ferry Building, aimlessly looking for... entertainment... gifts... wine... something to preoccupy my lunch hour. And I saw it. Acme. I love their breads. Their onion loaf has always added that extra something to my home cooked meals. Then it hit me. They have sandwiches. I had heard the salami sandwich was great and thought I would have one. But no. I saw on the menu a cheese sandwich made with Cowgirl Creamery Mt. Tam cheese. And jelly. Who could turn down a cheese and jelly sandwich. Not me, of course. And it was heaven. The bread slightly crunchy, the cheese so soft, the jelly a perfect match with the cheese. Can I have one every day?
author: Valerie V.

description:
the variety of breads here isn't as great as i would expect, but 65 cents for a single rosemary roll isn't so bad.  i'd like to one day try their green onion loaf though, once i find enough people to share with.

oh and very upsetting as they must know that every goes and gets some cowgirl to go with their bread.  why can't the slice up my bread?!
author: spiff e.

description: Great bread. Great service. Go to the Cowgirl creamery next door. Acme can recommend exactly what bread to use with the cheese you pick out next door. Also, supppper affordable. Especially for the quality you are getting!
author: Ashley G.

description: Cranberry walnut makes breakfast for 2-3 days. So good with butter and coffee. Do not overlook the olive loaf a well with a simple cheese is awesome app. Convenient and affordable.
author: Eric K.

description: The best bread in town. Period. And that marble counter is pretty nice too!
author: Frederic B.

description:
i'm usually giving by nature, but don't ask me to share their cranberry walnut bread with you.  it's not that i won't, it's that i CAN'T!  please don't ask me to.  please don't put me in this awkward compromising situation.

now that i think about it, all their breads are lovely and oh so very tasty.  and they're CHEAP considering all that artisanalferrybuilding brouhaha.  

besides, carbs are your friends!
author: Bird B.

description: Wonderful breads.  Reasonably priced.  Terrific place.
author: Matthew C.

description: So begins my career as a Copycat Yelper. I think I will be following in the footsteps of Mary Correa's archived works... I am tormented by thier chocolate crossaint. It's like having a crush within your same social circle. One (or two) is always waiting for me there within a 5 minute walk of my office. I am that pastry on a good day: golden on the outside, fluffy white on the inside, with a hardcore of chocolate. On a bad day, it's my redemption. I know, I know, I worship false gods. If you could not tell by now...
author: Jean W.

description: Unfortunately, I did not get to try any of the bread! So, for all I know they may have fantastic bread, but they are poor business people. They claim to be open until 7:30 however when I arrived around 6:30... after finding a thousand quarters to pay for a meter and going to the ATM to get cash since they do not accept cards... surprise surprise they were closed with a small sign taped up reading "Sorry, we ran out of bread"! Its ridiculous for a bread company to run out of bread especially in an area like the Ferry Building that requires planning i.e. parking or public transportation to visit. I generally love everything in the ferry building and I was looking forward to getting fresh bread, oh well.
author: Tara T.

description: Im a carb girl...this I cant hide. They make some of the bead bread in the bay, this is undeniable. ACME always serves up some pretty darn good bread and always fresh. It seems like when I eat out at restaurant, most of the bread is from ACME too. I'm know a usual here since the BF hooked on my special...I use the cinnamon currant as the bread for my french toast. The olive, ciabatta and epi are some my favs too, did I mention most are $2 or less each?
author: Lola L.

description: Wanna know why there's always empty space on the bread rack at Whole Foods where the ACME sour batards should be? Because they're delicious. Whenever i get the chance to get to an actual ACME shop, like this one at the Ferry Building i usually need a spare pair of pants to change into, especially if there's a place that sells some nice cheeses near by (can you say cowgirl creamery?). Oh yes, yes i can.
author: Travis D.

description: This has to be my most favorite bread in the Bay area!  Can't go wrong with anything here! My favorite is the Italian Rustic-so crusty yet chewy. Stop by the creamery next door and have yourself a picnic now! FYI-cash only (bummer).
author: Trish B.

description:
the best bread in SF!  acme bread company bakes a large variety of fresh baked breads.  they have a sample all the breads laid out on the front counter.  check it out!  

i go for the rustic baguette and the sour dough round.  bring cash!  it's cash only...and be prepared for a short line.
author: Wendy S.

description: I don't know what they put in their ciabatta, but between an Acme loaf, some cave-aged gruyere, and a split of red, I'm set for lunch. Europe, eat your heart out!
author: Vikram K.

description: As good as bread gets. I wish I could open a little place where I could sell subs made with this bread, cow girl cheese, and boccalone meat. mmmmm
author: Jeff S.

description: The bread is amazing. I love their sourdough. However, I can't help but feel like a jackass waiting in a bread line on Saturday morning.
author: Jennifer S.

description: So when I use to work in the Ferry Building, I needed something to get me through the long hours in the kitchen, something that I could munch on while plating up desserts. I come here and find yummy ham and cheese croissants filled with ham and cheese, not tit bits of it. There's also another item, cinnamon and raisin loaf? I forgot the name, but that's a great breakfast item to get for the next morning. I love standing there watching them work in the back making bread and pulling breads out of the oven when I'm on my break.  Satisfies my carbs even without consuming any. *Cash only*
author: Juliane N.

description: I, literally, quiver when I think about the bread here.  It makes me crazy, like french fries and ketchup from McDonalds, uughghghghghghg.
author: Claire C.

description: Tried the rye bread with raisins, it was filled with raisins upon every bite. $1. *Satisfied and happy customer*
author: Yan M.

description: VERY fresh bread. It reminds me of the sandwiches store in Europe train stations. I just order the basic, ham sandwich.
author: Ervinna L.

description: EXCELLENT. Pan Epi is SO good you will love it and go back for more whenever you can. The cheese rolls are really good as well. I'm sure the other items are worth trying but I cannot get over the pan epi so I always get that instead...
author: Emily A.

description: Great selection of freshly baked goods, friendly service, cash only.  The bread they recommended to serve with cheese from cowgirl and some wine, was spot on.
author: Aaron T.

description: What a treat to take home and eat! Fresh, melt in your mouth goodness.
author: Jewel N.

description: I like Acme bread.  In fact, I'm hard pressed to say that their bread isn't five stars.  It is.  We live in a good bread town, in good bread time in the world.  I will say that I think that Grace Bakery does an excellent sourdough walnut bread (a round) with nuts, and my favorite seeded sourdough baguette is Semifreddi's.  All that being said, I still think the Acme products are five star.  That walnut levain?  Amazing.
author: Laurel B.

description: Okay so I'm not usually trying to scarf down extra starch without anything in the middle (get your mind out of the gutter...talking about a smwich or burger here!), but their Herb Slab is insanely tasty all by itself or if you want...to dip in olive oil and ground pepper.  Trust!
author: Greg R.

description: I love bread. I love baking it, smelling it, eating it or just looking at it. Acme is wonderful because they bake everything fresh and their breads are always perfect. Crusty crusts and moist, flavorful insides. My favorite has to be the herb loaf. It's perfect for eating with some Stonehouse Dipping Oil or some cheese from the Cowgirl Creamery. In fact, the Boyfriend and I almost always make a stop at these three places. Acme is cash only so make sure you have enough on hand to stock up on some loaves!
author: Christine P.

description: Chikachika Herbslab - for real. I love me some bread and they happen to have a rather delectable assortment. And lucky you - they happen to be right by Cowgirl Creamery..too perfect right? That's what I thought.
author: Natalie G.

description: The absolute freshest, tastiest baked-today loaves in San Francisco.   A local treasure.
author: Max L.

description: BEST BREAD in the city!!!  Try the rosemary rolls...UNBELIEVEABLE!!!
author: Sarah D.

description: Great bread, Great prices and Great employees running the show.. I have NEVER had a bad experience at this place.. My family and I love their products and we have tried many of them.. The employees are ALWAYS so nice and polite..... unlike some places that are busy and take for granted they have good business, the Acme employees are still friendly ... (I love great customer service) and too........... they are quick without being pushy... If you love great bread, then this is your place. They also make a GREAT panetone around the holidays....
author: Susan L.

description: Absolutely just LOVE their breads! I live in the South Bay and whenever I'm in SF, I always have to stock myself up with their Epi breads! Really the best, especially with just something as simple as butter!
author: Annabel N.

description: I just ate an entire loaf of the pain epi in one sitting.  All I can say is that it was still warm from the oven and I'd do it again. Divine - perfect crust.
author: She-Ra ..

description: Everytime I come to the Ferry Building, one of my first stops is the Acme Bread Store. I keep forgetting what the bread is called, but it's the one that looks like a tree branch. Anyways it's so good with just some butter or with some olive tapenade. Also whenever I feel like kickin up my steak sandwiches, I'll pick up a nice sour dough bagguette. Just writing about this wants me to go and get some bread. Acme Bread Co heree I come!
author: jung j.

description:
yes, it is that good.

if i didn't care about my health and wasn't concerned about the opposite sex, i would glut myself on the stuff everyday until the jaws of life came to free me from my own house.
author: eve l.

description:
i've actually only like five or six of their breads... but so far so good right?  i've always been a fan of the herb slab, although the green onion slab is a close second.  the olive bread is good too, but i'm not that big into olives.

i am sure i can find better focaccia or baguettes elsewhere, but i think acme is a good centralized place to get all kinds of good bread.  this way, i don't have to make several different trips to get the best.  one trip and i already have pretty good bread.
author: H. L.

description: I LOVE BREAD and Acme makes the BEST bread in SF. The lines are helllllaaa long, but definitely worth the wait. If you are lucky enough to hit up Acme between 11am and 2pm, definitely try one of their sandwiches!
author: Angela T.

description: Olive bread rolls and rosemary bread rolls will make your dinner party a success.  Excellent texture and decadent flavor.  If you are in the ferry building, set some cash aside and pick up some bread.  Their apple turnovers are also excellent.
author: Lisse Q.

description: I could devour one of the amazing loafs of bread in just one day! I love carbs and I love their bread! They have a whole bread making operating system in the back and it's awesome to know their bread is fresh and not shipped from somewhere else.
author: Lynne T.

description:
this is my favorite bread company among the well known bread companies - boulangerie bay bread and arizmendi bakery.

whenever im at the ferry building, i always stock up on their sour baguette, twinkle, green onion slab, torpedo roll, and chocolate croissant.

the only complaint i have about the chocolate croissant is i wish the filling had more chocolate in it.    

death by acme's carbs.  that's all i have to say.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
you know what?  i used to delliver their bread!  
and i gotta say,  caps lock please THEY ARE THE BEST!
the bakers are great,  the owner and his family are great, my boss was my second dad, the restaurants i delivered to were THE BEST IN THE BAY AREA chez panizze, claremont, zaks tavern, cesar, cafe rouge in berkeley,  angele, acme chophouse in napa, terra in st helena, hurley's in yountville, wappo in calistoga, coppola, 
farralon, masa's  this is the only bread to buy.  
it is made with LOVE 
you can freeze it if you don't use it all,
and the walnut levain makes the best banana bread pudding and french toast you will ever eat!
ok, obviously i am a fan.
author: yayoi s.

description: Who knew bread could be so heavenly!  I go out of my way just to get a loaf of bread from Acme.  It's always fresh.  I love the ciabatta and the french bread.  Soooo goooood!
author: Miss T.

description: The olive rolls, oh the olive rolls. Everything here is excellent quality and very fairily priced, but those rolls are going to be the death of me. The best 70 cents you'll spend in the city...
author: Amanda B.

description: I wish I lived closer to the city i would probably get all my bread from here. awesome fresh baked artisan breads. Some of the guys workin there could be nicer but whatever im in and out and its a great product. Go to cowgirl creamery before or after and sit outside make a little snack.
author: G P.

description: This was a good sandwich. Only three varieties, but at $5 for a very generous slab of bread filled with some goodness, I'll deal with the limited selection. I went with the potato pesto and it was really good. Wish they weren't already made (required some scooping of excess pesto and cheese off), but that aside, the combo of roasted potatoes and the bread was delectable.
author: Jason B.

description: Acme Bread really deserves these stars. Aside from the impressive selection of breads, their seasonal five-dollar (and change) sandwiches are one of the few legitimately cheap options in this area's sea of overpriced lunch spots. Plus the green garlic sandwich is amazing.
author: Ryan C.

description: I don't usually give 5-star ratings easily but this place is very cool. First of all, the whole Ferry building experience is very cool ever since they remodeled the place. And you walk by this place and are wowed by the presentation and the freshness. Pricing is reasonable considering the quality. I usually buy their stuff at Whole Foods but have been to this location several times. I usually "have to" get the potato bread or pain rustique, but it's always fun to try new things. Definitely recommend if you love bread. I've never bought bread as a gift before this place (still kind of weird, but my friends also love this place).
author: Al B.

description: GREAT sourdough!  Why is it we can only get good sourdough in SF??  Really good croissants, sourgough cheese rolls, and a pure evil ham and cheese turnover.  Grab an herb or green onion slab, some cheese next door at Cowgirl Creamery, and watch the world go by in the Bay.
author: Michael M.

description: Changed my mind the get four stars because now that I work in the near them and eat it every day I realize just how superior it is to other bread companies
author: Sarah S.

description: I can't walk past this place without getting SOMETHING.  My favorites: the croissant, pain au chocolat, and herb slab.  I'll never view flour, yeast, and eggs the same way again.
author: M A N I K.

description: They have an assortment of pre-made delightful little sandwiches - salami or potato or cheese. I think they have them every day from 11am-2pm. I got one on Tuesday morning while I was shopping at the Farmers Market. The cheese sandwich is delicious - rustic baguette with Cowgirl Creamery triple cream cheese (sorta like Brie) with black pepper, arugula and fruit spread. It's the perfect combination of crunch and pepper and sweet and salty. For 5 bucks, it's a pretty good deal.
author: Maren P.

description: I usually come to ACME for a bag of their croutons. They are nice and crunchy, and infused with olive oil so it doesn't taste like stale bread. Also try the soft burger bun ($0.70), very good compare to supermarket-brand.
author: Joy H.

description: The Italian Long Loaf is so yummy I could eat a whole loaf in one sitting with a cube of butter and some cheese or jam.  Mmm...
author: Katie S.

description: This place has good bread but I wouldnt patronize this place unless I was going to the Farmer's market.
author: Fatty A.

description: I had the asiago cheese wheel and it was just ok.  I've had better asiago+bread at Arizmendi.  Plus it wasn't warm how I like, but I guess I can't complain b/c it was 10am.  Still, Acme didn't meet my expectations.
author: Derrick V.

description: I do not care how long that line is.  If you are at the Ferry Building get in that line and grab the best bread in town.  The sweet baguette is THE BEST!!
author: Bleep S.

description: UPSTAIRS BREAD is now my favourite loaf from Acme. Sadly they don't bake it on Sundays! I also bought a delightful conconction that they call 'not so cross bun' - not too sweet, perfect for teatime or breakfast!
author: Writer G.

description: Great breads - can't get enough of the country bread and olive bread. This is the place to pick up the bread for your gazpacho or pappa al pomodoro (Tuscan tomato and bread soup) - after you shop the Farmer's Market stands or for any recipe for that matter!
author: Mariangela S.

description: Have been off the old baked goods for a while, but after a wee taste of the Pain Au Levain at the Ferry Building last weekend, Bob and I are now on our second loaf in 3 days...
author: Carrie A.

description: Nothing beats fresh bread and good cheese!   Make sure to consume what you buy in the same day because it will not stay soft!  For cheese and butter, go see the spot next door at Cow Girl Creamery (St. Patrick's Brie) and for your favorite meat, it is a little further down at Molinari's.
author: Jason A.

description: Oh yeah dude, this place has all the most delicious bread you can choose from.  I usually get a baguette and stop by the cheese store next door to go along with my bread and enjoy!!!
author: David C.

description: I'm not a huge fan of bread...I know, I know...crazy concept, isn't it?  But my kids and I ate the WHOLE loaf of onion slab today, as we walked through the Ferry Building several times.  It was a softer bread with shreds of onion baked into it- tasty, moist and delicious!  We wanted MORE but unfortunately the Ferru Building closes at 5 on Sundays.
author: Judy K.

description: Unfortunately I have not tried any of their sandwiches or cheeses, but we stopped by to get a couple pan epi's for our trip to Napa Valley for a good ol' wine country picnic. Yummy bread!
author: S. D.

description: Their hot cross buns are awesome! We just had them the day after we bought it and it was still soft and delicious. We also had the sourdough which was, of course, great too.
author: Veronica M.

description: Mmmmmmm, bread, just smell it in all it's doughy, chewy, goodness!  Croissants, pastries, they do it all right!
author: Rob M.

description: I swear, there's something in the air around the Ferry Building that gets into the bread here that just makes it even better that usual.  I always go for the parmesean rolls or the herb slab(even though for some reason the word slab makes me a little uncomfortable). Great bread, so glad I work in the same building so I can partake in it five days a week.
author: Emily L.

description: Do we need any more proof that the Atkins diet is stupid than Acme Bread?  The Pain au Levain is one of the most perfect things ever to grace the face of the earth with its presence.
author: Ficus K.

description: I could make a meal out of the bread here.  I'm a true bread person and this is hands down, THE BEST.  I'm not comparing it to European Bakeries, but definitely around here it's the best.   They have this one roll that has asiago cheese in it all melted around it.  It's also cheap!  I just wish there were more locations so I could have it all the time.
author: Laurin A.

description: So many different kinds of bread!!! Don't  make me choose just one! I want them all!
author: Natalie H.

description: came here specifically to buy some sourdough when I first got to SF.  Tasty, fresh, and cheap.  Oh, and the place smells delicious!  All the breads looked excellent too...I want to go back here to get some of their hotdog buns for the sausages at the stand right next door.
author: Brett T.

description: I love their almond croissants and their various rolls and loafs. I work upstairs from this place, so whenever I'm craving carbs, I stroll on down and get my fix from here. Crossaints, rolls, cinamon rolls, sandwiches, oh my! I heart carbs!
author: Joshua C.

description:
Why is it so hard to find good bread this side of the pond? Grocery stores in Europe have better rolls than most bakeries in the US. But, Acme lives up and has renewed my consumption of warm, crusty bread. My favorite is the Pain Epi. Though, I usually end up chewing off a chunk before I make it the 5 blocks home. It's even still good the second day, with a little toasting. 
Avoid the almond croissant. Just ok.
author: Vidya R.

description: You cant go wrong with Acme bread.  That's why so many restaurants that dont make their own bread serve Acme's (so I've noticed).  Crisp, perfect crust with a chewy center texture.  It's perfect. I pick up a few pain epi loaves whenever I visit the Ferry Building.
author: Lauren S.

description: Bread and butter is, well, my bread and butter.  Acme has delicious breads and all kinds of lovely carb-y treats.
author: Annette K.

description: I like to think I'm Parisian and pretty much turn my nose up now at any bread that's not Acme. There's just no other better bread bakery that I have found in the city. $2 for my baguette that I try not to finish by the time I walk home...little special sandwiches on Sat mornings...awesome staff...this IS as good as it gets.
author: Abbie B.

description: I've never had a bad bread here! My co-worker got me on to the herb and olive slab. I've repeatedly gone back to get more. Then, i ventured out, and tried the current cinnomin rolls - they are the best cinnmon rolls EVER. A staple product here is the sweet baguette. You think you've had a good bagette, until you try the baguettes here! Something so simple and yet so good purely becuase its made with quality ingredients AND that it just came out of the oven!!! Bread is ususally warm here. You wont have this experience from store bought bread. Try this bread with a thick beef stew or clam chowder - you'll know what i'm talkin about. Everyone I buy this bread for, just loves it!
author: Mai T.

description: The bread from this place is so good that I now base menus around it.  When I get the yen for green onion slab, we have to have a soup that complements it.  Cinnamon stickies call for eggs and bacon, rolls call for Moroccan egg sandwiches or ham and butter, the ciabatta inspires broccoli rabe bruschetta.  The smell alone makes you glad to be alive.   I agree with some of the other reviewers that the staff seem oddly cheerless given their bay view and unlimited access to the chocolate croissants and foccaccia.
author: Margaret F.

description: Love it.  Although the line is long it moves fast, especially the earlier you are there.  So the small sour dough bread round is yummy.  I lived in France for a yr and the bread is on par w/ the bread stores in our old neighborhood.  My mom swears by the almond croissants and i think the butter croissants can give France a run for their money.  Also you can almost always get hot bread out of the ovens.  I ALWAYS stop there when I go to the Ferry Building.
author: Nicole F.

description: Beautifully baked baguette for less than $2. My favorite artisan bakery in SF. When I want my sweet baguette, I go to Acme. When I want my sour baguette, I go to Arizmendi's.
author: DANIEL T.

description: As an artisan bread baker myself, I can appreciate the hard work that goes into baking good loaves of bread.  I stopped here during my first visit ever to San Francisco and picked up a little rustic loaf to go with the brie I'd picked up at the Cowgirl Creamery nearby. Since I knew I'd like just about every bread they displayed, I didn't even agonize over my choice.  The staffperson was friendly, the display was neat, organized and labeled, and it looked nice and clean in there.  Bread can still be a relatively cheap pleasure. I could happily have bread, cheese and a bottle of water for lunch several days a week. When I make my future visits to SF I'll try Acme's other breads.  I sure wish there were an Acme in my neighborhood!
author: Allison P.

description: Countless restaurants use their bread throughout the city, so obviously its good. However, the storefront at the Ferry Building is even better. The options are endless and the prices are great. Probably the best burger bun I've ever had...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Besides the La Brea bread that I can find at Whole Foods, Acme has the best bread I've tasted in SF.  When the sky is clear and my mood is good, I'd take a walk to the Ferry Building and buy two loaves.  (Whole Wheat Seeds and Olive loaf are my personal favorite).  Then, I'd find some good olive oil or fruit spread to go with them.  Hm...I think it's sunny out right now.  See you at the bakery.
author: Vivian H.

description: Acme bread is fresh baked & delicious (hit the Ferry Bldg - SF). They have a nice selection including some great rolls - olive, raisin. The pricing is very reasonable. Because it is fresh & without additives/preservatives just buy what you can eat w/in a day or two (or freeze what you can't so you won't have to waste it). Bring cash, they do not take cards of any kind.
author: Abby W.

description: I wish I could get this bread near my house.  I just absolutely love the Levain Walnut; it is amazing.  I am also addicted to the olive bread and the scallion herb slab.   I am going to look for it today at Whole Foods and hope for the best!
author: Ayelet B.

description: Their olive bread (that has green olives) is the best I've had. Their pastries are fab. too!
author: n s.

description: I'm a complete bread snob thanks to this place as anything other than Acme bread just doesn't taste the same to me. The bread is fantastic. And they have so many varities you can't go wrong. Although, I'm a classic sweet baguette, sweet batard or an epi girl, I have branched out and enjoyed the onlive bread,  the crosissants and the brioches...
author: Jennifer S.

description: There is a new disease running rampant in my kitchen. It's breadaholism. I eat bread non-stop all the time. I'll buy a loaf of this at the market or at the Ferry Building and just stick my face in the bag and huff the garlic, rosemary, whatever fumes. Then I tear chunk after chunk of fresh grainy goodness eat it plain or covered in margarine. There's gotta be a help line for this.
author: aaron f.

description:
Dough-ilicious. So delicious. 

I've been a secondary feeder on a lot of this bread. (My sister always buys it. I just eat it.) And I like them all! Carbs wrapped in pure goodness.
author: Jane C.

description: Some of the best bread I have ever had! Excellent 2nd location in the Ferry building, and you can find their bread in many local markets. The staff there is very knowledgeable and friendly. Tons of options, but the baguettes (both sour and sweet) are my favorite.
author: Elisa C.

description: I've been on the bizzaro-Atkins diet for many years now, and just love good bread.  This is best bread around, anywhere.  All the varieties are good, but the a get a basic loaf (like a sweet batard) and be reminded what joy can be had from a slab of bread and butter.
author: nick w.

description: Five stars just for the sourdough cheddar roll.  Grab that, a nice cup of black tea and go sit outside.  It doesn't get any better - just watch that the seagulls don't turd on your head while you're out there.
author: Frankie D.

description: I've eaten an entire herb slab in one sitting.  Why am I so fat???
author: Marcus C.

description: Acme gets top scores in my book.  They have a great selection of classic loaves which are always fresh and well priced.  The hotdog buns and basic loaves rule.  No need for preservatives just eat it up and buy bread more often!  Yum!
author: Michael P.

description: Great really fresh bread at good prices!!!
author: Elaine S.

description: Unfortunately, yes, you can go wrong with bread some times. The exact opposite holds true for Acme. Their bread is some of the best around which is why it's not surprising to see the long lines here. Don't despair, though, it moves reasonably quick. Pick up a baguette, some Cowgirl Creamery cheese, and then sit yourself down somewhere to feed your face.
author: Fern D.

description:
everybody knows that they have good bread...but what i recently discovered is their delicious sandwiches at only $5.  they only have three kinds per day:
1) potato pesto
2) cheese with jam
3) salami
each sandwich does not have many ingredients, but they are premium and delicious.  i love the potato pesto sandwich!  but, they go fast.  you need to look at the yellow side board to see if the sandwiches are still available.  they will have a magnet over the sandwich if it is sold out.

the line moves very fast during lunch time.
author: Yummy E.

description: Best bakery in San Francisco. High quality artisan bread, generally faultless and delicious!
author: John S.

description: Their stuff is so good, I don't even have a favorite -- now THAT is rare for me, given my lifelong love affair with this gift to humankind.
author: Godot -.

description: The best bread in the city. I only eat Acme bread. Fluffy soft inside, crust satisfyingly dense without being too difficult to get through, sweet and a little salty, perfect for buttering. Pretty well distributed.
author: Geronimo G.

description: I LOVE their bread.  Sweet Baguette, herb slab, rosemary roll...etc.  It tastes so good when it's fresh.  It's so hard NOT to eat it on the way home.    =P
author: Jaquelina L.

description: Hands down, the best bread in the bay area. I could feast on Acme bread all day long... pain epi, long italian, sweet baguette, pain au levain, ciabatta, new york rye... seriously the best breads in the city, trust!
author: Monica C.

description: Handy place for when I'm taking the Vallejo ferry across to visit my parents--I get a small roll (or an epi and munch on it all weekend), stop next door and get a cooked italian sausage to stuff in the roll, cup of regular coffee from Peet's and I'm set for the ferry.  Yum.  They also make a delicious cinnamon monkey bread type thing, all sticky and gooey--gave loaves of them as Christmas gifts to my coworkers once year (big hit).  There's a cheese store close by, olive shop, and a wine shop so you can basically get all the things for a good "picnic" out on the Bay side of the Ferry Bldg.
author: Kai T.

description:
acme bread co is the place that would knock you off the carb wagon... seriously.

this is my go to bread place while up in the bay.  i'm a native from la, the wannabe food mecca of the world.  being that la has everything and anything within reach (or a 20 min drive) i feel that there was no place that could beat out my go to bread place (la brea bakery)....

... and i was wrong.  if acme bread co was only a 20 min drive, i'd hit that every morning. *drool*
author: ann.ie k.

description: Best bread in the city by far! I routinely come down here just to buy their sweet rustic baguette.  Crunchy on the outside soft on the inside.  (that's what she said) I've also tried their chocolate croissant  and it's as good as their baguette.  They recently started serving sandwiches, it's definitely on my "to try" list.
author: Brian H.

description: Their herb slab is the best bread on the planet.  I will not argue this point.
author: Jake B.

description: Although this might be my favorite bakery in the city (for bread), I cannot help but feel really rushed when placing my order because of the line and the hectic staff trying to help everyone. Other than that, I love all their variety and prices.
author: Boris A.

description: it's all too appropriate that acme is next door to cowgirl creamery. very little can beat the dynamic duo of fresh bread and cheese. we picked up the potato rosemary, the sour batard, and the onion bread. AMAZING!!
author: dorena b.

description: nice and convenient and good selection of "real" bread.  i think it's a good indicator of how much i have adjusted to living in California.  i would have shit myself a year ago after moving here from Pennsylvania if you said that I would be shelling out six bucks for a loaf of bread without thinking twice, but now, here I am am doing it and not thinking twice!  guess I've adjusted!
author: Jeremy S.

description: Went here during a 10 day trip to SF with my SO.  Our apt was in mission, but we came here one morning for breakfast because it was clear Acme was one of the best bakeries in the bay based on the fact that so many restaurants used them.  Acme breads we had in restaurants were consistently good---crisp crust, chewey crumb.  When we came here, we got the croissant and found it to be excellent---best we've tased in SF (better than Tartine and Thorough).  We also got a ham+cheese turnover, demi-baguette and cranberry-walnut bread.  The turnover was a little disappointing---all the cheese ran out and hardened and the ham was in cubes rather than slices, so it didn't integrate with the dough as well as it could have.  The demi-baguette was on the soft side, both crust and crumb, though it might have been done intentionally since I think it was marketed as a bread for sandwiches.  The cranberry-walnut bread was bad---too hard, under seasoned, heavy, tasted like cardboard.  Might have been better if they had been willing to slice it.  They said "no we don't slice" and "it should be easy to break off pieces".  It wasn't easy, but we struggled anyway until it was clear the taste wasn't worth struggling for.  So, they're clearly an excellent bakery, but not sufficiently perfect to warrant 5 stars.  Thorough was a better overall experience.
author: Jason R.

description: The best chocolate croissants outside of France.  Atkins dieters--you've been warned.
author: Mary C.

description: Try a sandwich! I had the Mount Tam soft cheese with fruit spread on Acme bread and it was out of this world. The bread was crusty on the outside and soft inside, with a great sourdough flavor. The cheese and fruit filling was perfect.
author: Laura C.

description: The best bread in the city. The first time I had Acme bread, at a restaurant, I went a little nuts, it was SO good. The flip side is that it's ruined me for commercially baked and preserved loaves. I cannot abide these inferior products!
author: Frida K.

description: i love you.  you are my favorite bread in the city.  you are my favorite bread in the world.  i eat you at the farmer's market.  i eat you in the ferry building.  i eat you at rainbow.  i eat you at whole foods.  i see your truck driving through the city and my heart swells with love.  sweet baguette.  sour baguette.  olive roll.  whole wheat walnut!!!!!
author: kate s.

description: Well I just found some stiff competition for my beloved ham and cheese croissant from Tartine.  Acme's version is a ham and cheese turnover.  It was so flaky and cheesy and hammy.  I loved it.  My scattered mind doesn't need any more choices in this city.  Tartine, Acme, etc?  I guess, when I'm at work, I will go to Acme, and my weekend splurges will be at Tartine.
author: t l.

description: Best bakery in town, hands down. Great selection of European-style breads. Not much more I can say than get your bread here.
author: Tim T.

description: the cheese turnover was good but a bit too greasy.  the cinnamon currant bread was decadent.  avoid the lunch hour crowd.
author: Big e.

description: I adore this place. The best pain epi in town. Almost every time I'm in the Ferry Building, I stop here for bread and make a stop at Cowgirl for cheese.
author: Look and C.

description: my sunday morning ritual would not be complete without a fresh baguette from ACME, a hot cup of tea, and the weekend journal. the bread here is delightful.
author: ashwin n.

description: acme bread sell sandwiches at lunch! yaaaay!!!!! they only offer two selections- cheese or salami- but they are both deelish... the cheese option (at least the day i went) had arugala, fruit jam, pepper and mt tam triple cream (which if you haven't ever had, you must made a stop by cowgirl creamery to pick some up. you'll think you're eating butter. it is AMAZING). the salami option has arugala and mustard (from what i recall...) best part is that they are only $5! it's the cheapest and best lunch you'll find in the ferry bldg. yum!
author: Kate M.

description: the baguettes are to die for! they make for a yummy appetizer, just spread some olive oil, garlic, roasted red peppers, and some cheese and you are good to go! i also love the herb slab's!!!
author: Suzan L.

description: mmm...i LOVE the new pumpkin bread, which also comes in rolls.  they are filled w/ nuts and dried fruit and are delicious!!
author: Helen T.

description: remember this... they do not slice bread.  do not ask them, they actually get affended and a little hurt when you ask.  but other than that, they do have really good bread.  i especially like their cranberry walnut wheat.  soooo good.  i can eat that ...without butter, untoasted all day long.  they also have a brioche bread that is nice and sweet.  i like the top of that.
author: Janet S.

description: Outstanding bread.  Make your next burger with an Acme roll and you'll take your burger to a whole new level.  Or grab a pain epi with some Cowgirl Creamery cheese and enjoy a lovely picnic.  They sell yummy sandwiches at lunchtime now too.
author: Grace R.

description: this is the only bakery i need.  okay, maybe the occasional pastry or cookie, but for my savory needs, acme is it!  prices are reasonable, they're efficient, and it's perfect every time.  i grew up 2.5 hours away in merced, but i know about acme from the time i was 10, because my folks would bring it home from the city every chance they got.  i stalk restaurants that serve their epi baguettes to start, and i bring home a couple loaves every time i go to the farmer's market.  pumpkim rolls are really good this time of year!
author: nicole l.

description: The bread is very good but what drives me nuts is how they are cash only. Acme is a big company and can afford the small cost of using a credit card processor. This is a small fee per transaction. As a business owner myself, and a small one too, if I can afford it they can. Any company that refuses to accept credit cards in the name of cost is a cheapskate plain and simple. Creating any inconvenience for a customer is a no no. But I love the bread. Just accept debit/credit cards OK???
author: Thomas K.

description: I enjoy walking here during my lunch break and picking up some rosemary, olive or rustic rolls. Quick and yummy snack. Cash only, I believe. It looks like something you would see in the Old World, two cash registers with bunch of bread in the back. I hear they have onion slabs and challas but haven't tried it yet.
author: Mala S.

description: Outstanding!  Delicious!  Amazing!  This is my favorite bread among many tough competitors (Grace, Boudin & Semifreddi).  You just can't beat their sourdough baguettes.
author: Mark C.

description: This place is wonderful.  Everytime I go to the Ferry Building to get medicinal mushroom supplements, caviar, organic persimmons and herbs from Nepal, I stop by for some of this high carb manna.
author: Larry T.

description: Excellent!  I made some paninis with the green onion loaf which went over well.  Not very crusty with the perfect amount of tender, sweet onion slivers inside to make it perfect for eating on its own, or in sandwiches, or with some trader joe's pesto & sun-dried tomato torta! yummm
author: Jia H.

description: They should just stick with their breads (YUM).  Their pastries were extremely disappointing. The croissants were dry and not very tasty. I thought the almond croissant lacked flavor - there were a couple of clumps of the almond filling. The morning bun was dry. Frankly, they tasted stale even though we were there very early in the morning.
author: CC C.

description: Tried there Walnut whole wheat bread with Feta cheese that we got from some other store. It was amazing. I never thought that I can enjoy a bread like this one. Both me and my friend totally loved it. Have to try the other breads as well. Highly recommended
author: Dia A.

description: I don't know about the Ferry Building place, but their dumpster in Berkeley   used to be great. But then starting about 5 years ago, they got a stick up their butt and they started chasing you away from the dumpster. Go to Semifreddi's for bread, not Acme.
author: Geoff R.

description: this is some of the best bread you will find anywhere in the world.  i love the baguettes.  i love the bread.  the only bad, absolutley no shelf life whatsoever, you have to consume their goods w/in 2 days of purchase.  definitely some of the tastiest bread products i have ever had though, especially for the price.
author: Anthony Y.

description: mmm absolutely love the bread and sandwiches, especially the green garlic sandwich. you have to go early on a weekend before the sandwiches run out, and by the end of the day the bread has been out on the shelves and is not quite fresh anymore. well-priced and delicious!
author: I. K.
